headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Noble Energy Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call. Just a reminder, today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introduction, I will turn the conference over to Mr. Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us this morning. We issued 2 news releases this morning: one covering the fourth quarter and our full year earnings; and the second one laying out details on our 2016 plan. We also posted t
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us this morning. We issued 2 news releases this morning: one covering the fourth quarter and our full year earnings; and the second one laying out details on our 2016 plan. We also posted to our website a number of supplemental slides for this call, which you will find helpful as we talk to our prepared comments. And later this morning, our 10-K will be filed with the SEC. 
Following prepared comments from Dave Stover, Chairman, President and CEO; and Gary Willingham, Executive Vice President of Operations, we'll open the call for a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Additional management team available for Q&A are Ken Fisher, Executive Vice President and CFO; Susan Cunningham, Executive Vice President of Exploration and New Ventures; and Keith Elliott, SVP of our Eastern Mediterranean assets. 
I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in the latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
With that, I'll turn the call to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. For more than a decade now, Noble Energy has planned and structured itself to succeed in any market environment. I'm proud of what we've accomplished last year and I feel good about how we are positioned moving th
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. For more than a decade now, Noble Energy has planned and structured itself to succeed in any market environment. I'm proud of what we've accomplished last year and I feel good about how we are positioned moving through this challenging time. 
I'd like to start today's call with a few highlights wrapping up 2015 before focusing on our plans for 2016. Fourth quarter results show our continued operating momentum and focus on prudently managing within cash flow. For the second straight quarter, discretionary cash flow exceeded capital requirements -- capital expenditures. This reflects our asset quality, our portfolio diversity and the ability of our organization to execute. It's also a testament to the swift, decisive actions we took to reduce spending and drive capital efficiency beginning more than a year ago. 
Sales volumes for the quarter averaged a record 422,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was above the high end of our increased guidance. This was driven by the accelerated project start-ups in the Gulf of Mexico, strong asset performance in Equatorial Guinea and Israel, and continued improvement in completion design and infrastructure capacity in the DJ Basin. 
Looking at our full year 2015 accomplishments, it was a year of outstanding operational and strategic execution under the backdrop of a difficult commodity environment. We began last year targeting increased production capacity from our DJ Basin asset, more recognition of the value in our Eastern Mediterranean projects and alignment with our Marcellus partner for future capital spend. By year's end, we had accomplished each of these objectives while transforming our cost structure to match the current environment. This was all achieved while realizing record-safety performance across the business. 
In addition, we took advantage of an opportunity to expand our leading U.S. unconventional portfolio with new top-tier positions in the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin. Initial operating results have exceeded expectations and highlight Noble's technical proficiency with new completion designs and drilling efficiencies.  Our major project execution capabilities were again evident in 2015. We commenced production on both Big Bend and Dantzler in the Gulf of Mexico, while keeping Gunflint in the Alba compression project on plan for 2016 start up. In Israel, an approved and implemented natural gas regulatory framework gives us substantial momentum for future projects and the regulatory clarity necessary for new development to meet the region's growing demand for natural gas.  We ended 2015 with total proved reserves of 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent, which was up slightly versus year end 2014. Excluding the impact of the Rosetta Resources merger and SEC commodity price changes, we replaced 1.5x 2015 production at a replacement cost of around $16 per barrel of oil equivalent. Total organic capital for 2015 was under $2.9 billion, down approximately 40% from the previous year, while unit operating costs were driven to their lowest point in 8 years. At the same time, our average full year reported sales volumes were up nearly 20% over the year before. Part of the increase was the addition of the new Texas assets, but our legacy volumes grew more than 10% by themselves. 
I would now like to take a few moments to describe how we're moving forward in the current environment. Noble Energy is an 84-year-old company. We've been through many cycles before. We believe our high-quality, low-cost and diversified portfolio, combined with capital discipline and tremendous investment flexibility, provides the best formula for the long-term sustainable value creation. Look at 2015 and 2016. Without question, we are achieving more, while spending less. As I look across the E&P spectrum, I believe Noble Energy is competitively advantaged for the future. Protecting the balance is fundamental in this environment. That is why we are committed to managing total cash outflows within total cash inflows at the company level. We started 2016 with $5 billion of liquidity, including $4 billion on our undrawn credit facility. This liquidity has already been further bolstered this year by approximately $200 million in cash proceeds from nonproducing Eastern Mediterranean asset sales. An additional $200 million of capacity was created through the recent dividend adjustment and debt refinancing. We also intend to reduce leverage using additional cash flow from operations or portfolio proceeds beyond what has been captured to date. Cash flow for the year is positively impacted by our hedging position, which covers approximately 35% of our global oil and 25% of our U.S. gas production. As we survey investment opportunities against the outlook for commodity prices, current returns do not justify prior activity levels. We're again pulling back capital aggressively in 2016 and focusing only in those areas where long-term value opportunities make sense. We've further reduced our capital program by nearly 50% year-over-year to $1.5 billion. This will allow us to maintain financial strength and sustain underlying operating capabilities. As part of our intense scrutiny on capital allocation, our operating teams continue to improve capital efficiency, while ensuring that each dollar spent is justified by the future value created. This focus, along with our ability to monetize additional assets, gives us flexibility to adjust in a volatile price environment. 
This year's program targets 2/3 of our capital to the U.S. unconventional business and 1/3 to development and exploration offshore. Gary will go through our detailed development programs in a moment, but first I want to briefly cover our exploration plans and production outlook for the year. Our organic exploration strategy has generated substantial value and created long-term cash flows for Noble over the years. In 2016, we're focused on drilling 2 to 3 offshore wells, while obtaining and interpreting seismic to open up future value opportunities. We see this as a great environment to deepen our exploration inventory of high-quality opportunities at a relatively low cost of entry. 
Now turning to production. In 2016, we expect to deliver volumes of approximately 390,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This is up 10% on a full year reported basis and essentially flat to the pro forma 2015 level. From a quarterly standpoint, we expect the first and third quarters to be higher volume than the second and fourth, with the second half of the year generally equal to the first. We've had a strong start to the year, and I'm optimistic that we can drive new capital and operating efficiencies to outperform our goals. 
In the slides for this conference call, we've provided detailed full year and first quarter guidance. First quarter volumes reflect downtime for the Alba compression project in Equatorial Guinea. 
I will now turn the call over to Gary Willingham, who will review recent performance and the 2016 program at the asset level.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. As Dave noted, from an efficiency and cost perspective, the company is firing on all cylinders, and I'm extremely pleased with the results we are delivering. I believe there's a strong correlation between our reco
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. As Dave noted, from an efficiency and cost perspective, the company is firing on all cylinders, and I'm extremely pleased with the results we are delivering. I believe there's a strong correlation between our record safety and exceptional operating performance. 
I'll start our asset level discussion with the DJ Basin. Fourth quarter total production of 121,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day reflected continued improvement in completion performance and infrastructure development. The DJ Basin was, once again, a big contributor to the company's lower operating costs and production outperformance. Essentially all of the growth in the DJ versus the fourth quarter of 2014 and the third quarter of 2015 has come from liquids, with most of that, oil. The December start up of the Grand Parkway system further reduce line pressures to the lowest levels we can remember and should provide redundancy and improved throughput. Noble's operated Keota plant in East Pony, which came online mid-year 2015, is also running well, supporting our activity in that area. After drilling and completing horizontals in the DJ Basin for more than 5 years now, our team is still driving step changes in drilling results and well performance. Our full year 2015 average drilling cost per lateral foot was down 40% from 2014. As well cost have been substantially reduced, we've also enhanced production performance with optimized completion designs. We continue to focus on slick water as our standard frac load design, which is consistently delivering lower costs and enhanced production per well. The next step in completion innovation and capital efficiency is utilizing the completion design that will allow slick water fracs to be pumped to the tow on long laterals and also with higher proppant concentrations. Actual results on both hybrid gel and slick water wells with higher proppant concentration are exhibiting better initial production and flatter declines compared to our historical jobs. 
For 2016, we plan to operate 2 rigs for the full year, focusing on the Wells Ranch and East Pony development areas. These are our highest valued IDPs, with strong oil contributions and existing infrastructure already in place. Total capital allocation to the basin this year is just under $600 billion. 70% of the DJ Basin well to be drilled in 2016 are planned to be extended reach, many of which will be 9,000-foot laterals in Wells Ranch. We are targeting the drilling of 150 equivalent wells this year, and expect to commence production on slightly more than 200 equivalents.  While these lower activity levels suggest that DJ production will be down somewhat from last year, I'm optimistic that these new completion designs can help offset some of the potential declines. 
Moving over to our Texas assets. I'm pleased with our integration efforts in 2015 and believe we're making good progress in optimizing the performance of these assets. During the fourth quarter, we started production on our first 5 Noble design completions in the Eagle Ford. And based on our review of public data, our first 3 design completions, which tested wider lateral spacing and higher profit concentrations are among the most productive Eagle Ford wells ever completed. We also announced 30-day results on 2 additional wells today. The average 30-day IP for these wells was over 4,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, and this is remarkable when you look on the fact that they were drilled by Rosetta on tighter 500-foot lateral spacing. Production from these 2 wells were normalized to a 5,000-foot lateral is also significantly above our 3 million-barrel EUR type curve which is based on wider lateral spacing. Capital allocation for the Texas assets is approximately $250 million. 60% is expected to be spent in the Eagle Ford, primarily to continue Gate Ranch development. The remaining 40% will be spent to begin our operational appraisal work in the Delaware Basin. Our first 2 completions in the Delaware are beginning production in this month. And while we have flow back capital in these assets from prior expectations, I still expect higher volumes in 2016 versus 2015 pro forma driven mostly by the Eagle Ford. In the Marcellus, total capital for this year is currently planned at $150 million. We've reduced activity to 0 drilling rigs with plans for the JV to be cash flow neutral. Focus will be on a limited number on completions in the nonoperated dry gas area and will be weighted towards the first half of the year. As such, this is expected to deliver modestly higher volumes versus full year 2015. The Gulf of Mexico finished the year strongly with Big Bend and Dantzler starting production during the fourth quarter, ahead of schedule and on budget. Our Gulf of Mexico strategy of pursuing high-quality reservoirs near existing infrastructure generates substantial value. A full year of Big Bend and Dantzler, along with Gunflint start-up, will contribute significant year-on-year oil volume growth during the coming year. Noble's Gulf of Mexico budget is $250 million for 2016. As we complete the Gunflint project, the vast majority of capital will be for exploration and appraisal activities. The lineup includes the Silvergate prospect, which is currently drilling, an appraisal well for our 2014 Katmai oil discovery. Silvergate is a Miocene target with a resource range between 30 and 100 million barrels of oil equivalent gross, with nearby subsea tieback potential. And results are expected by the end of the first quarter. In Israel, natural gas sales volumes averaged to 250 million cubic feet of gas equivalent per day during the fourth quarter. This represents an increase of 9% from the same period last year, mainly due to robust power generation demand. Strong natural gas demand is continuing out to 2016, not only from this year's early cold weather, but also from the expanded use of natural gas over other power generation source fuels. In 2016, we have included approximately $100 million for pre-FID capital expenditures on our Eastern Mediterranean projects. The region is fundamentally short gas and we'll focus this year on finalizing gas sales agreement within Israel and with multiple regional customers. As we progress the technical and commercial readiness of our projects, we are operating with the following principals: First and foremost, ensure that our development concepts match market demand; second, we remain focused on meeting and growing demand for natural gas within Israel, while diversifying our regional market opportunities; and third, we are managing project risk through financing, including the potential involvement of international financial institutions. 
I'd now like to take a couple of minutes and provide an update on our current thinking about the Leviathan development. Along with our FPSO development concept, we are also progressing another design that utilizes a fixed platform to ensure timely first production. The initial development under this fixed platform concept will be anchored by Israeli domestic demand, Jordan power needs and Egyptian industrial demand. While continuing to refine the technical requirements, initial capacity can start at over 1 BCF -- billion cubic feet of gas per day, and is quickly expendable to more than 2 BCF a day. This option provides the most flexibility to match contracted volumes with accelerated development, while retaining the capability to meet existing and growing demand. As you would expect, preproduction capital outlays can be substantially reduced by this design modification, along with the current service cost environment. This will all be firmed up as we move through 2016 securing necessary gas contracts, recosting the final technical project and finalizing project financing to move forward to FID. Additionally, we continue to work with LNG plant owners in the region to secure gas contracts. The combination of our high-quality Eastern Mediterranean reservoirs with idle LNG plants positions us well to be competitive in the global LNG world. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Dave for closing remarks.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. We've highlighted this morning how we executed exceptionally well during 2015. We did what we said we would do and then some. We know these are no ordinary times but Noble is no ordinary company. We've outlined the 2016 program today and ens
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. We've highlighted this morning how we executed exceptionally well during 2015. We did what we said we would do and then some. We know these are no ordinary times but Noble is no ordinary company. We've outlined the 2016 program today and ensures we maintain financial strength and operating capabilities. It provides flexibility to adapt in any environment and positions Noble Energy to build long-term value. We believe the prudent approach is to manage the business with in total cash flow, while keeping our eyes focused on the long-term. How can we say this? Because our diverse portfolio and capabilities have us uniquely positioned to differentially outperform in 2016 and beyond. 
At this time, Debbie, we'll go ahead and open the call to questions.

componenttextpreview: Dave, I first wanted to ask you, Noble has a lot of strong operating momentum in '16 with the Gulf of Mexico, Wattenberg and the Eagle Ford completions. I wanted to see if you could perhaps give us your thoughts, I know it's early, but the sustaining that
componenttext: Dave, I first wanted to ask you, Noble has a lot of strong operating momentum in '16 with the Gulf of Mexico, Wattenberg and the Eagle Ford completions. I wanted to see if you could perhaps give us your thoughts, I know it's early, but the sustaining that operating momentum as you think about 2017?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Arun, I appreciate the comments, and highlighting the momentum that Gary and his team and actually, the whole organization have put in place and realized as we've goen thorough 15, and what we're seeing already moving into '16. As you look beyond '16 and
componenttext: Arun, I appreciate the comments, and highlighting the momentum that Gary and his team and actually, the whole organization have put in place and realized as we've goen thorough 15, and what we're seeing already moving into '16. As you look beyond '16 and to 2017, you have to look at the pieces of the portfolio and kind of just think through each one of those and how they are impacted. The Eastern Med for example, it's going to be flat to up, depending on demand. In the Gulf of Mexico, we should see some improvement in '17 versus '16 because you're bringing Isabella back on, we've got Isabella work over here in the first quarter impacting '16. We'll bring that back on, so you'll have impact of Isabella, and then you'll have a full year of Gunflint in '17. West Africa, you'll have the full year of Alba, which has been impacted this year and '16 by the downtime on the compression project. And that should offset decline on word. So West Africa should be flat to potentially up. So the international offshore portfolio give you good sustenance, if you will, underlaying the production basin. Then in the U.S, I would assume the Texas properties will continue to grow in '17. And then at the current type investment levels, you could see some declines in the Marcellus and the DJ. But when you think about '17 overall, the way I think about it, that's kind of 2016 spending level, you probably remain fairly flat. I think a lot of work and the length of time going to go by on looking at where we want to set up the 2017 program before we go too far down the road as to what we'd actually be spending.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful as we think about 2017. My follow-up or second question is really regards the Delaware Basin. It looks like you guys will be turning in the sales of about 10 wells. Gary, could you give us a little bit of more details around where comp
componenttext: That's very helpful as we think about 2017. My follow-up or second question is really regards the Delaware Basin. It looks like you guys will be turning in the sales of about 10 wells. Gary, could you give us a little bit of more details around where completion activity is focused and a little bit about expectations for those wells? And in addition, maybe discuss some offset wells that you've seen in the area?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say those wells are spread throughout kind of the core part of the acreage that we're focused on. This year remains a bit more of appraisal delineation well as we bring some of our own completion techniques to the basin. So we're just now bringin
componenttext: Yes, I'd say those wells are spread throughout kind of the core part of the acreage that we're focused on. This year remains a bit more of appraisal delineation well as we bring some of our own completion techniques to the basin. So we're just now bringing our first 2 completions on this month with those, we're trying 2 different completion techniques. One with hybrid gel frac that's been more typically used in the area, also our first slick water completion in the area. So we'll see how those perform. We'll continue to test some other things this year. I would expect performance relative to historical performance to be up similar to what we've seen as we brought new completion techniques to the Eagle Ford and some history in the Marcellus and the DJ over the years as we continue to refining things. So still a bit early this year to see what we've got, just bringing the first 2 wells on, but excited to get to those on and see how we continue to progress the development of that acreage.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, the priorities assuming the same price environment, the same as of this year, which is managing that balance sheet, and also keeping an eye on the long-term capabilities that you're continuing to build. I think, as we look at this year, we built
componenttext: I think, the priorities assuming the same price environment, the same as of this year, which is managing that balance sheet, and also keeping an eye on the long-term capabilities that you're continuing to build. I think, as we look at this year, we built the budget -- the capital budget from ground up. We looked at what commitment and requirements we had, and then how much discretionary capital and where would we put the first project to the discretionary capital. I mean that's kind of been in the Texas and DJ Basin right now, and you're watching your cash flow, you're watching where that comes together. So I think, for this environment, we're going to continue to position ourselves to manage within cash flow. And I think, we have the portfolio that allows us to do that and still maintain a strong underlying foundation.

componenttext: Yes, so we are still focused, as we always have been, on delivering a quality product and quality project first. Really, the course of 2016, that's kind of got as Dave said, 4 key areas we're working on. We made a lot of progress in 2015 on the regulatory framework and that's resolved  Now we're focused in on technical work, revised revising and optimizing the development scenario. As you heard, looking at concluding our gas marketing contracts and of course, getting our project financing lined up. And our view is that we can be in a place to have all finished up by the end of 2016.

componenttext: Real quickly. In your prepared remarks and in your slides, you referenced the potential to monetize portions in your portfolio and use that for deleveraging. Can you give us a little bit more color around that in terms of scale, scope? And is there a target leverage metric you're trying to get to? Just kind of any additional color there will be helpful.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we've already seen some of the monetization take place here in the first quarter with a couple hundred million from [indiscernible] and what we've talked about on selling down some interest in Cyprus. I mean, we know we've got some unique a
componenttext: Well, I think, we've already seen some of the monetization take place here in the first quarter with a couple hundred million from [indiscernible] and what we've talked about on selling down some interest in Cyprus. I mean, we know we've got some unique assets in Eastern Med. For example, we know as part of the framework that we're going to sell down some Tamar interest over time. Again, we've got the period -- significant period of time, 6 years, to do that. But it does give you an opportunity at that value is realized, whether it's Tamar or whether it's some interest in Leviathan, to have some assets that are positioned a little differently than some of the rest of the world out there. I think, the other thing we've talked about, and it's still on the shelf, if you will, is just continuing to unlock value in the midstream part of our business. I think, that's another unique high-value asset piece that can help in that whole portfolio mix over some period.

componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave. Like many people with off-shorings and an APB 23 assertion on, that said, that we would continue to reinvest our foreign earnings internationally and not bring them back to the U.S. at that point of time. As we looked at it in '15, at the end o
componenttext: Yes, Dave. Like many people with off-shorings and an APB 23 assertion on, that said, that we would continue to reinvest our foreign earnings internationally and not bring them back to the U.S. at that point of time. As we looked at it in '15, at the end of the year, we removed that assertion and that allowed us to utilize the foreign tax credits very effectively. And so what that means is we have then full fungibility of about a couple billion dollars of additional monies that could be repatriated through time to the U.S. So it adds a lot to our flexibility. And it was, in a sense, a good time because we could utilize the foreign tax credits efficiently.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, it's a reflection of all the customers. I think, the customer base and the customer needs have done nothing but grow, as we've been in discussions over the last year or 2. What this is a reflection of is being able to match up some as these contr
componenttext: I think, it's a reflection of all the customers. I think, the customer base and the customer needs have done nothing but grow, as we've been in discussions over the last year or 2. What this is a reflection of is being able to match up some as these contracts come together, we can make decisions and then scale this as we go. And then essentially, match it to the timing of contracts as they come together to able to keep pushing forward and accelerate. And one of the other things, and Keith mentioned it a little bit, is probably take advantage of actually better cost environment as you start looking at fix platform concept, if that's where we end up with on this because it's, one, it probably utilizes capabilities at the industry a little better; and it probably also ties into what we've already done over there. So there's a knowledge base that's already built. I think, it's kind of win-win on all fronts. No readthrough to any different outlook is for us all the potential customers, I'd say all the potential customers are still at the table. But just the recognition, some things will come to place a different time periods. And as they do, that will enable us to continue to move forward faster.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Thank you, I appreciate that, David. And I guess on that benefit relative to FPSO is scalability. And also is the Israeli domestic market, your view of that market at the end of the decade significantly higher than it was just a couple of years ago, is that fair to say as well?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, it's like the rest of the regional basis, we are seeing more potential demand. I mean, we're seeing -- I think Gary alluded to it briefly, but we're starting to see some indications there could be more demand even come in place as early as this y
componenttext: I think, it's like the rest of the regional basis, we are seeing more potential demand. I mean, we're seeing -- I think Gary alluded to it briefly, but we're starting to see some indications there could be more demand even come in place as early as this year. And we're going to keep a close eye on as this as continued movement to generate more power with gas.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good. I was wondering if I could flip in one other for Ken just in terms of how we should think about project financing. I know it's early. But as you think about '17 and the capital call coming like how should we think about this? Was this consolidated d
componenttext: Good. I was wondering if I could flip in one other for Ken just in terms of how we should think about project financing. I know it's early. But as you think about '17 and the capital call coming like how should we think about this? Was this consolidated debt at the NBL corporate level? Is there another structure here? Just how should we all think about funding this project in a kind of muted commodity price recovery scenario?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've continued, all throughout the last year, to keep the banking sector warm on Leviathan financing, and we still see that there. If you look at the Aramco guys did a very successful financing on Tamar. On a project basis, those bonds actually got
componenttext: Yes, we've continued, all throughout the last year, to keep the banking sector warm on Leviathan financing, and we still see that there. If you look at the Aramco guys did a very successful financing on Tamar. On a project basis, those bonds actually got investment grade rating and continue to trade very well. So our sense is the bank market will be there. Our intent will be not to add the equity in from -- in the Israel but rather leverage the things that Dave talked about in terms of some partial monetization of assets. We just had realized $200 million from nonproducing assets there. And so, I think, the financing will be either a project finance or an RBL type of financing. For our share, it will count as debt. If it's project finance, it will be counted as deb, as we think about it that way. And then we'll also try and leverage multilaterals or export credit agencies to help support projects will financially and from a risk standpoint. So all that effort continues. And so I don't see it as a pacing item to enable sanction.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, it will go hand in hand with some of this. I'll also step back and look at just some of the things that happened over last quarter, over in Israel. We've seen now export approval to Egypt. We've seen longer-term LOIs with parties in Egypt for
componenttext: And I think, it will go hand in hand with some of this. I'll also step back and look at just some of the things that happened over last quarter, over in Israel. We've seen now export approval to Egypt. We've seen longer-term LOIs with parties in Egypt for gas from Leviathan. We've seen additional demand, to your point earlier, about in-country additional demand coming forward for Leviathan gas. So I think where we are with this framework in place, where we are with keeping the external financing parties well aligned as we've pulled this whole thing together, it's just created a lot of momentum, and we just got to keep things moving forward.

And then I have a follow up.

componenttext: You have to look at the different component. So when you compare apples-to-apples for the rest of the program, you've got some of the Gulf of Mexico, both Gunflint dropping off as far as capital needs next year, you've got rig commitments dropping off part of the year next year. Alba compression project will be done this year. So when you look at truly committed portions next year, there's very little, most all the capital next year will be discretionary, there will be driven by what we elect to invest in relative to how we're looking at our cash flow.

componenttext: The good part of our Lower 48 portfolio has essentially been cleaned up and cord up to where were -- what we're focusing on high quality with tremendous upside value opportunities. headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could ask another question about the Eastern Med, and, I guess, everyone wants to ask why you're selling gas for $5 right now. But the news -- the recent news about the Israeli Supreme Court suggesting that the framework should be sent to word, is th
componenttext: If I could ask another question about the Eastern Med, and, I guess, everyone wants to ask why you're selling gas for $5 right now. But the news -- the recent news about the Israeli Supreme Court suggesting that the framework should be sent to word, is that -- should we look at that as just a sideshow? Or is that more part of the main act? And hopefully, you can shed some light on how we should look at that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, it's no surprise that this was going to go through the Supreme Court to be brought up and discussed with an expectation that an [indiscernible] position to the framework was going to take this to Supreme Court, they were going to have weigh
componenttext: Yes. I think, it's no surprise that this was going to go through the Supreme Court to be brought up and discussed with an expectation that an [indiscernible] position to the framework was going to take this to Supreme Court, they were going to have weigh in at a certain point of time. So I'd say this is part of the process right now. I think, what I am focused on and what's important is when you look at the comments from the government on all of this, and the comments on the total framework being critical to move forward, I think, that's definitely in the place that we are. And I go back to how everything's come together as these frameworks come together, how the customers have come to the table, how the demand has probably held up or increased, and how we'd move forward to come up with some alternative as an option that can keep this project, Leviathan projects, especially moving forward as quick as possible, and maybe accelerated on some of the contracts come together. I think, us and the government are in complete agreement on the necessity of the framework and the urgency of the framework, and it's time to keep moving forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, got it. That's helpful. And then if I could just go in a completely direction. The code a results you guys had, in East Pony, could you talk more about that? I think, you mentioned that they were kind of equivalent to some of the Niobara wells in
componenttext: Got it, got it. That's helpful. And then if I could just go in a completely direction. The code a results you guys had, in East Pony, could you talk more about that? I think, you mentioned that they were kind of equivalent to some of the Niobara wells in there which sounds really good. And I'm wondering if that -- how much appraisal zone might be part of '16, if you can kind of take your temperature on that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have any drilling in '16 yet, to be honest, we've drilled the one-off in East Pony to date, the [indiscernible] gets quite a bit better up in that part of the field. So the one we drilled was more of an appraisal type test to see what we will get.
componenttext: I don't have any drilling in '16 yet, to be honest, we've drilled the one-off in East Pony to date, the [indiscernible] gets quite a bit better up in that part of the field. So the one we drilled was more of an appraisal type test to see what we will get. We are very encouraged with the results and how they compare to the Niobrara development in the area, we need to see how that holds up a bit over time and where that could lead to. But the code in that there are certainly not anything we really counted on to much in development plans in the past. So it could be interesting.

componenttextpreview: No, Dave. And that's a good the point to make sure we emphasize that we're not. We've essentially assumed a fairly flat demand given how strong the demand was in 2015. And so besides any interruptible impact, the other thing we're watching pretty close is
componenttext: No, Dave. And that's a good the point to make sure we emphasize that we're not. We've essentially assumed a fairly flat demand given how strong the demand was in 2015. And so besides any interruptible impact, the other thing we're watching pretty close is just the in-country demand. As I said, we're starting to see some indications that there is some more push to get more gas for power instead of other fuels, and just don't really have a field for how much of that could be but we'll be watching that pretty close this year.

componenttext: I'd say you can see that start to trickle in fairly soon. By first half of the year, which could start to see some impact of that hopefully.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then last year, you made a pretty strategic apposition of Rosetta and there's been a lot more pain in the industry, and you talk about your move on the tax side that make more liquidity available. How do you think about additional opportunities as Nob
componenttext: And then last year, you made a pretty strategic apposition of Rosetta and there's been a lot more pain in the industry, and you talk about your move on the tax side that make more liquidity available. How do you think about additional opportunities as Noble's consolidator going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, as we've talked about in the past, we'll continue to do our business development work to look at what would the priorities mainly from quality of assets. Rosetta jumped to the front because of the quality asset and the value we felt we could brin
componenttext: I think, as we've talked about in the past, we'll continue to do our business development work to look at what would the priorities mainly from quality of assets. Rosetta jumped to the front because of the quality asset and the value we felt we could bring to that asset base. So anything else going forward, will have to have the same attributes. I said right now, I'm just not seeing things close the gap on expectations from buyer and seller at this point. So it's not something I anticipate anytime real soon. But we keep our capacity and financial firepower available to take advantage of opportunities. But I'd say those will be further down the road at this point. What we don't want to do is take on in other people's problems. It would have to be high-quality assets that also would make a positive difference from an overall balance sheet and just future quality and opportunity base for the company.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Going back to the Eastern Med, you spent some time talking about the various volumes impact. Can you talk more on the pricing? In the current low oil price and tough spot natural gas price environment, how do you see some of the Eastern Med export gas price opportunities looking and how oil prices versus spot LNG prices versus what you're already getting with the Israel contract would play into that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just a quick overview and then, Keith, who is closer to it can talk a little bit about that. When you look in and even go back to how we are talking about contracts before. There's a mix of different contracts and what you're competing with. You're c
componenttext: I'll just a quick overview and then, Keith, who is closer to it can talk a little bit about that. When you look in and even go back to how we are talking about contracts before. There's a mix of different contracts and what you're competing with. You're competing, in some cases, against importing LNG or higher cost fuels into countries at different points. On some places like that existing idle LNG plant, you're looking at what makes sense there given that you've got a high quality known gas source that you can tie-in with probably one of the lowest cost LNG plants in the world. So you're kind of balancing both of those types of contract and potential pricing outlook. So each one has a different characteristic. I'll let Keith talk about how he is seeing things playing out.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Mark. As Dave said, we see the market to be the regional market to be to fundamentally connected but slightly different markets. In one case, you're competing against the alternative of being imported LNG. In the other case, you're competing
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Mark. As Dave said, we see the market to be the regional market to be to fundamentally connected but slightly different markets. In one case, you're competing against the alternative of being imported LNG. In the other case, you're competing into the LNG global market through supply to this idle LNG plants in the region. And so as you look at that market, that I'll call it, more connected to regional pipeline export, then what you see there is a market that's a very well represented by the existing contracts that we have in place, and certainly, in some cases, some premiums to those contracts.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, when you look at it on the scope of different things, current contracts in place in Israel, I probably wouldn't expect a whole lot of price swings on those. I'd say on the future contracts, as Keith talked about, having this known high quality of
componenttext: I think, when you look at it on the scope of different things, current contracts in place in Israel, I probably wouldn't expect a whole lot of price swings on those. I'd say on the future contracts, as Keith talked about, having this known high quality of gas and the quantities that we have it, right adjacent to huge regional demands and growing in-country needs is going to keep us very highly competitive on a global market basis here as we go forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then I'd have to go back to the cash flow point again. You've mentioned a few times that in this environment you want to keep CapEx and cash flow aligned. Is there an oil price or what oil price would no longer represent this environment? Or what oil price would you be more willing to spend above cash flow?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: I mean, that's hard to speculate on at this point. I think you just have to see how it plays out and where your confidence is on where prices going to. I think, no matter what, it makes good business sense to watch your cash and make sure you're directing and allocating our capital to not only the highest return projects, but the projects with the greatest value per dollar invested. And that's just the way we'll continue to look at it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, we look at all the metrics and we also stress test very lower decks than the agencies used. So I think we're comfortable that we can continue to maintain strong liquidity. And as we're not spending -- outspending cash flow, maintain our debt posi
componenttext: I think, we look at all the metrics and we also stress test very lower decks than the agencies used. So I think we're comfortable that we can continue to maintain strong liquidity. And as we're not spending -- outspending cash flow, maintain our debt position in such a way that we're not going to create any issues for ourselves. So I think, that's the prudent thing to do now: Spend within cash flow, manage the business that way, and then if we have some portfolio proceeds, we'll certainly have -- take a look at the back in the context of delevering, as David mentioned, that term loan that we did was there advantageous in another synergy from ROSE and saving about $50 million of annual interest cost. But the other thing that was most attractive was it gave us the ability to potentially pay down some debt as we move forward. All of our debt to date had been bond debt, which had some friction involved in any prepayment. This gives us full flexibility. So that's how we'll manage going forward. And as Dave mentioned, we'll continue to stay closely engaged with the agencies, the recent S&P announcement reaffirming our investment grade rating was welcomed and we'll just have to continue to work through that with other agencies.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: I think, the key, just to add a little bit to that, I think the key has been to get in action early. The other piece to that is, I think we're doing the right thing and the decisions we're making and getting out front of it. I think, we've seen that somewhat reaffirmed in just what the S&P came out with a couple of weeks ago.

Like I mentioned with -- we're not interesting in bringing in any anybody else's problem or something that -- to deal with and take away from our focus on executing the portfolio that we have. So we'll continue to keep our eyes open on what will be attractive to us, and continue to keep a priority list of things like we had when we did Rosetta, but I just don't see anything like that in the near term.

componenttext: I think, we've touched on the pricing. I don't know if I have a lot more to add on that on the demand. They're interested in more gas over there. You have the potential tying in with Cyprus of some port to get more into the EU piece. So you've got a lot of regional pieces moving around and that are interested in the things we just need to focus on bringing things to the table. And what we've talked about here today is that we bring things to the table, we can make decision to move forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Noble Energy Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call. Just a reminder, today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introduction, I will turn the conference over to Mr. Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Debbie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us this morning. We issued 2 news releases this morning: one covering the fourth quarter and our full year earnings, and the second one laying out details on our 2016 plan. We also posted t
componenttext:
Thanks, Debbie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us this morning. We issued 2 news releases this morning: one covering the fourth quarter and our full year earnings, and the second one laying out details on our 2016 plan. We also posted to our website a number of supplemental slides for this call, which you will find helpful as we talk to our prepared comments. And later this morning, our 10-K will be filed with the SEC. 
Following prepared comments from Dave Stover, Chairman, President and CEO; and Gary Willingham, Executive Vice President of Operations, we'll open the call for a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Additional management team available for Q&A are Ken Fisher, Executive Vice President and CFO; Susan Cunningham, Executive Vice President of Exploration and New Ventures; and Keith Elliott, SVP of our Eastern Mediterranean assets. 
I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call contains projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in the latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
With that, I'll turn the call to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. For more than a decade now, Noble Energy has planned and structured itself to succeed in any market environment. I'm proud of what we've accomplished last year and I feel good about how we're positioned moving thr
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. For more than a decade now, Noble Energy has planned and structured itself to succeed in any market environment. I'm proud of what we've accomplished last year and I feel good about how we're positioned moving through this challenging time.  I'd like to start today's call with a few highlights wrapping up 2015, before focusing on our plans for 2016. 
Fourth quarter results show our continued operating momentum and focus on prudently managing within cash flow. For the second straight quarter, discretionary cash flow exceeded capital requirements -- capital expenditures. This reflects our asset quality, our portfolio diversity and the ability of our organization to execute. It's also a testament to the swift, decisive actions we took to reduce spending and drive capital efficiency beginning more than a year ago. 
Sales volumes for the quarter averaged a record 422,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, which was above the high end of our increased guidance. This was driven by the accelerated project start-ups in the Gulf of Mexico, strong asset performance in Equatorial Guinea and Israel, and continued improvement in completion design and infrastructure capacity in the DJ Basin. 
Looking at our full year 2015 accomplishments, it was a year of outstanding operational and strategic execution under the backdrop of a difficult commodity environment. We began last year targeting increased production capacity from our DJ Basin asset, more recognition of the value in our Eastern Mediterranean projects and alignment with our Marcellus partner for future capital spend. By year's end, we had accomplished each of these objectives while transforming our cost structure to match the current environment. This was all achieved while realizing record safety performance across the business. 
In addition, we took advantage of an opportunity to expand our leading U.S. unconventional portfolio with new top-tier positions in the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin. Initial operating results have exceeded expectations and highlight Noble's technical proficiency with new completion designs and drilling efficiencies.
Our major project execution capabilities were again evident in 2015. We commenced production on both Big Bend and Dantzler on the Gulf of Mexico, while keeping Gunflint and the Alba compression project on plan for 2016 start-up. In Israel, an approved and implemented natural gas regulatory framework gives us substantial momentum for future projects and the regulatory clarity necessary for new development to meet the region's growing demand for natural gas.
We ended 2015 with total proved reserves of 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent, which was up slightly versus year-end 2014. Excluding the impact of the Rosetta Resources merger and SEC commodity price changes, we replaced 1.5x 2015 production at a replacement cost of around $16 per barrel of oil equivalent.
Total organic capital for 2015 was under $2.9 billion, down approximately 40% from the previous year, while unit operating costs were driven to their lowest point in 8 years. At the same time, our average full year reported sales volumes were up nearly 20% over the year before. Part of the increase was the addition of the new Texas assets, but our legacy volumes grew more than 10% by themselves. 
I would now like to take a few moments to describe how we're moving forward in the current environment. Noble Energy is an 84-year-old company. We've been through many cycles before. We believe our high-quality, low-cost and diversified portfolio, combined with capital discipline and tremendous investment flexibility, provides the best formula for long-term sustainable value creation. Look at 2015 and 2016. Without question, we're achieving more, while spending less. As I look across the E&P spectrum, I believe Noble Energy is competitively advantaged for the future.
Protecting the balance sheet is fundamental in this environment. That is why we are committed to managing total cash outflows within total cash inflows at the company level. We started 2016 with $5 billion of liquidity, including $4 billion on our undrawn credit facility. This liquidity has already been further bolstered this year by approximately $200 million in cash proceeds from nonproducing Eastern Mediterranean asset sales. An additional $200 million of capacity was created through the recent dividend adjustment and debt refinancing. We also intend to reduce leverage using additional cash flow from operations or portfolio proceeds beyond what has been captured to date.
Cash flow for the year is positively impacted by our hedging position, which covers approximately 35% of our global oil and 25% of our U.S. gas production. As we survey investment opportunities against the outlook for commodity prices, current returns do not justify prior activity levels. We're again pulling back capital aggressively in 2016 and focusing only in those areas where long-term value opportunities make sense.
We've further reduced our capital program by nearly 50% year-over-year to $1.5 billion. This will allow us to maintain financial strength and sustain underlying operating capabilities. As part of our intense scrutiny on capital allocation, our operating teams continue to improve capital efficiency, while ensuring that each dollar spent is justified by the future value created. This focus, along with our ability to monetize additional assets, gives us flexibility to adjust in a volatile price environment. 
This year's program targets 2/3 of our capital to the U.S. unconventional business and 1/3 to development and exploration offshore. Gary will go through our detailed development programs in a moment, but first I want to briefly cover our exploration plans and production outlook for the year.
Our organic exploration strategy has generated substantial value and created long-term cash flows for Noble over the years. In 2016, we're focused on drilling 2 to 3 offshore wells, while obtaining and interpreting seismic to open up future value opportunities. We see this as a great environment to deepen our exploration inventory of high-quality opportunities at a relatively low cost of entry. 
Now turning to production. In 2016, we expect to deliver volumes of approximately 390,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This is up 10% on a full year reported basis and essentially flat to the pro forma 2015 level. From a quarterly standpoint, we expect the first and third quarters to be higher volume than the second and fourth, with the second half of the year generally equal to the first. We've had a strong start to the year, and I'm optimistic that we can drive new capital and operating efficiencies to outperform our goals. 
In the slides for this conference call, we've provided detailed full year and first quarter guidance. First quarter volumes reflect downtime for the Alba compression project in Equatorial Guinea. 
I will now turn the call over to Gary Willingham, who will review recent performance and the 2016 program at the asset level.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. As Dave noted, from an efficiency and cost perspective, the company is firing on all cylinders, and I'm extremely pleased with the results we are delivering. I believe there's a strong correlation between our reco
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. As Dave noted, from an efficiency and cost perspective, the company is firing on all cylinders, and I'm extremely pleased with the results we are delivering. I believe there's a strong correlation between our record safety and exceptional operating performance. 
I'll start our asset-level discussion with the DJ Basin. Fourth quarter total production of 121,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day reflected continued improvement in completion performance and infrastructure development. The DJ Basin was, once again, a big contributor to the company's lower operating costs and production outperformance. Essentially all of the growth in the DJ versus the fourth quarter of 2014 and the third quarter of 2015 has come from liquids, with most of that, oil.
The December start-up of the Grand Parkway system further reduce line pressures to the lowest levels we can remember and should provide redundancy and improved throughput. Noble's operated Keota plant in East Pony, which came online mid-year 2015, is also running well, supporting our activity in that area. After drilling and completing horizontals in the DJ Basin for more than 5 years now, our team is still driving step changes in drilling results and well performance.
Our full year 2015 average drilling cost per lateral foot was down 40% from 2014. As well cost have been substantially reduced, we've also enhanced production performance with optimized completion designs. We continue to focus on  slickwater as our standard frac fluid design, which is consistently delivering lower costs and enhanced production per well.
The next step in completion, innovation and capital efficiency is utilizing the completion design that will allow our slickwater fracs to be pumped to the tow on long laterals and also with higher proppant concentrations. Actual results on both hybrid gel and slickwater wells with higher proppant concentration are exhibiting better initial production and flatter declines compared to our historical jobs. 
For 2016, we plan to operate 2 rigs for the full year, focusing on the Wells Ranch and East Pony development areas. These are our highest-value IDPs, with strong oil contributions and existing infrastructure already in place. Total capital allocation to the basin this year is just under $600 billion. 70% of the DJ Basin well to be drilled in 2016 are planned to be extended reach, many of which will be 9,000-foot laterals in Wells Ranch. We are targeting the drilling of 150 equivalent wells this year, and expect to commence production on slightly more than 200 equivalents.  While these lower activity levels suggest that DJ production will be down somewhat from last year, I'm optimistic that these new completion designs can help offset some of the potential declines. 
Moving over to our Texas assets. I'm pleased with our integration efforts in 2015 and believe we're making good progress in optimizing the performance of these assets. During the fourth quarter, we started production on our first 5 Noble design completions in the Eagle Ford. And based on our review of public data, our first 3 design completions, which tested wider lateral spacing and higher profit concentrations, are among the most productive Eagle Ford wells ever completed.
We also announced 30-day results on 2 additional wells today. The average 30-day IP for these wells was over 4,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. And this is remarkable, when you look on the fact that they were drilled by Rosetta on tighter 500-foot lateral spacing. Production from these 2 wells when normalized to a 5,000-foot lateral is also significantly above our 3 million-barrel EUR type curve, which is based on wider lateral spacing.
Capital allocation for the Texas assets is approximately $250 million. 60% is expected to be spent in the Eagle Ford, primarily to continue Gates Ranch development. The remaining 40% will be spent to begin our operated appraisal work in the Delaware Basin. Our first 2 completions in the Delaware are beginning production this month. And while we have pulled back capital in these assets from prior expectations, I still expect higher volumes in 2016 versus 2015 pro forma, driven mostly by the Eagle Ford.
In the Marcellus, total capital for this year is currently planned at $150 million. We've reduced activity to 0 drilling rigs with plans for the JV to be cash flow neutral. Focus will be on a limited number on completions in the nonoperated dry gas area and will be weighted towards the first half of the year. As such, this is expected to deliver modestly higher volumes versus full year 2015.
The Gulf of Mexico finished the year strongly, with Big Bend and Dantzler starting production during the fourth quarter, ahead of schedule and on budget. Our Gulf of Mexico strategy of pursuing high-quality reservoirs near existing infrastructure generates substantial value. A full year of Big Bend and Dantzler, along with the Gunflint start-up, will contribute significant year-on-year oil volume growth during the coming year.
Noble's Gulf of Mexico budget is $250 million for 2016. As we complete the Gunflint project, the vast majority of capital will be for exploration and appraisal activities. The lineup includes the Silvergate prospect, which is currently drilling, an appraisal well for our 2014 Katmai oil discovery. Silvergate is a Miocene target with a resource range between 30 and 100 million barrels of oil equivalent gross, with nearby subsea tieback potential, and results are expected by the end of the first quarter.
In Israel, natural gas sales volumes averaged to 250 million cubic feet of gas equivalent per day during the fourth quarter. This represents an increase of 9% from the same period last year, mainly due to robust power generation demand. Strong natural gas demand is continuing into 2016, not only from this year's early cold weather, but also from the expanded use of natural gas over other power generation source fuels. In 2016, we have included approximately $100 million for pre-FID capital expenditures on our Eastern Mediterranean projects. The region is fundamentally short gas and we'll focus this year on finalizing gas sales agreements within Israel and with multiple regional customers.
As we progress the technical and commercial readiness of our projects, we are operating with the following principles: First and foremost, ensure that our development concepts match market demand; second, we remain focused on meeting and growing demand for natural gas within Israel, while diversifying our regional market opportunities; and third, we are managing project risk through financing, including the potential involvement of international financial institutions. 
I'd now like to take a couple of minutes and provide an update on our current thinking about the Leviathan development. Along with our FPSO development concept, we are also progressing another design that utilizes a fixed platform to ensure timely first production. The initial development under this fixed platform concept would be anchored by Israeli domestic demand, Jordan power needs and Egyptian industrial demand. While continuing to refine the technical requirements, initial capacity can start at over 1 BCF, billion cubic feet, of gas per day, and is quickly expendable to more than 2 BCF a day. This option provides the most flexibility to match contracted volumes with accelerated development, while retaining the capability to meet existing and growing demand.
As you would expect, preproduction capital outlays can be substantially reduced by this design modification, along with the current service cost environment. This will all be firmed up as we move through 2016 securing necessary gas contracts, recosting the final technical project and finalizing project financing to move forward to FID. Additionally, we continue to work with LNG plant owners in the region to secure gas contracts. The combination of our high-quality Eastern Mediterranean reservoirs with the idle LNG plants positions us well to be competitive in the global LNG world. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Dave for closing remarks.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. We've highlighted this morning how we executed exceptionally well during 2015. We did what we said we would do and then some. We know these are no ordinary times, but Noble is no ordinary company. We've outlined the 2016 program today that e
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. We've highlighted this morning how we executed exceptionally well during 2015. We did what we said we would do and then some. We know these are no ordinary times, but Noble is no ordinary company. We've outlined the 2016 program today that ensures we maintain financial strength and operating capabilities. It provides flexibility to adapt in any environment and positions Noble Energy to build long-term value. We believe the prudent approach is to manage the business within total cash flow, while keeping our eyes focused on the long term. How can we say this? Because our diverse portfolio and capabilities have us uniquely positioned to differentially outperform in 2016 and beyond. 
At this time, Debbie, we'll go ahead and open the call to questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first caller, Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first caller, Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, first I wanted to ask you, Noble has a lot of strong operating momentum in '16 with the Gulf of Mexico, Wattenberg and the flush [ph] Eagle Ford completions. I wanted to see if you could perhaps give us your thoughts, I know it's early, but sustaini
componenttext: Dave, first I wanted to ask you, Noble has a lot of strong operating momentum in '16 with the Gulf of Mexico, Wattenberg and the flush [ph] Eagle Ford completions. I wanted to see if you could perhaps give us your thoughts, I know it's early, but sustaining that operating momentum as you think about 2017?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Arun, yes, I appreciate the comments, and highlighting the momentum that Gary and his team and actually the whole organization has put in place and realized as we've gone through '15 and what we're seeing already moving into '16. As you look beyond '16 an
componenttext: Arun, yes, I appreciate the comments, and highlighting the momentum that Gary and his team and actually the whole organization has put in place and realized as we've gone through '15 and what we're seeing already moving into '16. As you look beyond '16 and to 2017, you have to look at the pieces of the portfolio and kind of just think through each one of those and how they are impacted. The Eastern Med, for example, it's going to be flat to up depending on demand. In the Gulf of Mexico, we should see some improvement in '17 versus '16 because you're bringing Isabela back on. We've got Isabela work over here in the first quarter impacting '16. We'll bring that back on, so you'll have impact of Isabela, and then you'll have a full year of Gunflint in '17. West Africa, you'll have the full year of Alba, which has been impacted this year and '16 by the downtime on the compression project, and that should offset decline on Aseng and Alen. So West Africa should be flat to potentially up. So the international offshore portfolio give you good sustenance, if you will, underlying the production basin. Then in the U.S, I would assume the Texas properties will continue to grow in '17. And then at the current type investment levels, you could see some declines in the Marcellus and the DJ. But when you think about '17 overall, the way I think about it, at kind of a 2016 spending level, you'd probably remain fairly flat. But I think a lot of work and a lot of time is going to go by on looking at where we want to set up the 2017 program before we go too far down the road as to what we'd actually be spending.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful as we think about 2017. My follow-up or second question really regards the Delaware Basin. It looks like you guys will be turning in the sales of about 10 wells. I don't know, Gary, could you give us a little bit of more details around
componenttext: That's very helpful as we think about 2017. My follow-up or second question really regards the Delaware Basin. It looks like you guys will be turning in the sales of about 10 wells. I don't know, Gary, could you give us a little bit of more details around where the completion activity is focused and a little bit about expectations for those wells? And in addition, maybe discuss some offset wells that you've seen in the area?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say those wells are spread throughout kind of the core part of the acreage that we're focused on. This year remains a bit more of appraisal delineation well as we bring some of our own completion techniques to the basin. So we're just now bringin
componenttext: Yes, I'd say those wells are spread throughout kind of the core part of the acreage that we're focused on. This year remains a bit more of appraisal delineation well as we bring some of our own completion techniques to the basin. So we're just now bringing our first 2 completions on this month. With those, we're trying 2 different completion techniques. One is a hybrid gel frac that's been more typically used in the area, also our first slickwater completion in the area. So we'll see how those perform. We'll continue to test some other things this year. I would expect performance relative to historical performance to be up similar to what we've seen as we've brought new completion techniques to the Eagle Ford, and similar to our history in the Marcellus and the DJ over the years as we continue to refine things. So still a bit early this year to see what we've got, just bringing the first 2 wells on, but excited to get to those on and see how we continue to progress the development of that acreage.

I mean, how do you think about priorities, kind of growths or balance sheet into 2017? And more specifically, what oil price would you expect to need to figuring out a re-acceleration process?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the priorities, assuming you're in the same price environment or the same as this year, which is managing that balance sheet, and also keeping an eye on the both the near and long-term capabilities that you're continuing to build. I think, as we l
componenttext: I think the priorities, assuming you're in the same price environment or the same as this year, which is managing that balance sheet, and also keeping an eye on the both the near and long-term capabilities that you're continuing to build. I think, as we looked at this year, we built the budget from -- the capital budget from ground up. We looked at what commitments and requirements we had, and then how much discretionary capital and where would we put the first tranche of the discretionary capital. I mean, that's kind of been in the Texas and DJ Basin right now. And then you're watching your cash flow, and you're watching where that comes together. So I think, for this environment, we're going to continue to position ourselves to manage within cash flow. And I think, we have the portfolio that allows us to do that and still maintain a strong underlying foundation.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we are still focused, as we always have been, on delivering a quality product and a quality project first. Really, in the course of 2016, that's kind of got, as Dave said, sort of 4 key areas that we're working on. We made a lot of progress in 201
componenttext: Yes, so we are still focused, as we always have been, on delivering a quality product and a quality project first. Really, in the course of 2016, that's kind of got, as Dave said, sort of 4 key areas that we're working on. We made a lot of progress in 2015 on the regulatory framework and that's resolved. Now we're focused in on the technical work, revising and optimizing the development scenario. As you've heard, looking at concluding our gas marketing contracts and of course getting our project financing lined up. And our view is that we can be in a place to have that all finished up by the end of 2016.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we've already seen some of the monetization take place here in the first quarter with a couple hundred million from Tanin and Karish, and what we've talked about on selling down some interest in Cyprus. I mean, we know we've got some unique
componenttext: Well, I think, we've already seen some of the monetization take place here in the first quarter with a couple hundred million from Tanin and Karish, and what we've talked about on selling down some interest in Cyprus. I mean, we know we've got some unique assets in the Eastern Med. For example, we know as part of the framework that we're going to sell down some Tamar interest over time. Again, we've got a period of -- significant period of time, 6 years, to do that. But it does give you an opportunity as that value is realized, whether it's Tamar or whether it's some interest in Leviathan, to have some assets that are positioned a little differently than some of the rest of the world out there. I think the other thing we've talked about, and it's still on the shelf, if you will, is just continuing to unlock value in the midstream part of our business. So I think that's another unique high-value asset piece that can help in that whole portfolio mix over some period.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: Yes, let me ask can Ken to kind of highlight that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave. We, like many people with offshore earnings and an APB 23 assertion on that said that we would continue to reinvest our foreign earnings internationally and not bring them back to the U.S. at that point of time, as we looked at it in '15, at th
componenttext: Yes, Dave. We, like many people with offshore earnings and an APB 23 assertion on that said that we would continue to reinvest our foreign earnings internationally and not bring them back to the U.S. at that point of time, as we looked at it in '15, at the end of the year, we removed that assertion and we -- that allowed us to utilize the foreign tax credits very effectively. And so what that means is we have then full fungibility of about a couple billion dollars of additional monies that could be repatriated through time to the U.S. So it adds a lot to our flexibility. And it was, in a sense, a good time because we could utilize the foreign tax credits efficiently.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, David, it's consistent with the number of things we've been doing to make sure we provide ourselves the most flexibility as we can.
componenttext: I think, David, it's consistent with the number of things we've been doing to make sure we provide ourselves the most flexibility as we can.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

componenttext: I appreciate that. I assume it also makes maybe forward guidance on international tax a little bit easier for all of us. Is that a fair statement?

componenttext: Yes, I think that's true, because you'll see then that it'll effectively be more the statutory rate. So it should make Brad's life a little easier.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
