headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Levi. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we issued our first quarter 2016 operational and financial news release and we also posted a number of supplemental slides to our website. You will find them helpful
componenttext:
Thanks, Levi. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. 
This morning, we issued our first quarter 2016 operational and financial news release and we also posted a number of supplemental slides to our website. You will find them helpful as we talk through our prepared comments.  Later this morning, our 10-Q will be filed with the SEC. 
Following prepared comments from Dave Stover, Chairman, President and CEO; and Gary Willingham, EVP of Operations, we'll open the call for Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] Additional management members available for Q&A are Ken Fisher, EVP and CFO; Susan Cunningham, EVP, Exploration and New Ventures; and Keith Elliott, SVP of our Eastern Mediterranean business. 
I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call may contain projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
With that, I'll turn the call to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. If you've had a chance to look at our earnings release and conference call slides this morning, I think you'll agree that we had a tremendous operating quarter and a very solid start to 2016. We began the year w
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. 
If you've had a chance to look at our earnings release and conference call slides this morning, I think you'll agree that we had a tremendous operating quarter and a very solid start to 2016. We began the year with these key goals: Protect the balance sheet; align cash outflows with cash inflows; leverage the benefits of our diversified portfolio; and optimize returns with enhanced completion. First quarter results show we are delivering on each of these objectives. 
Before going into our results, I'd like to take a moment to discuss the current environment. With the U.S. rig count at a record low, significantly lower investment is translating into production declines in the majority of unconventional basins. It is my hope that we will continue to see capital discipline throughout the industry regarding activity levels. Even if we see sustained higher commodity prices, any meaningful U.S. production impact from increased industry activity is likely to take several months from initial investment decisions. 
Outside North America, non-OPEC major project deferrals are beginning to add up to at least a few million barrels per day through 2020. While there have been early indications of a potential commodity price turn, I expect commodities will continue to show volatility day-to-day and week-to-week. Regardless, no matter what commodity environment persist, it is clear to me Noble Energy is well positioned to sustain and create long-term value for its shareholders. 
Moving to our results. We continue to lower both our capital and underlying cost structure in the first quarter. This was primarily the result of impressive and sustainable and efficiency gains in our U.S. onshore business. Capital expenditures were below the low end of our guidance, and decreased for a sixth consecutive quarter as we manage within cash flow. We came in well below guidance on most of our key cost metrics. Total lease operating expense and general administrative cost in the first quarter of 2016, which included Rosetta, were flat in an absolute amount compared to a Noble in [indiscernible] of first quarter 2015. This is a powerful indication of our cost-reduction efforts when you consider the company added almost 100,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day over that same period. Excluding the [indiscernible] workover, unit lease operating expense was down 34% from the first quarter of last year. At the same time, we exceeded the high end of our volume guidance with 416,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day sold in the first quarter. This is up more than 30% in total and 8% pro forma for the Rosetta merger versus the same quarter last year. Compared to guidance, oil was higher, NGLs were higher, and so was gas. This was achieved by impressive productivity improvements in the U.S. with new completions, record first quarter sales volumes in Israel and reduced downtime at Alba and Equatorial Guinea. In fact, every core area is delivering or exceeding our plans so far in 2016. 
Executions stood out in the DJ Basin position where completion optimization and longer laterals drove 34% growth in Wells Ranch and East Pony production compared to the same quarter of last year. And in the Delaware Basin, where we're just getting started, third-party analysis of state data indicate Noble Energy has the highest productivity per lateral foot in the basin this year. 
Equally as important, we maintained our robust financial position, ending the quarter with $5 billion in liquidity. Since quarter end, we have executed asset sales transactions totaling nearly $550 million, including the transaction announced yesterday. Combined with first quarter proceeds received, we will have generated total proceeds of over $775 million so far in 2016. The Greeley Crescent [ph] transaction significantly accelerates the value of this acreage for Noble Energy. It is an area that would not have been developed for some time as we are currently focused on higher value areas within the DJ Basin. Gary will talk more about this shortly. 
Our continued focus on discipline capital allocation and prudent balance sheet management did not go unnoticed by the rating agencies. We not only maintained our investment grade ratings at Moody's and S&P, but received initial investment grade ratings from Fitch as well. Ken and the treasury team did a great job continuing engagement with the rating agencies, and I believe we are 1 of only 4 of our peers with investment grade ratings across the board. 
Our strong underlying performance, the recent upward move in commodity prices and announced proceeds from asset sales position us to generate significant excess cash in 2016 and give us more flexibility for the future. 
At current prices, we continue to be focused on balance sheet strength and the opportunity to pay down debt. As commodity prices moves and sustain above $50 per barrel, we will begin to consider additional capital allocation to the U.S. unconventional business, with initial focus on our low-cost and liquids-rich assets in the DJ Basin in Texas. 
We've continued the trend of improving our performance in the first quarter, and I'm confident there is much more to come. I will now turn the call over to Gary Willingham.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. As Dave mentioned, we continue with very high levels of operating momentum in the early part of the year, particularly in the U.S. onshore business. The level of engagement by our entire organization to continuous
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. As Dave mentioned, we continue with very high levels of operating momentum in the early part of the year, particularly in the U.S. onshore business. The level of engagement by our entire organization to continuously drive efficiencies throughout the business is certainly apparent, and realized drilling time reductions and enhanced productivity in all of our reasons. 
The DJ Basin, once again, delivered production outperformance at lower costs. First quarter production totaled 118,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. During the quarter, we reduced normalized extended-reach lateral well cost to $2.7 million in Wells Ranch, down 35% from the first quarter of 2015, despite utilizing higher profit concentrations. This decrease is a result of intense focus on drilling and completion execution and utilizing the best rigs and the best crudes in the basin. 
We continue to shift our well design to include more model board drilling, which provides many benefits, particularly for the combination of longer laterals and slickwater fracs. On the first 35 model board wells we drilled, we're observing reduced drill times of 1.5 to 2.5 days or 30%, the ability to eliminate gel and [indiscernible] in the long laterals, and finally, the model board also provides more options for future well innovations. 
Completion design continues to evolve rapidly, and it's paying off an impressive well productivity. You can see on Slide 5 the average IP-30 rate per lateral foot was up more than 30% from the same period a year ago, and the liquids content of the wells, which came online in 2016, is higher than in prior years. This productivity improvement reflects both the shift of slickwater fluids as well as enhanced profit loading. Both Noble Energy and third-party infrastructure have been performing well keeping line pressure low throughout the field. Our plant turnaround and our Wells Ranch processing facility was completed in April. This was part of routine maintenance and is the first as the facility start up 3 years ago. 
Yesterday, we announced the transaction to sell approximately 33,000 net acres from our Greeley Crescent area, which is located on the western side of our DJ acreage position. Representing about half of our acreage in Greeley Crescent, the transaction accelerates the value of Noble Energy from an area which was not in our development plan for many years. Our strategy is to focus on areas with higher oil content where we have more contiguous acres and drive efficiency gains through long lateral development and existing infrastructure. Greeley Crescent is [indiscernible] with very little production as horizontal drilling industry and the transaction highlights the strong value of undeveloped acreage in the DJ Basin. Total proceeds are expected to be $505 million. 
In Texas, we continue to deliver results that confirm our high quality positions in both the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin. Drilling times were down 20% from prior performance on these assets, and we announced several exciting well results this morning. Results from our first 2 Delaware completions in Reeves County were impressive. The average IP-30 rate of over 320 barrels of oil equivalent per 1,000 lateral feet is nearly 15% better than the prior average on these assets. 
I want to turn your attention to Slide 7, which provides more details. The first will validate our Tier 1 Wolfcamp A position across the eastern and western extent of the acreage. The Calamity Jane well is performing significantly above Noble's 700,000 type curve, with oil production in line and gas showing material outperformance. We're also pleased to see our western extension test, the Soapy Smith well, performing consistent with the Tier 1 type curve. These outstanding results right out of the gate demonstrate the transferability of our U.S. onshore completion expertise, and we'll continue to delineate the acreage position while further optimizing completions this year. 
In the Eagle Ford, we're seeing early success bringing our improved completion designs from South Gates Ranch to new areas, unlocking additional resource potential. As Slide 8 indicates, the 2 Briscoe Ranch well fall under in the quarter are materially outperforming the 400,000-barrel type curves you can see on the chart. In fact, they're actually outperforming even 1 million-barrel type curve. These wells are an average lateral length of 4,900 feet and were completed with 2,000 pounds of profit per lateral foot. The better performing well is designed with tighter cluster spacing. In March, we brought 6 online 6 Gates Ranch wells which tested various spacing and completion concepts. We're just now seeing production post cleanup, and these wells will drive significant volume growth in Texas during the second quarter. 
In the Marcellus, exceptional operating performance continues to ensure deliverability of base production. We remain well aligned with our partner to be cash flow neutral in the joint venture in 2016 and we'll continue to be flexible with completion activity for the remainder of the year. 
We started the year strongly in the Gulf of Mexico, with Big Bend and Dantzler contributing 19,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net to Noble Energy during the quarter. This drove Gulf of Mexico oil volumes up almost 100% in the first quarter compared to the prior year. In addition, the Isabella workover was completed ahead of schedule, and Gunflint continues to progress toward the mid-year 2016 start-up. 
We recently commenced drilling in appraisal well at Katmai. This well will test resource upside to the 40 million to 60 million barrels of oil equivalent already discovered. And we anticipate results early in the fourth quarter. 
Sales volumes in West Africa averaged 65,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Strong underlying performance at [indiscernible] continued during the quarter. And in Alba, installation of the new D3 compression platform was carried out with fewer downtime days than expected. Commissioning and start-up of the compression platform, which will enhance full field recovery remains on schedule for mid-year. 
In Israel, natural gas sales volumes averaged to 266 million cubic feet of gas per day. This represents an increase of nearly 10% from the same period last year despite mild weather experienced thus far in 2016. With the Israeli government's mandate to reduce coal-fired generation by 15% year-over-year, we've seen consistent incremental coal-to-gas switching on the order of 50 million cubic feet per day gross with potential upside to that number. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Before providing details on our adjusted guidance, I'd like to take a moment to provide a further update on our Israel projects. Tamar's production growth, resilient cash flows and access to significantly undersupplied markets make it one of
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. Before providing details on our adjusted guidance, I'd like to take a moment to provide a further update on our Israel projects. Tamar's production growth, resilient cash flows and access to significantly undersupplied markets make it one of the most attractive assets in the world. Leviathan is the same quality asset, on an even larger scale with a total recoverable resource of 22 trillion cubic feet of gas based on multiple appraisal wells drilled and a production test as well. 
In late March, Israel's Supreme Court acknowledged the strategic and national importance of these discoveries by upholding all but one of the provisions of the natural gas framework. The court recognized the important of stabilization but rejected the specific provision in the framework. We are engaged with the government as it works to timely address the Supreme Court's concern. 
In the meantime, we continue to progress the other 3 critical requirements for Leviathan sanction: Financing, marketing and technical readiness. We are pleased that the Israeli National Planning Committee recently approved the location of the Leviathan platform and pipeline connection in northern Israel. I am convinced that the Leviathan, along with Tamar, will supply much-needed gas for both Israel and the neighboring region for decades. 
We've provided a full update to our 2016 guidance on Slide 11. Normally, I wouldn't change our outlooks so early in the year, but this reflects the high level of confidence I have in our strategy, assets, execution and ultimately, our future. 
Full year sales are now expected to average 405,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 4% from original guidance, with increased expectations for all 3 commodities. The production raise is based primarily on outperformance in the DJ Basin, Israel and West Africa. 
And on the capital side, we are trending on a path to come in under $1.5 billion. 
For the second quarter, capital is affected to be in line with the first quarter. Sales volumes are anticipated to range between 405,000 and 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Volumes are expected to be impacted by seasonality in Israel and facility turnaround in the DJ Basin. This will be partially offset by significant quarter-over-quarter growth in Texas. We also expect higher volumes in West Africa as a result of Alba field production returning to full rate. 
In summary, I continue to be pleased with the capital efficiencies generated across the business. Our financial strengths, asset quality and onshore and offshore expertise give us a unique competitive advantage in any commodity environment. 
At this time, Levi, why don't we go ahead and open the call to questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: How should we think about asset sale targets for the year? Is there a program? And what is the use of proceeds? Did they bolster the balance sheet or improved your ability to reaccelerate?
componenttext: How should we think about asset sale targets for the year? Is there a program? And what is the use of proceeds? Did they bolster the balance sheet or improved your ability to reaccelerate?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as potential sales, I think this was an opportunity where we saw that it could create more value for somebody else, and essentially create more value for us by monetizing the asset. It was something in our plans we weren't going to be developi
componenttext: Yes, as far as potential sales, I think this was an opportunity where we saw that it could create more value for somebody else, and essentially create more value for us by monetizing the asset. It was something in our plans we weren't going to be developing for a while given where it meets in the past portfolio, so it made sense to move forward. I'd say when we look at things in general, and if it goes back to kind of what our philosophy has been as we always look at all parts of our portfolio. More value at somebody else, then we're going to do that. If there's some reason that it can -- we can realize more value from it by moving it to somebody else's hand, we'll look at that. I think as we look at the year and what we've talked about previously, the one place were Noble continue to look at potential monetization of a portion of our business is over in Israel with Tamar, for example. We've talked about this as part of the framework that in over 6 years, we look to bring down our interest from 36% to 25%. I'd say in the current environment, there's still a lot of interest and other folks wanting to get into that field. So there could be a possibility. We might bring down some of our interest this year, but it's too early to say. So I would say that the main one we're continuing to stay focus on. Outside of that, we still have a big midstream business that we kept that one active. And at some point in time, I think we'll see some real value, additional value come out of that part of the business. That's kind of how I think about that portfolio. Most of it's all cord, up, we don't have a lot of fringe pieces. But as in the case of this opportunity, if it makes sense to accelerate value, we'll look at it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My second question is similar. Your CapEx is trending well below in 1Q, and you gave a guide, it was modestly lower. Last year, many cycle saving in higher activity, are you considering recycling lower CapEx into more activity? Or is this just in conjunct
componenttext: My second question is similar. Your CapEx is trending well below in 1Q, and you gave a guide, it was modestly lower. Last year, many cycle saving in higher activity, are you considering recycling lower CapEx into more activity? Or is this just in conjunction with asset sales continuing to improve the balance sheet?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in this environment and too early to see a sustained different price outlook at this point. Our -- I mentioned in the prepared comments, our initial focus, our primary focus is maintaining the strength of balance sheet. So it gives us more f
componenttext: Well, I think in this environment and too early to see a sustained different price outlook at this point. Our -- I mentioned in the prepared comments, our initial focus, our primary focus is maintaining the strength of balance sheet. So it gives us more flexibility and more opportunity there. I think as we see, and we'll see how it progresses through the year, as we start to see more of a sustainable higher price environment, then we'll look at activity levels later in the year. But at this point, assuming we keep the same price outlook that we have right now, first priority is probably to continue to maintain the balance sheet. But I'd say, one of the things we've done with the way we've looked at organization and how we manage the business, we've maintained the capability to probably adjust relatively quickly as conditions change. So this just gives us more flexibility and optionality to do that over time.

componenttext: Yes, I'll let Gary dive into that one. But I'd say, I share your enthusiasm for the results, especially when you look at the fact that we tested 2 wells on -- one in the far eastern side, one on the far western side of our contiguous acres, but let me turn that over to Gary.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Charles I'd say that length of the laterals is definitely tied more towards to lease issues at the time they were drilled more than an indication of plans going forward. The Soapy Smith, certainly the well on the west side, is less than 2,800-foot lateral. That was actually drilled by Rosetta prior to the transaction. And it drilled to hold that particular lease. So I think as we continue to satisfy the remaining lease obligations in the area and move into more of a development phase going on, you'll see longer and longer laterals in those areas.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks for that, Gary. And then my second question, I suppose on the CapEx or use of proceeds of this Greeley Crescent sale. Your new guidance is for less than 1.5, but I think that's probably nonspecific by design. And I wonder if you could give u
componenttext: Great, thanks for that, Gary. And then my second question, I suppose on the CapEx or use of proceeds of this Greeley Crescent sale. Your new guidance is for less than 1.5, but I think that's probably nonspecific by design. And I wonder if you could give us a sense for what the moving pieces are that would get you under 1.5 or if that's just simply a reflection of you coming in under -- in the first quarter? And if that 500 million is just going to kind of sit on the balance sheet, or be there for the case where it all goes back over 50 or perhaps it's used to [indiscernible]?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Charles, I think when you look at it, I'll go back to my comment that I usually don't like to change guidance this early in the year. But I think it's pretty obvious from the way our capital efficiency played out in the first quarter, that continued i
componenttext: No, Charles, I think when you look at it, I'll go back to my comment that I usually don't like to change guidance this early in the year. But I think it's pretty obvious from the way our capital efficiency played out in the first quarter, that continued improvements we're seeing, especially in our onshore programs, on what we're spending versus what we're getting, that we needed to indicate at least directionally where this was going to come. I think as far as by design, we haven't given specific number because we're keeping the flexibility as things changed through the year. All I'd say is on the planned activity, we're definitely on trend when you look at it to come in under the 1.5 billion, and we'll see how the year plays out as far as, to your point, we brought in some other proceeds. We're well positioned when it make sense to increase activity. But we're not going to do that until we're comfortable we got a sustainable environment to support it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One consistent theme that we have heard through earnings season is that $50 barrel fulcrum point for potentially more activity. What do you forecast or what do you think the industry should forecast for increasing services costs in an accelerating environ
componenttext: One consistent theme that we have heard through earnings season is that $50 barrel fulcrum point for potentially more activity. What do you forecast or what do you think the industry should forecast for increasing services costs in an accelerating environment?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, Dave. I think, obviously, you would expect it -- it's going to be driven by activity and it's also going to be driven by the ability of the service sector to get people back to work. So one of the things we tried to do this me this r
componenttext: It's a good question, Dave. I think, obviously, you would expect it -- it's going to be driven by activity and it's also going to be driven by the ability of the service sector to get people back to work. So one of the things we tried to do this me this relationship, especially in the key basins so that we're on the priority list for returning to work, if you will. I don't have a real strong sense as to what the magic price. I think it's going to be more what the magic amount of activity as far as to put more pressure on the service sector or the supply of available resources. And then we'll just have to say a place from there. I think the one thing that's been encouraging from some of this, as we really focused on some of the efficiencies, and you've seen this from a number of folks, the other piece of that is that there's still a large piece of this that we're seeing, probably 50% or more, of our onshore cost reduction that we think at least sustainable on a much higher priced environment. Just from the way we've changed the way we do our business. Then when you look at the other part going forward, and here's where the diversified portfolio plays in, I think there's still a lot of room for offshore project, especially new project cost that come down and stay down for a while, and not respond real quickly to any change.

componenttext: Quick question, David. I appreciate all the comments on capital flexibility. Can you remind us as we want to think forward to 6 to 12 months from now and even into '17, how do you think about your flexibility on capital? So can you just remind us what you think maintenance capital is for U.S. onshore business in this environment? And maybe any major project obligations you think you have, either Gulf of Mexico, West Africa or internationally again acknowledging that, that's all dependent on project sanction? How do you think about the flexibility around the programs in '17?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have tremendous flexibility in '17, probably even more so than we had going into '16. I think the only places that were looking at as far as committed capital, if you will, and you start from a bottoms up, we have probably about a half year wit
componenttext: I think we have tremendous flexibility in '17, probably even more so than we had going into '16. I think the only places that were looking at as far as committed capital, if you will, and you start from a bottoms up, we have probably about a half year with our rig in the Gulf of Mexico, and we have a few leases in the Texas properties that we want to drill to maintain your acreage position. But outside of that, we've got pretty much complete flexibility. So I think we've got a lot of room to make decisions based on whatever the environment turns out to be. I think as far as the maintenance fees, we kind of talked about that last time, and I don't think our view on that has changed any.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. And maybe on Israel, one thing that would be interesting is, what are your current thoughts on potential expansion of Tamar? I appreciate the comments on potential monetization of that 11% working interest. But how do you think about th
componenttext: I appreciate that. And maybe on Israel, one thing that would be interesting is, what are your current thoughts on potential expansion of Tamar? I appreciate the comments on potential monetization of that 11% working interest. But how do you think about the potential expansion projects and some of the things we've discussed in the past? And where they sit in the priority queue, particularly relative to Leviathan?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I think a lot of the discussions has been, and what you'll see moves on, is obviously getting the second big source of supply online. So that's been a lot of what the news focus has been on Leviathan. But if you step back and look at what's hap
componenttext: Yes, well, I think a lot of the discussions has been, and what you'll see moves on, is obviously getting the second big source of supply online. So that's been a lot of what the news focus has been on Leviathan. But if you step back and look at what's happening with Tamar, and I mentioned it or Gary and I both mentioned it, that you're seeing more of this push to move more of the power generation from coal to gas. We actually saw that show up in the first quarter. I think we're still being cautious about what we'll see for the rest of the year, but that's a near-term positive impact for Tamar. You still have the drive and the push from customers in Egypt to get gas, interruptible gas, as soon as that can be worked out. So I think when you look at both near and in longer-term market viability for both of those projects, it's pretty exciting place to have that quality of opportunity when you think about the combination of the reservoir characteristics and the access to market over there for both of those Tamar and Leviathan.

componenttext: I wanted to see if you could guys could discuss the potential implications from an inventory perspective of some of the results that you shared at Briscoe Ranch?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me turn that over to Gary.
componenttext: Okay, let me turn that over to Gary.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun. I think the exciting thing about the results we're seeing at Briscoe is we've taken an area and significantly improved it by taking learnings from South Gates Ranch to a new area in Eagle Ford. Of course, a lot of the success that we've had in
componenttext: Yes, Arun. I think the exciting thing about the results we're seeing at Briscoe is we've taken an area and significantly improved it by taking learnings from South Gates Ranch to a new area in Eagle Ford. Of course, a lot of the success that we've had in South Gates Ranch improvement, and you're seeing it in the Delaware now too, comes from our prior experience in the Marcellus and the DJ. And collectively, as a company, we've completed over 1,600 horizontal wells now. So we got a lot of learnings under our belt. I think specifically for that acreage and the inventory and the running room, Briscoe Ranch is a fairly small course of the acreage, it's less than 5,000 acres, I think. But the exciting thing there's other acreage nearby, which we think a lot of those same improvements and completion designs can be applied to, and we could see perhaps similar uplift to the results on those wells. So even though that block of acreage is not huge, it certainly applies elsewhere. We continue to have quite a bit of inventory still in South Gates Ranch, North Gates Ranch, and then obviously in the Delaware, we're just getting started the first 2 wells.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I think Gary, you just talked about 165 locations at Gates Ranch, and 475 elsewhere with Eagle Ford. So you think that perhaps some of the enhanced completions could maybe improve the well productivity on the balance outside of Gates Ranch?
componenttext: Great. I think Gary, you just talked about 165 locations at Gates Ranch, and 475 elsewhere with Eagle Ford. So you think that perhaps some of the enhanced completions could maybe improve the well productivity on the balance outside of Gates Ranch?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I think the results that we've seen, and again, it goes back to what we've done in the DJ and the Marcellus, now the Eagle Ford and the Permian where we continue to see improvement in results as we get to refine completion techniques. I think
componenttext: Absolutely. I think the results that we've seen, and again, it goes back to what we've done in the DJ and the Marcellus, now the Eagle Ford and the Permian where we continue to see improvement in results as we get to refine completion techniques. I think what you're seeing now, it certainly bodes well for the potential of the future completions in those areas. I think the numbers you're citing there are still based on wider spacing too. So the extent that we continue to get better at confining the fracking and stimulating more of the near wellbore rock, that potentially opens up tighter spacing over time too, which would only add to the inventory count.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my follow-up is on the DJ. You talked about 30% kind of per lateral foot productivity gains. What would also surprised me was just the oil mix in the new wells. So I was just wondering if you could maybe just talk to us why you think the oil mi
componenttext: Great. And my follow-up is on the DJ. You talked about 30% kind of per lateral foot productivity gains. What would also surprised me was just the oil mix in the new wells. So I was just wondering if you could maybe just talk to us why you think the oil mix was higher? Was it related to mix? I know that the East Pony was a little bit oiler, but could you maybe just talk to that because that is a pretty significant delta in terms of -- versus the historical mix in the DJ.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the numbers on that slide are obviously over a 3-year period. So it just goes to show why over the last couple of years, we've really been talking a lot about refocusing activity in the best of the best, which is the higher oil content areas,
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the numbers on that slide are obviously over a 3-year period. So it just goes to show why over the last couple of years, we've really been talking a lot about refocusing activity in the best of the best, which is the higher oil content areas, Wells Ranch and East Pony. East Pony is, by far, the highest oil percentage acreage that we have in our portfolio, and that's were a large number of the wells that we're bringing on early part of this year were from. So that's probably driving that percentage up.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: I think certainly by year-end, we'll probably start talking about new [indiscernible] and new type curves. I think we're not done testing new ideas. We've only recently really ramped up the sand concentration in some of these wells, and we've only done it on few so far. So we like to get a few more of those under our belts and see some extended production history of some of these wells before we update the numbers. But, clearly, from what we're seeing an early time data, the results we're very encouraging versus what we talked about the past.

componenttext: No, I think when you're looking at any other factors like other things, I think for us, the biggest reason we've sold that acreage was we felt somebody else could create more value out of the accelerating than we were going to create over time. And actually increase our value because what we're focusing on and what we will be for a while here is where we have infrastructure in place where we can drill longer laterals and where have a higher oil content. I mean those are the reasons we made that transaction.

componenttext: Real quickly. One of the comments on acceleration of activity, can you guys just give us a little bit of color in terms of after making personnel adjustments, what kind of a rig ramp you could prosecute or some respect, I guess, would be offset by the efficiencies you've seen as well, but maybe kind of a max rig count that the current staff could handle?

componenttext: Yes, I'll turn that over to Gary for some color, but that's one of the things we took into consideration as we looked at any adjustments in our organization was to make sure we have the flexibility to go up or down within a reasonable range. componenttext: Dave, that's true. We did retain a decent amount of flexibility in our ability to ramp up activity when prices recover. So we're just running the 2 rigs and the DJ and right now. We've got the capacity to handle a bit more activity there than 2 rigs when time is right. I think when you look at Texas, we're running off and on 1 rig total between the 2 areas, and we can certainly increase that activity a bit within the constraints of the current organization. So I think, for any reasonable amount of activity increase that you would expect to see over the near term, we're fine.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate that. And then just looking at kind of the decline in well cost in the DJ Basin. Obviously, completions have become more intense, and I'm just trying to understand that the biggest driver in that is? I mean, we understand efficiency gai
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate that. And then just looking at kind of the decline in well cost in the DJ Basin. Obviously, completions have become more intense, and I'm just trying to understand that the biggest driver in that is? I mean, we understand efficiency gains. But is there something you're doing differently that's allowing you to reduce the cost dramatically as you were able to show this quarter?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's a lot of things. It's not one thing that's driving it. I mean, you certainly see it in the continuing improvement in the drilling performance where we continue to set records on a fairly consistent basis, taking a little bit of time off
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's a lot of things. It's not one thing that's driving it. I mean, you certainly see it in the continuing improvement in the drilling performance where we continue to set records on a fairly consistent basis, taking a little bit of time off here and there as our previous records on drilling times. Slickwater is certainly have been a driver of it as well, moving to monobore drilling helps by taking a day, sometimes more than that off so the wells as well. So and then in Wells Ranch and East Pony where we've got existing infrastructure and the ability to drill those long laterals, which can drive your average cost per foot down as well, will certainly no doubt that we have some things that are offsetting that was removing the higher and higher sand concentrations and testing some tighter spacing in some areas. But the good news is we been able to deliver an up efficiencies and all the other areas to more than offset that and continue to drive cost down. As I mentioned in the press release, were down to $2.7 million in Wells Ranch on our extended reach well, adjusted back to a normal lateral link. And that's with some of the impact of the higher completion cost from the higher sand loading. If you go back to more of a traditional type completion design that we might have had in the past, those costs are down more to the $2.4 million range. So great job by the teams and continuing to execute and look for efficiencies.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just one follow-up. Is any of that cost-saving associated with using existing pads or would there be step shift change as you go to that over time?
componenttext: Maybe just one follow-up. Is any of that cost-saving associated with using existing pads or would there be step shift change as you go to that over time?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say very little, if any, of it is probably associated with the DJ. We don't have a lot of activity in the DJ where we go back to an existing pads and drill more wells given the type of acreage we got there, being HBP and the ability to plan that aroun
componenttext: I'd say very little, if any, of it is probably associated with the DJ. We don't have a lot of activity in the DJ where we go back to an existing pads and drill more wells given the type of acreage we got there, being HBP and the ability to plan that around infrastructure development plan, we generally go in and build the pad and drill it out from the beginning. So there might be some savings of a that type come up in the Permian later on as we go back and move to the development mode there, but I wouldn't expect a lot of that in the DJ.

componenttext: This is perhaps a follow on to an earlier question. But just wondering, given the work being done in Israel to address the Supreme Court's concern about the framework stability language, do you think you still need to spend the full $100 million compared that you budgeted?

componenttext: Well, I think we continue to look at that. I mean, our position has been, we're not going to spend significant money until we're comfortable. We have the predictable revenues environment that gives us the assurance for the project. And that's we've been very consistent on that message. So what you have in there is still some money that ties to some pre-FID spend this year probably depends on how quickly they define their solutions.

Just thinking mainly about kind of any updated views you have on Israel gas demand and West Africa downtime, in particular.

componenttext: Well, we are in the first quarter obviously, and the read through on that is that we added some for Israel expectation with this mandate now for pushing more from coal to gas. Could there be some more? I hope so. But we'll wait to see. As Keith highlighted on it, average basis for the full year, we have ability to absorb some more upside if they continue to push more of their power generation to gas. But we've built in some of that.

componenttext: Wanted to follow up on a couple of earlier questions. First, on the Delaware basin well that you highlighted on Slide 7, both had strong rates versus your type curve. If you look at relative performance of each, the Calamity Jane outperformed on a lateral length basis, adjusted basis, seemingly, a lot more from gas and NGLs relative to oil. And I wondered if you could talk about the geology as it moves from east to west within your acreage block, and if we should expect differentiation in well productivity and in production mix?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think on the Calamity Jane, the gas percentage, what we see from our mapping is, as you move probably further north and east of the Calamity Jane location, we think it does give a little gas here, and we think we've tapped into some of that with th
componenttext: Yes. I think on the Calamity Jane, the gas percentage, what we see from our mapping is, as you move probably further north and east of the Calamity Jane location, we think it does give a little gas here, and we think we've tapped into some of that with this well. I think as you move it back to the west, we're, by far, the majority of our acreages, we would expect to see the higher oil gas more in line with what we're seeing [indiscernible].

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And should the decline profile look similar on both wells or is there any other differentiation that you see?
componenttext: Got it. And should the decline profile look similar on both wells or is there any other differentiation that you see?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we considered all Tier 1 acreage, but even within Tier 1, there's obviously some acreages that's better than others. And I think generally speaking, we see the eastern half of the acreage, Tier 1 acreage slightly higher quality, I think you
componenttext: Well, I think, we considered all Tier 1 acreage, but even within Tier 1, there's obviously some acreages that's better than others. And I think generally speaking, we see the eastern half of the acreage, Tier 1 acreage slightly higher quality, I think you see that in the performance of the wells. Most of the activity that we have planned for the rest of the year is in either the central or eastern half of the acreage block, so we'll continue to test that area as we go. I think the interesting thing about the Soapy Smith is even though it's outperforming the type curve, not as much as the Calamity Jane is, but that's outperforming the type curve, it's significantly outperforming, I think, some of historical wells in that area by as much as 20% or 30%. And so that's the well we did the slickwater test on. It's really the only well that we've done a slickwater test on in that area. I thin that potentially could create some excitement going forward as we test more slickwater in the Delaware Basin and see  how much uplift we can get from that versus the historical hybrids.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And then going back to the asset sale, you got a couple of questions here. You thinking about using proceeds towards debt paydown, balance sheet improvement and recommitting capital to drilling. But wondered on the M&A front, how you're thinking a
componenttext: Thanks. And then going back to the asset sale, you got a couple of questions here. You thinking about using proceeds towards debt paydown, balance sheet improvement and recommitting capital to drilling. But wondered on the M&A front, how you're thinking about -- and what ability there may be to further add to your Permian and Eagle Ford positions and whether the asset sales open up to flex with the in your mind to do so?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it just gives us more firepower, if you will, Brian, for that type of thing. And there's no doubt we'll continue to look at opportunities in those areas, especially around the Delaware and so forth. And obviously, a number of others are doing the sa
componenttext: Well, it just gives us more firepower, if you will, Brian, for that type of thing. And there's no doubt we'll continue to look at opportunities in those areas, especially around the Delaware and so forth. And obviously, a number of others are doing the same thing. So it has to be the right opportunity, the right situation, and it's going to be based off the asset and inventory quality that we will be looking at. But we'll continue to look. This doesn't really change what -- how much are what you're looking at, but just gives you more in reserve to use. And that's one of the 3 legs of opportunity that this can be used for. We talked about the balance sheet, we talked about accelerating the activity when that makes sense, and the third piece of that is continuing to build the opportunity for the future.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016

componenttext: And I guess given the point that you made on the competitive environment, you're not the only one looking to expand in the Delaware. componenttext: I think we'll see some things with interested in. We'll just have to see if we can find to be opportunity to make the right deal at the right price. So I mean we have a big inventory. I mean as I've talked about before, our Delaware Basin position, plus our Eagle Ford position, is pretty much the same thing as our Wells Ranch and East Pony position. So both of those give you a large inventive, but we'll continue to look at what new opportunities will be there and make sure we're in the market, so we can understand that a good opportunity looks like.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Gary. I don't think that's a huge driver. I mean, it's true, if you got less activity going on, you can have a more people focus on it and perhaps be a bit more efficient. I think you also have a trade off, when you have less activity going o
componenttext: Yes, this is Gary. I don't think that's a huge driver. I mean, it's true, if you got less activity going on, you can have a more people focus on it and perhaps be a bit more efficient. I think you also have a trade off, when you have less activity going on, you have just less scale and less ability to be more efficient that way. So I don't see it being a huge driver one way or the other.

componenttext: I think I'd go back to my earlier statement. As long as we feel we can create more value out of it than somebody else, we'll continue to keep looking at that, the optionality of that acreage. I mean, I think when you look at, even outside of Wells Ranch and East Pony, it's very valuable acreage, and I think this deal highlights of that. So no rush to do anything different.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Levi. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. This morning, we issued our first quarter 2016 operational and financial news release and we also posted a number of supplemental slides to our website. You will find them helpful
componenttext:
Thanks, Levi. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. 
This morning, we issued our first quarter 2016 operational and financial news release and we also posted a number of supplemental slides to our website. You will find them helpful as we talk through our prepared comments. Later this morning, our 10-Q will be filed with the SEC. 
Following prepared comments from Dave Stover, Chairman, President and CEO; and Gary Willingham, EVP of Operations, we'll open the call for a Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] Additional management members available for Q&A are Ken Fisher, EVP and CFO; Susan Cunningham, EVP, Exploration and New Ventures; and Keith Elliott, SVP of our Eastern Mediterranean business. 
I want to remind everyone that this webcast and conference call may contain projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
With that, I'll turn the call to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. If you've had a chance to look at our earnings release and conference call slides this morning, I think you'll agree that we had a tremendous operating quarter and a very solid start to 2016. We began the year w
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. 
If you've had a chance to look at our earnings release and conference call slides this morning, I think you'll agree that we had a tremendous operating quarter and a very solid start to 2016. We began the year with these key goals: protect the balance sheet; align cash outflows with cash inflows; leverage the benefits of our diversified portfolio; and optimize returns with enhanced completions. First quarter results show we are delivering on each of these objectives. 
Before going into our results, I'd like to take a moment to discuss the current environment. With the U.S. rig count at a record low, significantly lower investment is translating into production declines in the majority of unconventional basins. It is my hope that we will continue to see capital discipline throughout the industry regarding activity levels. Even if we see sustained higher commodity prices, any meaningful U.S. production impact from increased industry activity is likely to take several months from initial investment decisions. 
Outside North America, non-OPEC major project deferrals are beginning to add up to at least a few million barrels per day through 2020. While there have been early indications of a potential commodity price turn, I expect commodities will continue to show volatility day-to-day and week-to-week. Regardless, no matter what commodity environment persist, it is clear to me Noble Energy is well positioned to sustain and create long-term value for its shareholders. 
Moving to our results. We continue to lower both our capital and underlying cost structure in the first quarter. This was primarily the result of impressive and sustainable efficiency gains in our U.S. onshore business. Capital expenditures were below the low end of our guidance and decreased for a sixth consecutive quarter as we manage within cash flow. We came in well below guidance on most of our key cost metrics. Total lease operating expense and general and administrative cost in the first quarter of 2016, which included Rosetta, were flat in an absolute amount compared to a Noble-only first quarter of 2015. This is a powerful indication of our cost-reduction efforts when you consider the company added almost 100,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day over that same period. 
Excluding the Isabela workover, unit lease operating expense was down 34% from the first quarter of last year. At the same time, we exceeded the high end of our volume guidance with 416,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day sold in the first quarter. This is up more than 30% in total and 8% pro forma for the Rosetta merger versus the same quarter last year. 
Compared to guidance, oil was higher, NGLs were higher and so was gas. This was achieved by impressive productivity improvements in the U.S. with new completions, record first quarter sales volumes in Israel and reduced downtime at Alba in Equatorial Guinea. In fact, every core area is delivering or exceeding our plans so far in 2016. 
Executions stood out in the DJ Basin position where completion optimization and longer laterals drove 34% growth in Wells Ranch and East Pony production compared to the same quarter of last year. And in the Delaware Basin, where we're just getting started, third-party analysis of state data indicates Noble Energy has the highest productivity per lateral foot in the basin this year. 
Equally as important, we maintained our robust financial position, ending the quarter with $5 billion in liquidity. Since quarter end, we have executed asset sales transactions totaling nearly $550 million, including the transaction announced yesterday. Combined with first quarter proceeds received, we will have generated total proceeds of over $775 million so far in 2016. 
The Greeley Crescent transaction significantly accelerates the value of this acreage for Noble Energy. It is an area that would not have been developed for some time as we are currently focused on higher value areas within the DJ Basin. Gary will talk more about this shortly. 
 
Our continuous focus on disciplined capital allocation and prudent balance sheet management did not go unnoticed by the rating agencies. We not only maintained our investment-grade ratings at Moody's and S&P, but received an initial investment-grade rating from Fitch as well. Ken and the treasury team do a great job continuing engagement with the rating agencies, and I believe we are 1 of only 4 of our peers with investment-grade ratings across the board. 
Our strong underlying performance, the recent upward move in commodity prices and announced proceeds from asset sales position us to generate significant excess cash in 2016 and give us more flexibility for the future. 
 
At current prices, we continue to be focused on balance sheet strength and the opportunity to pay down debt. As commodity prices move and sustain above $50 per barrel, we will begin to consider additional capital allocation to the U.S. unconventional business, with initial focus on our low-cost and liquid-rich assets in the DJ Basin in Texas. 
 
We've continued the trend of improving our performance in the first quarter, and I'm confident there is much more to come. I will now turn the call over to Gary Willingham.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. As Dave mentioned, we've continued with very high levels of operating momentum in the early part of the year, particularly in the U.S. onshore business. The level of engagement by our entire organization to contin
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. As Dave mentioned, we've continued with very high levels of operating momentum in the early part of the year, particularly in the U.S. onshore business. The level of engagement by our entire organization to continuously drive efficiencies throughout the business is certainly apparent, and realized drilling time reductions and enhanced productivity in all of our reasons. 
The DJ Basin, once again, delivered production outperformance at lower costs. First quarter production totaled 118,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. During the quarter, we reduced normalized extended-reach lateral well cost to $2.7 million in Wells Ranch, down 35% from the first quarter of 2015 despite utilizing higher profit concentrations. This decrease is the result of intense focus on drilling and completion execution, and utilizing the best rigs and the best crews in the basin. 
We continue to shift our well design to include more monobore  drilling, which provides many benefits, particularly for the combination of longer laterals and slickwater fracs. On the first 35 monobore  wells we've drilled, we're observing reduced drill times of 1.5 to 2.5 days or 30%, the ability to eliminate gel and tow stages in the long laterals. And finally, the monobore  also provides more options for future well innovations. 
Completion design continues to evolve rapidly, and it's paying off an impressive well productivity. You can see on Slide 5 the average IP-30 rate per lateral foot was up more than 30% from the same period a year ago, and the liquids content of the well, which came online in 2016, is higher than in prior years. This productivity improvement reflects both the shift to slickwater fluid as well as enhanced proppant loading. 
Both Noble Energy's and third-party infrastructure have been performing well, keeping line pressures low throughout the field. A planned turnaround at our Wells Ranch central processing facility was completed in April. This was part of routine maintenance and is the first as the facility start up 3 years ago. 
Yesterday, we announced the transaction to sell approximately 33,000 net acres from our Greeley Crescent area, which is located on the western side of our DJ acreage position. Representing about half of our acreage in Greeley Crescent, the transaction accelerates the value to Noble Energy from an area, which was not in our development plan for many years. Our strategy is to focus on areas with higher oil content where we have more contiguous acreage and can drive efficiency gains through long lateral development and existing infrastructure. Greeley Crescent is an area with very little production in horizontal drilling history, and the transaction highlights the strong value of undeveloped acreage in the DJ Basin. Total proceeds are expected to be $505 million. 
 
In Texas, we continue to deliver results that confirm our high quality positions in both the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basin. Drilling times are down 20% from prior performance on these assets, and we announced several exciting well results this morning. Results from our first 2 Delaware completions in Reeves County are impressive. The average IP-30 rate of over 320 barrels of oil equivalent per 1,000 lateral feet is nearly 15% better than the prior average on these assets. 
I want to turn your attention to Slide 7, which provides more details. These first wells validate our Tier 1 Wolfcamp A position across the eastern and western extent of the acreage. The Calamity Jane well in the east is performing significantly above Noble's 700,000-barrel type curve, with oil production in line and gas showing material outperformance. We are also pleased to see our western extension test, the Soapy Smith well, performing consistent with the Tier 1 type curve. These outstanding results right out of the gate demonstrate the transferability of our U.S. onshore completion expertise, and we will continue to delineate the acreage position while further optimizing completions this year. 
 
In the Eagle Ford, we're seeing early success bringing our improved completion designs from South Gates Ranch to new areas, unlocking additional resource potential. As Slide 8 indicates, the 2 Briscoe Ranch wells brought on during the quarter are materially outperforming the 400,000-barrel type curve you can see on the chart. In fact, they're actually outperforming even 1 million-barrel type curve. These wells have an average lateral length of 4,900 feet and were completed with 2,000 pounds of proppant per lateral foot. The better performing well was designed with tighter cluster spacing. In March, we brought 6 -- online 6 Gates Ranch wells which tested various spacing and completion concepts. We're just now seeing production post-cleanup, and these wells will drive significant volume growth in Texas during the second quarter. 
In the Marcellus, exceptional operational performance continues to ensure deliverability of base production. We remain well aligned with our partner to be cash flow neutral in the joint venture in 2016 and we'll continue to be flexible with completion activity for the remainder of the year. 
 
We started the year strongly in the Gulf of Mexico, with Big Bend and Dantzler contributing 19,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day net to Noble Energy during the quarter. This drove Gulf of Mexico oil volumes up almost 100% in the first quarter compared to the prior year. In addition, the Isabela workover was completed ahead of schedule, and Gunflint continues to progress toward the mid-year 2016 start-up. 
We recently commenced drilling an appraisal well at Katmai. This well will test resource upside to the 40 million to 60 million barrels of oil equivalent already discovered, and we anticipate results early in the fourth quarter. 
 
Sales volumes in West Africa averaged 65,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Strong underlying performance at Aseng and Alen continued during the quarter. And at Alba, installation of the new B3 compression platform was carried out with fewer downtime days than expected. Commissioning and start-up of the compression platform, which will enhance full field recovery, remains on schedule for mid-year. 
 
In Israel, natural gas sales volumes averaged to 266 million cubic feet of gas per day. This represents an increase of nearly 10% from the same period last year despite mild weather experienced thus far in 2016. With the Israeli government's mandate to reduce coal-fired generation by 15% year-over-year, we've seen consistent incremental coal-to-gas switching on the order of 50 million cubic feet per day gross with potential upside to that number. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. Before providing details on our adjusted guidance, I'd like to take a moment to provide a further update on our Israel projects. Tamar's production growth, resilient cash flows and access to significantly undersupplied markets make it one of
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. Before providing details on our adjusted guidance, I'd like to take a moment to provide a further update on our Israel projects. Tamar's production growth, resilient cash flows and access to significantly undersupplied markets make it one of the most attractive assets in the world. Leviathan is the same quality asset, on an even larger scale with a total recoverable resource of 22 trillion cubic feet of gas based on multiple appraisal wells drilled and a production test as well. 
 
In late March, Israel's Supreme Court acknowledged the strategic and national importance of these discoveries by upholding all but one of the provisions of the natural gas framework. The court recognized the importance of stabilization but rejected the specific provision in the framework. We are engaged with the government as it works to timely address the Supreme Court's concern. 
In the meantime, we continue to progress the other 3 critical requirements for a Leviathan sanction: financing, marketing and technical readiness. We are pleased that the Israeli National Planning Committee recently approved the location of the Leviathan platform and pipeline connection in northern Israel. I am convinced that Leviathan, along with Tamar, will supply much-needed gas for both Israel and the neighboring region for decades. 
We've provided a full update to our 2016 guidance on Slide 11. Normally, I wouldn't change our outlook so early in the year. But this reflects the high level of confidence I have in our strategy, assets, execution and ultimately, our future.   
Full year sales are now expected to average 405,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 4% from original guidance, with increased expectations for all 3 commodities. The production raise is based primarily on outperformance in the DJ Basin, Israel and West Africa. And on the capital side, we are trending on a path to come in under $1.5 billion. 
For the second quarter, capital is affected to be in line with the first quarter. Sales volumes are anticipated to range between 405,000 and 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. Volumes are expected to be impacted by seasonality in Israel and facility turnaround in the DJ Basin. This will be partially offset by significant quarter-over-quarter growth in Texas. We also expect higher volumes in West Africa as a result of Alba field production returning to full rate. 
In summary, I continue to be pleased with the capital efficiencies generated across the business. Our financial strengths, asset quality and onshore and offshore expertise give us a unique competitive advantage in any commodity environment. 
 
At this time, Levi, why don't we go ahead and open the call to questions?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: How should we think about asset sale targets for the year? Is there a program? And what is the use of proceeds? Did they further bolster the balance sheet or improved your ability to reaccelerate?
componenttext: How should we think about asset sale targets for the year? Is there a program? And what is the use of proceeds? Did they further bolster the balance sheet or improved your ability to reaccelerate?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as potential sales, I think this was an opportunity where we saw that it could create more value for somebody else and essentially create more value for us by monetizing the asset. It was something in our plans we weren't going to be developin
componenttext: Yes, as far as potential sales, I think this was an opportunity where we saw that it could create more value for somebody else and essentially create more value for us by monetizing the asset. It was something in our plans we weren't going to be developing for a while, given where it fit in the portfolio, so it made sense to move forward. I'd say when we look at things in general, and it goes back to kind of what our philosophy has been as we've always looked at all parts of our portfolio. If we can create more value out of it than somebody else, then we're going to do that. If there's some reason that it can -- we can realize more value from it by moving it to somebody else's hands, we'll look at that. I think as we look at the year and what we've talked about previously, the one place were Noble continued to look at potential monetization of a portion of our business is over in Israel with Tamar, for example. We've talked about as part of the framework that in over 6 years, we'll look to bring down our interest from 36% to 25%. I'd say in the current environment, there's still a lot of interest in other folks wanting to get into that field. So there could be a possibility. We might bring down some of our interest this year, but it's too early to say. So I would say that the main one we're continuing to stay focus on. Outside of that, we still have a big midstream business that we kept that S-1 active. And at some point in time, I think we'll see some real value -- additional value come out of that part of the business, but that's kind of how I think about that portfolio. Most of it's all cord up, we don't have a lot of fringe pieces. But as in the case of this opportunity, if it makes sense to accelerate value, we'll look at it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My second question is similar. Your CapEx is trending well below in 1Q, and you gave a guide that was modestly lower. Last year, many cycle savings into higher activity, are you considering recycling lower CapEx into more activity? Or is this just i
componenttext: Okay. My second question is similar. Your CapEx is trending well below in 1Q, and you gave a guide that was modestly lower. Last year, many cycle savings into higher activity, are you considering recycling lower CapEx into more activity? Or is this just in conjunction with asset sales continuing to improve the balance sheet?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in this environment, and too early to see a sustained different price outlook at this point, our -- I mentioned in the prepared comments, our initial focus, our primary focus is maintaining the strength of the balance sheet. So it gives us m
componenttext: Well, I think in this environment, and too early to see a sustained different price outlook at this point, our -- I mentioned in the prepared comments, our initial focus, our primary focus is maintaining the strength of the balance sheet. So it gives us more flexibility and more opportunity there. I think as we see, and we'll see how it progresses through the year, as we start to see more of a sustainable higher price environment, then we'll look at activity levels later in the year. But at this point, assuming we keep the same price outlook that we have right now, first priority is probably to continue to maintain the balance sheet. But I'd say, one of the things we've done with the way we've looked at even our organization and how we've managed our business, we've maintained the capability to probably adjust relatively quickly as conditions change. So this just gives us more flexibility and optionality to do that over time.

componenttext: Yes, I'll let Gary dive into that one, Charles. But I'd say, I share your enthusiasm for the results, especially when you look at the fact that we tested 2 wells on -- one in the far eastern side, one on the far western side of our contiguous acres, but let me turn that over to Gary.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles, I'd say that the length of those laterals is definitely tied more to kind of lease issues at the time they were drilled more than an indication of plans going forward. The Soapy Smith, certainly the well on the west side, is less than 2,800-
componenttext: Yes, Charles, I'd say that the length of those laterals is definitely tied more to kind of lease issues at the time they were drilled more than an indication of plans going forward. The Soapy Smith, certainly the well on the west side, is less than 2,800-foot lateral. That was actually drilled by Rosetta prior to the transaction. And it was drilled to hold that particular lease. So I think as we continue to satisfy the remaining lease obligations in the area and move into more of a development phase going on, you'll see longer and longer laterals in those areas.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks for that, Gary. And then my second question falls I suppose on the CapEx or use of proceeds of this Greeley Crescent sale. Your new guidance is for less than $1.5 billion, but I think that's probably nonspecific by design. And I wonder if yo
componenttext: Great. Thanks for that, Gary. And then my second question falls I suppose on the CapEx or use of proceeds of this Greeley Crescent sale. Your new guidance is for less than $1.5 billion, but I think that's probably nonspecific by design. And I wonder if you could give us a sense for what the moving pieces are that would get you under $1.5 billion or if that's just simply a reflection of you coming in under in the first quarter? And if that $500 million is just going to kind of sit on the balance sheet, or be there for the case where it all goes back over $50 or perhaps it's used to pay down the term loan?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Charles. I think when you look at it, I'll go back to my comment that I don't -- I usually don't like to change guidance this early in the year. But I think it's pretty obvious from the way our capital efficiency played out in the first quarter, that
componenttext: No, Charles. I think when you look at it, I'll go back to my comment that I don't -- I usually don't like to change guidance this early in the year. But I think it's pretty obvious from the way our capital efficiency played out in the first quarter, that continued improvements we're seeing, especially in our onshore programs, on what we're spending versus what we're getting, that we needed to indicate at least directionally where this was going to come. I think as far as by design, we haven't given a specific number because we're keeping that flexibility as things changed through the year. And all I'd say is on the planned activity, we're definitely on trend when you look at it to come in under the $1.5 billion, and we'll see how the year plays out as far as -- to your point, we brought in some other proceeds. We're well positioned when it make sense to increase activity, but we're not going to do that till we're comfortable that we've got a sustainable environment that supports it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
