headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: How should we think about asset sale targets for the year? Is there a program? And what is the use of proceeds? Did they further bolster the balance sheet or improve your ability to reaccelerate?
componenttext: How should we think about asset sale targets for the year? Is there a program? And what is the use of proceeds? Did they further bolster the balance sheet or improve your ability to reaccelerate?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as far as potential sales, I think this was an opportunity where we saw that it could create more value for somebody else and essentially create more value for us by monetizing the asset. It was something in our plans we weren't going to be developin
componenttext: Yes, as far as potential sales, I think this was an opportunity where we saw that it could create more value for somebody else and essentially create more value for us by monetizing the asset. It was something in our plans we weren't going to be developing for a while, given where it fit in the portfolio, so it made sense to move forward. I'd say when we look at things in general, and it goes back to kind of what our philosophy has been as we've always looked at all parts of our portfolio. If we can create more value out of it than somebody else, then we're going to do that. If there's some reason that it can -- we can realize more value from it by moving it to somebody else's hands, we'll look at that. I think as we look at the year and what we've talked about previously, the one place where Noble continued to look at potential monetization of a portion of our business is over in Israel with Tamar, for example. We've talked about as part of the framework that in over 6 years, we'll look to bring down our interest from 36% to 25%. I'd say in the current environment, there's still a lot of interest in other folks wanting to get into that field. So there could be a possibility. We might bring down some of our interest this year, but it's too early to say. So I would say that's the main one we're continuing to stay focused on. Outside of that, we still have a big midstream business that we've kept that S-1 active. And at some point in time, I think we'll see some real value -- additional value come out of that part of the business, but that's kind of how I think about the portfolio. Most of it's all cored [ph] up, we don't have a lot of fringe pieces. But as in the case of this opportunity, if it makes sense to accelerate value, we'll look at it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My second question is similar. Your CapEx is trending well below in 1Q, and you gave a guide that was modestly lower. Last year, many cycle savings [ph] into higher activity, are you considering recycling lower CapEx into more activity? Or is this j
componenttext: Okay. My second question is similar. Your CapEx is trending well below in 1Q, and you gave a guide that was modestly lower. Last year, many cycle savings [ph] into higher activity, are you considering recycling lower CapEx into more activity? Or is this just in conjunction with asset sales continuing to improve the balance sheet?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in this environment, and too early to see a sustained different price outlook at this point. Our -- I mentioned in the prepared comments, our initial focus, our primary focus is maintaining the strength of the balance sheet. So it gives us m
componenttext: Well, I think in this environment, and too early to see a sustained different price outlook at this point. Our -- I mentioned in the prepared comments, our initial focus, our primary focus is maintaining the strength of the balance sheet. So it gives us more flexibility and more opportunity there. I think as we see, and we'll see how it progresses through the year, as we start to see more of a sustainable higher price environment, then we'll look at activity levels later in the year. But at this point, assuming we keep the same price outlook that we have right now, first priority is probably to continue to maintain the balance sheet. But I'd say, one of the things we've done with the way we've looked at even our organization and how we've managed our business, we've maintained the capability to probably adjust relatively quickly as conditions change. So this just gives us more flexibility and optionality to do that over time.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Charles Meade with Johnson Rice.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on the Delaware Basin wells. Those look like really encouraging results, but I was surprised by the relatively short length of laterals. And if wonder if you could talk about your lease geometry there, whether it supports longer laterals,
componenttext: I had a question on the Delaware Basin wells. Those look like really encouraging results, but I was surprised by the relatively short length of laterals. And if wonder if you could talk about your lease geometry there, whether it supports longer laterals, and if and when those would become part of your development plan?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll let Gary dive into that one, Charles. But I'd say, I share your enthusiasm for the results, especially when you look at the fact that we tested 2 wells on -- one in the far eastern side, one on the far western side of our contiguous acres, but l
componenttext: Yes, I'll let Gary dive into that one, Charles. But I'd say, I share your enthusiasm for the results, especially when you look at the fact that we tested 2 wells on -- one in the far eastern side, one on the far western side of our contiguous acres, but let me turn that over to Gary.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles, I'd say that the length of those laterals is definitely tied more to kind of lease issues at the time they were drilled more than an indication of plans going forward. The Soapy Smith, certainly the well on the west side, is less than 2,800-
componenttext: Yes, Charles, I'd say that the length of those laterals is definitely tied more to kind of lease issues at the time they were drilled more than an indication of plans going forward. The Soapy Smith, certainly the well on the west side, is less than 2,800-foot lateral. That was actually drilled by Rosetta prior to the transaction. And it was drilled to hold that particular lease. So I think as we continue to satisfy the remaining lease obligations in the area and move into more of a development phase going on, you'll see longer and longer laterals in those areas.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks for that, Gary. And then my second question falls I suppose on the CapEx or use of proceeds of this Greeley Crescent sale. Your new guidance is for less than $1.5 billion, but I think that's probably nonspecific by design. And I wonder if yo
componenttext: Great. Thanks for that, Gary. And then my second question falls I suppose on the CapEx or use of proceeds of this Greeley Crescent sale. Your new guidance is for less than $1.5 billion, but I think that's probably nonspecific by design. And I wonder if you could give us a sense for what the moving pieces are that would get you under $1.5 billion or if that's just simply a reflection of you coming in under in the first quarter? And if that $500 million is just going to kind of sit on the balance sheet, or be there for the case where oil goes back over $50 or perhaps it's used to pay down the term loan?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Charles. I think when you look at it, I'll go back to my comment that I don't -- I usually don't like to change guidance this early in the year. But I think it's pretty obvious from the way our capital efficiency played out in the first quarter, that
componenttext: No, Charles. I think when you look at it, I'll go back to my comment that I don't -- I usually don't like to change guidance this early in the year. But I think it's pretty obvious from the way our capital efficiency played out in the first quarter, that continued improvements we're seeing, especially in our onshore programs, on what we're spending versus what we're getting, that we needed to indicate at least directionally where this was going to come. I think as far as by design, we haven't given a specific number because we're keeping that flexibility as things change through the year. And all I'd say is on the planned activity, we're definitely on trend when you look at it to come in under the $1.5 billion, and we'll see how the year plays out as far as -- to your point, we brought in some other proceeds. We're well positioned when it make sense to increase activity, but we're not going to do that till we're comfortable that we've got a sustainable environment that supports it.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy Advisors.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from David Heikkinen with Heikkinen Energy Advisors.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: One consistent theme that we have heard through earnings season is that $50 barrel fulcrum point for potentially more activity. What do you forecast or what do you think the industry should forecast for increasing services costs in an accelerating environ
componenttext: One consistent theme that we have heard through earnings season is that $50 barrel fulcrum point for potentially more activity. What do you forecast or what do you think the industry should forecast for increasing services costs in an accelerating environment?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, Dave. I think, obviously, you would expect it -- it's going to be driven by activity and it's also going to be driven by the ability of the service sector to get the people back to work. So one of the things we've tried to do is main
componenttext: It's a good question, Dave. I think, obviously, you would expect it -- it's going to be driven by activity and it's also going to be driven by the ability of the service sector to get the people back to work. So one of the things we've tried to do is maintain those relationships, especially in the key basins, so that we're kind of on the priority list for returning to work, if you will. Yes, I don't have a real strong sense as to what the magic price. I think it's going to be more what the magic amount of activity that starts to put more pressure on the service sector or the supply [ph] of available resource. And then we'll just have to see it plays from there. I think the one thing that's been encouraging from some of this, as we've really focused on some of the efficiencies, and you've seen this from a number of folks, the other piece of that is that there's still a large piece of this that we're seeing, probably 50% or more, of our onshore cost reduction that we think is at least sustainable on a much higher price environment. Just from the way we've changed the way we're doing our business. Then when you look at the other part going forward, and here's where the diversified portfolio plays in, I think there's still a lot of room for offshore projects, especially new project costs to come down and stay down for a while, and not respond real quickly to any change.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Stephen Richardson with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Stephen Richardson with Evercore ISI.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question, David. I appreciate all the comments on capital flexibility. Can you remind us as we want to think forward to 6 to 12 months from now and even into '17, how do you think about your flexibility on capital? So can you just remind us what you
componenttext: Quick question, David. I appreciate all the comments on capital flexibility. Can you remind us as we want to think forward to 6 to 12 months from now and even into '17, how do you think about your flexibility on capital? So can you just remind us what you think maintenance capital is for U.S. onshore business in this environment? And maybe any major project obligations you think you have, either Gulf of Mexico, West Africa or internationally? Again, acknowledging that, that's all dependent on project sanction and everything. But how do you think about the flexibility around the program in '17?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we have tremendous flexibility in '17, probably even more so than we had going into '16. I think the only places that we're looking at as far as committed capital, if you will, when you start from a bottoms up, we have probably about a half y
componenttext: Yes, I think we have tremendous flexibility in '17, probably even more so than we had going into '16. I think the only places that we're looking at as far as committed capital, if you will, when you start from a bottoms up, we have probably about a half year with our rig in the Gulf of Mexico and we have a few leases in the Texas properties that you'd want to drill to maintain your acreage position. But outside of that, we've got pretty much complete flexibility. So I think we've got a lot of room to make decisions based on whatever the environment turns out to be. I think as far as the maintenance piece, we've kind of talked about that last time, and I don't think our view on that has changed any.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And maybe on Israel, one thing that would be interesting is, what are your current thoughts on the potential expansion of Tamar? I appreciate the comments on the potential monetization of that 11% working interest. But how do you think about the pot
componenttext: Okay. And maybe on Israel, one thing that would be interesting is, what are your current thoughts on the potential expansion of Tamar? I appreciate the comments on the potential monetization of that 11% working interest. But how do you think about the potential expansion projects and some of the things that have been discussed in the past? And where they sit in the priority queue, particularly relative to Leviathan?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I think a lot of the discussion has been, and what you'll see news on, is obviously getting the second big source of supply online. So that's been a lot of what the news focus has been on Leviathan. But if you step back and look at what's happe
componenttext: Yes, well, I think a lot of the discussion has been, and what you'll see news on, is obviously getting the second big source of supply online. So that's been a lot of what the news focus has been on Leviathan. But if you step back and look at what's happening with Tamar, and I mentioned it, or Gary or I both mentioned it, that you're seeing more of this push to move more of the power generation from coal to gas. We actually saw that show up in the first quarter. I think we're still being cautious about what we'll see for the rest of the year, but that's a near-term positive impact for Tamar. You still have the drive and the push from customers in Egypt to get gas, interruptible gas, as soon as that can be worked out. So I think when you look at both near and then the longer-term market viability for both of those projects, it's pretty exciting place to have that quality of opportunity when you think about the combination of the reservoir characteristics and the access to market over there for both of those, Tamar and Leviathan.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. Just one quick follow-up, David. So would you think that we would be in a position potentially to have an expansion of Tamar, and concurrently FID and beginning of a project Leviathan at the same time in 2017, if everything lines up on the regu
componenttext: I'm sorry. Just one quick follow-up, David. So would you think that we would be in a position potentially to have an expansion of Tamar, and concurrently FID and beginning of a project Leviathan at the same time in 2017, if everything lines up on the regulatory side?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, just because of the emphasis on the priority and the critical need to get that second big project on, I would continue to think of the Tamar expansion as probably following the Leviathan project.
componenttext: First, just because of the emphasis on the priority and the critical need to get that second big project on, I would continue to think of the Tamar expansion as probably following the Leviathan project.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to see if you guys could discuss the potential implications from an inventory perspective of some of the results that you shared at Briscoe Ranch?
componenttext: I wanted to see if you guys could discuss the potential implications from an inventory perspective of some of the results that you shared at Briscoe Ranch?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me turn that over to Gary.
componenttext: Okay, let me turn that over to Gary.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun. I think the exciting thing about the results we're seeing at Briscoe is we've taken an area and significantly improved it by taking learnings from South Gates Ranch to a new area in the Eagle Ford. Of course, a lot of the success that we've had
componenttext: Yes, Arun. I think the exciting thing about the results we're seeing at Briscoe is we've taken an area and significantly improved it by taking learnings from South Gates Ranch to a new area in the Eagle Ford. Of course, a lot of the success that we've had in South Gates Ranch improvement, and you're seeing it in the Delaware now too, comes from our prior experience in the Marcellus and the DJ. And collectively, as a company, we've completed over 1,600 horizontal wells now. So we got a lot of learnings under our belt. I think specifically for that acreage and the inventory and the running room, Briscoe Ranch is a fairly small portion of the acreage. It's less than 5,000 acres, I think. But the exciting thing is there's other acreage nearby, which we think a lot of those same improvements and completion designs can be applied to, and we can see perhaps similar uplift to the results on those wells. So even though that block of acreage isn't huge, it certainly applies elsewhere. We've continued to have quite a bit of inventory still in South Gates Ranch, North Gates Ranch, and then obviously in the Delaware, we're just getting started with the first 2 wells.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I think, Gary, you guys have talked about 165 locations at Gates Ranch, and 475 elsewhere within the Eagle Ford. So you think that perhaps some of the enhanced completions could maybe improve the well productivity on the balance outside of Gates Ra
componenttext: Great. I think, Gary, you guys have talked about 165 locations at Gates Ranch, and 475 elsewhere within the Eagle Ford. So you think that perhaps some of the enhanced completions could maybe improve the well productivity on the balance outside of Gates Ranch?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I mean, I think the results that we've seen, and again, it goes back to what we've done in the DJ and the Marcellus, now the Eagle Ford and the Permian, where we've continued to see improvement in results as we've continued to refine completio
componenttext: Absolutely. I mean, I think the results that we've seen, and again, it goes back to what we've done in the DJ and the Marcellus, now the Eagle Ford and the Permian, where we've continued to see improvement in results as we've continued to refine completion techniques, I think what you're seeing now certainly bodes well for the potential of the future completions in those areas. I think the numbers you're citing there are still based on wider spacing too. So the extent that we continue to get better at confining the fracs and stimulating more of the near wellbore rock, that potentially opens up tighter spacing over time, too, which would only add to the inventory count.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my follow-up is on the DJ. You talked about 30% kind of per lateral foot productivity gains. What also surprised me was just the oil mix in the new wells. So I was just wondering if you could maybe just talk to us why you think the oil mix was
componenttext: Great. And my follow-up is on the DJ. You talked about 30% kind of per lateral foot productivity gains. What also surprised me was just the oil mix in the new wells. So I was just wondering if you could maybe just talk to us why you think the oil mix was higher? Was it related to mix? I know that the East Pony wells are a little bit oiler, but could you maybe just talk to that because that is a pretty significant delta in terms of -- versus the historical mix in the DJ.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, and the numbers on that slide are obviously over a 3-year period. So it just goes to show why over the last couple of years, we've really been talking a lot about refocusing activity in the best of the best, which is the higher oil content ar
componenttext: Yes, I mean, and the numbers on that slide are obviously over a 3-year period. So it just goes to show why over the last couple of years, we've really been talking a lot about refocusing activity in the best of the best, which is the higher oil content areas, Wells Ranch and East Pony. East Pony is, by far, the highest oil percentage acreage that we have in our portfolio, and that's were a large number of the wells that we're bringing on early part of this year were from. So that's partly driving that percentage up.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Gary, just in terms of the overall type curve, you have some decent history now on the DJ. When could you potentially declare victory on a higher type curve, given the slickwater and some of the enhanced completions that you're doing now on the DJ?
componenttext: And Gary, just in terms of the overall type curve, you have some decent history now on the DJ. When could you potentially declare victory on a higher type curve, given the slickwater and some of the enhanced completions that you're doing now on the DJ?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think certainly by year end, we'll probably start talking about new EURs and new type curves. I think we're not done testing new ideas. We've only recently really ramped up the sand concentration in some of these wells, and we've only done it on few so
componenttext: I think certainly by year end, we'll probably start talking about new EURs and new type curves. I think we're not done testing new ideas. We've only recently really ramped up the sand concentration in some of these wells, and we've only done it on few so far. So I think we'd like to get a few more of those under our belt and see some extended production history on some of these wells before we update the numbers. But clearly, from what we're seeing in the early time data, the results are very encouraging versus what we've talked about in the past.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from David Tameron with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from David Tameron with Wells Fargo.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Dave, if I go back to that -- the $50-barrel type number, let's say tomorrow you get additional -- let's say we go to $50, we stay there, or whatever the number is, you get an extra $300 million or $400 million of cash flow that you want to spend on Ca
componenttext: So Dave, if I go back to that -- the $50-barrel type number, let's say tomorrow you get additional -- let's say we go to $50, we stay there, or whatever the number is, you get an extra $300 million or $400 million of cash flow that you want to spend on CapEx, where -- I know you mentioned U.S. shale, but where specifically, where -- how should we think about that allocation?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we'd continue to build out our DJ Basin, accelerate some of that inventory, and we'll probably ramp up and accelerate some of the Delaware Basin. I don't know, Gary, do you have any different view?
componenttext: I think we'd continue to build out our DJ Basin, accelerate some of that inventory, and we'll probably ramp up and accelerate some of the Delaware Basin. I don't know, Gary, do you have any different view?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's where we'd focus.
componenttext: No, I think that's where we'd focus.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second, if I think about the Greeley acreage. I mean, any concern about some of the setback? And does that factor in the decision to sell that versus other parts of the DJ that you don’t have on the development time frame?
componenttext: Okay. And then second, if I think about the Greeley acreage. I mean, any concern about some of the setback? And does that factor in the decision to sell that versus other parts of the DJ that you don’t have on the development time frame?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think when you're looking at any other factors like setback or some of these other things, I think for us, the biggest reason we sold that acreage was we felt somebody else could create more value out of it by accelerating than we were going to crea
componenttext: No, I think when you're looking at any other factors like setback or some of these other things, I think for us, the biggest reason we sold that acreage was we felt somebody else could create more value out of it by accelerating than we were going to create over time. And it actually increased our value because what we're focusing on, and what we will be for a while here, is where we have infrastructure in place where we can drill longer laterals and where have a higher oil content. So I mean, those are the reasons we made that transaction.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Dave Kistler with Simmons & Company.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Real quickly. One of the comments on acceleration of activity, can you guys just give us a little bit of color in terms of after making personnel adjustments, what kind of a rig ramp you could prosecute? Or in some respects, I guess, that would be offset
componenttext: Real quickly. One of the comments on acceleration of activity, can you guys just give us a little bit of color in terms of after making personnel adjustments, what kind of a rig ramp you could prosecute? Or in some respects, I guess, that would be offset by the efficiencies you've seen as well, but maybe kind of a max rig count that the current staff could handle?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I'll turn that over to Gary for some color, but that's one of the things we took into consideration as we looked at any adjustments in our organization was to make sure we had the flexibility to go up or down within a reasonable range. So let me
componenttext: Yes, and I'll turn that over to Gary for some color, but that's one of the things we took into consideration as we looked at any adjustments in our organization was to make sure we had the flexibility to go up or down within a reasonable range. So let me ask Gary to just give you more of his thoughts on that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes -- no, Dave. That's true. We did retain a decent amount of flexibility in our ability to ramp up activity when prices recover. So we're just running the 2 rigs and the DJ right now. We've got the capacity to handle a bit more activity there than 2 rig
componenttext: Yes -- no, Dave. That's true. We did retain a decent amount of flexibility in our ability to ramp up activity when prices recover. So we're just running the 2 rigs and the DJ right now. We've got the capacity to handle a bit more activity there than 2 rigs when time is right. I think when you look at Texas, we're running off and on 1 rig total between the 2 areas, and we can certainly increase that activity a bit within the constraints of the current organization. So I think, for any reasonable amount of activity increase that you would expect to see over the near term, we're fine.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think the other key thing with that, Dave, and I mentioned it earlier, is maintaining the relationships with the service providers, so you can stay in the priority queue there.
componenttext: And I think the other key thing with that, Dave, and I mentioned it earlier, is maintaining the relationships with the service providers, so you can stay in the priority queue there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just looking at kind of the decline in well cost in the DJ Basin. Obviously, completions have become more intense, and I'm just trying to understand that the biggest driver of that is? I mean, we understand efficiency gains. But is there so
componenttext: Okay. And then just looking at kind of the decline in well cost in the DJ Basin. Obviously, completions have become more intense, and I'm just trying to understand that the biggest driver of that is? I mean, we understand efficiency gains. But is there something you're doing differently that's allowing you to reduce the costs as dramatically as you were able to show this quarter?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave. I mean, it's a lot of things. I mean, it's not one thing that's driving it. I mean, you certainly see it in the continuing improvement in the drilling performance where we continue to set records on a fairly consistent basis, taking a little bi
componenttext: Yes, Dave. I mean, it's a lot of things. I mean, it's not one thing that's driving it. I mean, you certainly see it in the continuing improvement in the drilling performance where we continue to set records on a fairly consistent basis, taking a little bit of time off here and there of our previous records on drilling times. Slickwater is certainly -- have been a driver of it as well. Moving to monobore drilling has helped by taking a day, sometimes more than that, off of the wells as well. So -- and then in Wells Ranch and East Pony, where we've got existing infrastructure and the ability to drill those long laterals, which can drive your average cost per foot down as well, certainly help out. So do have some things that are offsetting that as we're moving to higher and higher sand concentrations and testing some tighter spacing in some areas, but the good news is we've been able to deliver enough efficiencies in all the other areas to more than offset that and continue to drive costs down. As we mentioned in the press release, we're down to $2.7 million in Wells Ranch on an extended reach well, adjusted back to a normal lateral length. And that's with some of the impact of the higher completion cost from the higher sand loading. If you go back to more of a traditional type completion design that we might have had in the past, those costs are down more to the $2.4 million range. So great job by the teams and continuing to execute and look for efficiencies.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe just one follow-up. Is any of that cost-saving associated with using existing pads or would that be a step-shift change as you go to that over time?
componenttext: And maybe just one follow-up. Is any of that cost-saving associated with using existing pads or would that be a step-shift change as you go to that over time?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say very little, if any, of it is probably associated with that in the DJ. We don't have a lot of activity in the DJ where we go back to an existing pad and drill more wells, given the type of acreage we've got there, being HBP and the ability to plan
componenttext: I'd say very little, if any, of it is probably associated with that in the DJ. We don't have a lot of activity in the DJ where we go back to an existing pad and drill more wells, given the type of acreage we've got there, being HBP and the ability to plan that out around the infrastructure development plans. We generally go in and build a pad and drill it out from the beginning. So there might be some savings of a that type come up in the Permian later on as we go back and move to a development mode there, but I wouldn't expect a lot of that in the DJ.

componenttext: Well, I think we continue to look at it. I mean, our position has been, we're not going to spend significant money till we're comfortable. componenttext: Wanted to follow up on a couple of earlier questions. First, on the Delaware basin wells that you highlighted on Slide 7, both had strong rates versus your type curve. If we look at the relative performance of each, the Calamity Jane outperformed on a lateral length basis, adjusted basis, seemingly a lot more from gas than NGLs relative to oil. And I wondered if you could talk about the geology as it moves from east to west within your acreage block, and if we should expect a differentiation in well productivity and in production mix?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think on the Calamity Jane, the gas percentage, what we see from our mapping is, as you move probably further north and maybe a little east of the Calamity Jane location, we think it does get a little gassier, and we think we've tapped into some of
componenttext: Yes. I think on the Calamity Jane, the gas percentage, what we see from our mapping is, as you move probably further north and maybe a little east of the Calamity Jane location, we think it does get a little gassier, and we think we've tapped into some of that with this well. I think as you move back to the west, where, by far, the majority of our acreage is, we would expect to see the higher oil cuts more in line with what we're seeing in Soapy Smith.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And should the decline profile look similar on both wells? Or is there any other differentiation that you see?
componenttext: Got it. And should the decline profile look similar on both wells? Or is there any other differentiation that you see?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we consider it all Tier 1 acreage. But even within Tier 1, there's obviously some acreages better than others. And I think generally speaking, we see the eastern half of the acreage, Tier 1 acreage, slightly higher quality. I think you're se
componenttext: Well, I think we consider it all Tier 1 acreage. But even within Tier 1, there's obviously some acreages better than others. And I think generally speaking, we see the eastern half of the acreage, Tier 1 acreage, slightly higher quality. I think you're seeing that in the performance of the wells. Most of the activity that we have planned for the rest of the year is in either the central or eastern half of the acreage block. So we'll continue to test that theory as we go. I think the interesting thing about the Soapy Smith is even though it's outperforming the type curve, not as much as the Calamity Jane is, but it's outperforming the type curve, it's significantly outperforming, I think, some of the historical wells in that area by as much as 20% or 30%. And so that's the well we did the slickwater test on. It's really the only well that we've done a slickwater test on in that area. I think that potentially could create some excitement going forward as we test more slickwater in the Delaware Basin and see how much uplift we can get from that versus the historical hybrids.

componenttext: Well, it just gives us more firepower, if you will, Brian, for that type of thing. This doesn't really change what -- how much or what you're looking at, but it just gives you more in reserve to use. And that's one of the 3 legs of opportunity that this can be used for. We talked about the balance sheet, we talked about accelerating the activity when that makes sense, and the third piece of that is continuing to build opportunity for the future.

componenttext: Yes, Doug. This is Gary. I mean, I don't think that's a huge driver. headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Noble Energy's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. And now, I'd like to turn the conference over to Mr. Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jake. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today.This morning, I hope you've had a chance to review our second quarter 2016 operational and financial news release as well as the supplemental slides for this event, which highlight
componenttext:
Thanks, Jake. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today.
This morning, I hope you've had a chance to review our second quarter 2016 operational and financial news release as well as the supplemental slides for this event, which highlight a very strong quarter for Noble Energy and an enhanced outlook the remainder of  the year. Both items are posted to our website, and you will find them helpful as we talk through our prepared comments. In addition, we anticipate filing our 10-Q with the SEC later this morning. 
Following prepared comments from Dave Stover, Chairman, President and CEO; and Gary Willingham, EVP of Operations, we'll open the event for a Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] Additional management members available for Q&A are Ken Fisher, EVP and CFO; Susan Cunningham, EVP, Exploration and New Ventures; and Keith Elliott, SVP of our Eastern Med assets.
I want to remind everyone that this event may contain projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
With that, I'll turn the call to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Before diving into specifics on the quarter, I thought it'll be helpful to take a high-level view of our performance to date in 2016. Entering the year with an uncertain outlook on commodities, our stated focus wa
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Before diving into specifics on the quarter, I thought it'll be helpful to take a high-level view of our performance to date in 2016. Entering the year with an uncertain outlook on commodities, our stated focus was clear. First, operate the business within cash flows. Second, continue to improve capital efficiency to enhance returns. And third, increase our flexibility and financial strength by leveraging our portfolio. We are running well ahead of plan for the year and meeting or exceeding all of these identified goals. 
We've delivered another quarter where cash flow exceeded capital expenditures. We raised our full year 2016 volume expectation for a second time this year, providing an additional 10 million barrels of oil equivalent compared to our original expectation. We have accomplished this with less capital than original planned, an efficiency story that not many in our industry can match. 
We've also reset our underlying cost structures and continue to strengthen our financial position through a series of portfolio optimization transactions. 
Each of these accomplishment has improved our long-term outlook and generated significant value. 
In terms of what we control. In our business, I can easily say that we are executing as well as I've seen in my 14-year history with Noble. 
Moving into the second quarter results. It was a period of operational records and milestones. To name a few, Noble reported record total company sales volumes, led by our U.S. onshore assets and Israel. Over the last year, we realized that daily volume increase of nearly 130,000 barrels of oil equivalent, while absolute lease operating expense and G&A combined were actually down period-over-period. As part of the volume increase, 31,000 barrels per day were oil and 32,000 barrels per day were NGLs. 
Focusing onshore. In Texas, we brought online our best Delaware Basin well yet, along with several great Eagle Ford wells, extending our successes in these assets since we acquired them a year ago. In the DJ Basin, we enhanced our asset position through a strategic acreage exchange, adding additional depth of high-quality inventory in our core Wells Ranch IDP area. And in the Marcellus, wells continue to outperform expectation, enhancing resource recovery in this leading gas position. 
This operational momentum has continued offshore. Recent highlights include: In the Gulf of Mexico, we commenced production at Gunflint on time and under budget. In Equatorial Guinea, the Alba compression project has also started off. And in Israel, at the beginning of July, we entered into an agreement for an initial 3% divestiture of our world-class Tamar asset establishing a growth valuation benchmark of $12.3 billion. 
Second quarter volumes totaled 427,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, an increase of 43% versus the second quarter of last year, or 18% on a pro forma basis. Performance for each business unit in commodity was ahead of expectations. This illustrates the benefits of our portfolio and industry-leading execution, continuing to drive differential value among our peer group. 
With respect to cost. Results were within or below our expectation on essentially every metric. Capital was below below the low end of guidance driven by efficiency gains and the shifting of some onshore wells into the second half of the year. Unit lease operating expense stood out, down 30% from the second quarter of last year. LOE per barrel equivalent benefited from record total production and deferred worker activity. 
I cannot overemphasize the strong performance of our Texas assets where completion optimization and a busy quarter of activity drove substantial growth. 
Our third Noble design Delaware Basin completion is showing robust productivity and a higher oil mix. Gary will share more on this well and our plans for the Delaware in a minute. 
Everyone seems curious how we and others are thinking about capital allocation for the remainder of the year and into 2017. Our capital allocation discussion never stops as a continual process focused on delivering the best value and returns. The forward curve on oil has declined versus where it was the time of our last earnings call, and 2017 remains notably below the $50 level. The recent trend reflects resilient global supply and high inventories. The outlook on gas appears to have improved slightly for 2017 yet it softens quickly in the following years. Significant volatility in both commodities remain. We've not yet seen market fundamentals reach a point where we would consider changing our capital plans for the year. At the same time, our execution and operating performance has increased our inventory and resource potential for when the environment is appropriate to accelerate. And while total capital for the year remains under $1.5 billion, it has shifted slightly more toward the U.S. onshore unconventional plays where we have been able to exceed our production goals with fewer completions. Adding to our flexibility is the expectation that we will now exit this year with about 140 operated drilled and completed wells. This represents a decrease of just 10% from the beginning of the year, a higher inventory -- higher inventory than previously expected. 
As we look forward, our capital will be prioritize on accelerating our Delaware Basin position, developing our DJ and Eagle Ford positions and post sanction, implementing our first phase of Leviathan. Our other offshore assets will provide necessary cash to support these activities. The Marcellus program will be driven by the gas price outlook. 
With an improved liquidity profile following our asset sale proceeds, we're positioned to begin paying down debt by the end of the year, which will continue to lower Noble's underlying cost structure and further strengthen our balance sheet. Sufficient liquidity will be maintained to allow us increased activity when it make sense. 
We have executed as well as anyone during the volatility over the last 2 years. I am confident that our focus and disciplined strategy is the right approach in this environment. 
Let me know hand the call over to Gary to walk through an excellent operating performance.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. As Dave mention, high levels of operating momentum continued in the second quarter, particularly in the U.S. onshore business. Operating and capital cost have been further reduced, and production from new wells is outpe
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone. As Dave mention, high levels of operating momentum continued in the second quarter, particularly in the U.S. onshore business. Operating and capital cost have been further reduced, and production from new wells is outperforming historical price curves in every one of our business units. 
I want to start off this quarter in Texas, where improvements we've made in both areas in a relatively short PUDs of time highlight the quality of our acreage and the value that Noble Energy can deliver. 
I'll start in the Delaware with the Calamity Jane 2101H well. To say this is an exciting well is an understatement, especially when you consider it's only our third completion in the basin. You can see on Slide 5 the location of the well versus the first 2 Noble completions. The 2101H well is nearly 5,000 feet in lateral length, and was completed with 3,000 pounds of profits per lateral foot and slickwater fluid. 
In absolute terms, we have 2,500 barrel of oil equivalent per day well, with 1,450 barrels of oil, 560 barrels of natural gas liquids and over 3 million cubic feet of gas per day. The chart shows the production compared to our prior 2 wells in the type curve. The first 2 wells continue to widen versus the 700,000-barrel equivalent type curve, and this latest well is even better. Versus type curve, this most recent well is more than 75% higher. 
From recent industry M&A activity is clear that the value of the Delaware Basin acreage continue to increase. Two reason transactions, specifically in and around our acreage, reaffirmed to me that we have a very enviable 45,000-acre position in the basin. Being early into the play, obviously generated tremendous amount of value. 
Wel have a rig operating in the Delaware continuously through the remainder of the year, with several new drills in the wells coming on production. Long-term development planning is underway, and our focus will be on delivering substantial well cost efficiencies by utilizing multiwell pad design and longer laterals and will also delineate multiple Wolfcamp zones in the Third Bone spring across our acreage. In addition, we're working to design centralized infrastructure, which will support our long-term plans. 
We also announced extremely strong results in the Eagle Ford this morning, specifically in the Gates Ranch area. Slightly more than half of the announced well had 500-foot lateral spacing with the remainder completed at 1,000-foot lateral spacing or more. And I want to emphasize a couple of takeaways from this results, which are shown on Slide 6. First, results continue to demonstrate the benefits of higher intensity fracs, specifically more profit with tighter cluster and spacing. A graet example of this is the 2 wells, which commenced production in the North Gates Ranch area during the quarter. These wells are performing above the 3 million-barrel equivalent type curve that we used for Southern Gates Ranch or 3x our prior assumption for North Gates Ranch. This follows similar significantly improved results in Briscoe Ranch, which we talked about last quarter. Second, we are gathering additional production history on lateral spacing, which will increase our drilling inventory going forward. With a 500-foot space well performing in line with a 3 million-barrel equivalent type curve, we believe that the South Gates Ranch area will support at least 750-foot spacing as we move into drilling and completing the fourth row of South South Gates Ranch during 2017. 
In addition to our Delaware rig activity, we have a rig coming into the Eagle Ford for the remainder of the year and have ongoing completion activity as well. Our Eagle Ford volumes will be lower in the third quarter reflecting shut in impacts from offsetting frac activity. Several new wells are expected to come online toward the end of the third quarter giving us strong momentum exiting the year and into 2017.  This will include wells in the Briscoe Ranch area, one of which will be in upper Eagle Ford test. 
Moving to the DJ Basin. The dominant theme to the new transformative capital efficiencies from drill time reductions and cost savings as well as performance improvements from enhanced completions. As we indicated on the first quarter call, our central processing facility underwent its first planned turnaround since starting out 3 years ago. As a result, the only wells which were brought online during the quarter were in May or June, and thus did not have a full quarter impact. The basin also experienced unplanned third-party facility downtime during the quarter. 
Once again, we reduced normalized extended reach lateral well cost. We are now down to $2.6 million in Wells Ranch, which represents a sequential quarterly decrease of another 4%. This includes the cost efficiency in modern bore drilling, which accounted for nearly all of our drilling activity during the second quarter as well as the increased cost of higher sand concentrations and higher stages. 
On the completion design front, the change for slickwater fluid as well as increasing profit loading continues. Now turn your attention to Slide 8, which provides more details. Cumulative production chart on the right show the actual averages for these new completion designs with 1,000 pounds of profit or more compared to the historical type curve. As you can see, performance in Wells Ranch is at least 15% higher-than-historical type curves, and East Pony has improved by more than 35%. With the continued strong performance improvement, I am excited about the potential impact of a higher percentage of these well designs coming online the remainder of the year. 
The new [indiscernible] motor pad and Mustang IDP includes our first 7 wells testing enhanced completions outside of Wells Ranch in East Pony. These wells came online at the end of the quarter and are significantly outperforming expectations, which speaks very positively for the future potential of our Mustang IDP development. 
During the quarter, we continue to optimize our large DJ Basin acreage position. We completed the first closing of the previously announced sale of approximately 33,000 net acres from our Greeley Crescent area. This acreage was not in our development plans for many years. We received $486 million in proceeds, with the remaining $19 million expected around the end of the year. 
In addition, we completed our strategic acreage trade with PDC Energy, which expands our Wells Ranch position by approximately 20% and provides substantial operating synergies and cost efficiencies for both companies. Both transactions are consistent with our strategy to focus on areas with higher well content where we have more contiguous acreage then drive efficiency gains for the long lateral development and existing infrastructure. 
As part of our focus on improving total value in the DJ Basin, we have been deferring workovers and repairs, especially for legacy vertical wells, when those expenditures just don't make sense in this price environment. As a result of these economic choices, vertical production is expected to be impacted by up to 5,000 barrels equipment per day during the second half of 2016. 
Moving on to the Marcellus. Production remains above expectations despite the limited capital spend. In addition, the JV continues to benefit from shared infrastructure to optimize recycling of produced water, significantly reducing our operating expenses. Recent pads in both the wet and dry gas areas continue to highlight the prolific nature of our position in the play as depicted on Slide 9. We remain aligned with our partner to operate the JV within cash flow in 2016 and will continue to be flexible with activities the remainder of the year. 
At current commodity prices, we expect 6 additional wells to be completed between now and year-end. The continued outstanding performance of the Marcellus wells has driven the growth seen by CONE, the midstream gathering company partially owned by Noble. 
Offshore in the Gulf of Mexico. We continue to see strong production for the Big Bend and Dantzler fields during the quarter. This is despite a temporary shut in of the Thunder Hawk facility in late June due to issues downstream third-party gas processing plant. 
In July, we brought online our Gunflint development on time and under budget. This is the third middle Miocene tieback to commence production in the last 12 months contributing to the almost doubling of our Gulf of Mexico volumes this year.  The net amount from Gunflint in Noble Energy is expected to be at least 5,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with potential for additional volumes dependent upon available capacity and a third-party host facility. The 2 wells are currently ramping up as expected. 
Sales volumes in the West Africa were up from the first quarter, which had downtime from the installation of the new Alba B3 compression platform. Start-up of this Marathon-operated project, which will enhance full bill recovery, occurred in July. While Noble's quarterly sales volumes will fluctuate a bit quarter-to-quarter based on the lifting schedule, we would expect total West Africa production to remain relatively level for the remainder of the year. 
Our Gulf of Mexico and West Africa assets don't often get the attention from the equity markets they deserve. The company's major project execution capabilities were highlighted again recently with the success of the Gunflint and Alba, and these capabilities continued to deliver substantial value for Noble Energy. 
Looking forward, near-term capital needs in both are relatively low and the assets remain significant cash flow generators. 
In Israel, natural gas volumes from Tamar were up nearly 30% from the same period last year and even higher than the first quarter of this year. Israeli government has mandated the reduction of coal-fired power generation by 15% year-over-year as shown on Slide 11. This reflects the government's recognition of the economic and environmental benefits of natural gas and the confidence in the timing of the Leviathan development. This new underlying  base load demand is showing up in big numbers, particularly in the shoulder periods when additional quantities of gas have historically been available. As a result, coal power [indiscernible] is during the second quarter was down over 20% versus the second quarter of last year. We are now into the high demand third quarter period when Israel will need even more gas. 
We've also announced plans to commence drilling and other wells in Tamar later this year, which will reinforce reliability and help meet peak demand going forward. 
At Leviathan, we are continuing to target the final investment decision around year end. We've now contracted up to 100 million cubic feet per day of natural gas to Israeli customers and continue to advance negotiations with additional domestic and regional customers. The regulatory progress we have a seen over the last quarter is also significant, including the government approval of the fixed platform plan and development. Feed work is under way, and early indications are that that this continues to be a great opportunity to log in very competitive cost for this long-life resource project. Over the coming months, we expect to finalize remaining key milestones for sanctions. This includes additional sales contracts, both in Israel and for the export market and financing plans as well as completion of the engineering work and project cost estimates. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. We've provided a full update of our 2016 guidance on Slide 14. As I mentioned earlier, we've now raised full year sales volumes to 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up more than 7% from our original guidance on a divestment-adjusted
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. We've provided a full update of our 2016 guidance on Slide 14. As I mentioned earlier, we've now raised full year sales volumes to 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up more than 7% from our original guidance on a divestment-adjusted basis, while reducing our original full year capital expenditure guidance. Not many companies will grow production at that rate while enhancing their financial position and without diluting shareholders. This is a testament to our high-quality portfolio and the underlying execution in our business delivered by our talented and dedicated workforce. 
For the third quarter, capital is expected to range between $400 million and $450 million with 80% going to the U.S. onshore business. Sales volumes are anticipated to range between 405,000 and 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. The primary difference from the second quarter is our Eagle Ford volumes due to well shut-ins for offsite completions. 
In our other onshore areas, Marcellus will likely be up in the third quarter, and DJ is expected to be down, reflecting lower vertical production, as Gary mentioned. Offshore volumes should be relatively flat to the second quarter with Israel up and West Africa lower due to timing of liftings. 
The third quarter outlook also includes the impact of about 2,000-barrel equivalent per day from the word sale in Montana and the initial closing of the Greeley Crescent divestiture. The production impact from asset sales grossed around 8,000 barrels of oil equivalent in the fourth quarter, with the second Greeley Crescent closing and the Tamar saledown already announced. These asset divestitures accelerate and highlight the value in our portfolio. 
There's a lot to look forward to in the second half of 2016. We have continuous operations ongoing in both the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basins, including the doubling of the new wells in the Delaware compared to the first half of the year. We will also continue to advance the enhanced completion designs in the DJ Basin and leverage our midstream competitive advantage. And in Israel, we expect to see higher utilization of our Tamar asset, while at the same time, progressing Leviathan towards final investment decisions. 
When you put it all together, this is a great company with a great future. The high-quality and deep inventory of our U.S. onshore portfolio can deliver high return growth for many years. This is complemented by the visible and prolific long-term growth in the value potential of the Eastern Med assets. In addition, the Gulf of Mexico and West Africa assets provide meaningful and long-term cash generation. Portfolio execution and financial capacity, these are our competitive advantages and our strong foundation to build upon. 
At this time, Jake, we'll go ahead and open the call for questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, clearly, we've been very happy with the results we've seen after only the first 3 wells. I think for the plans for the rest of the year, lateral length may do get a little bit longer for the second half of this year, and then we'll really sta
componenttext: Yes, I mean, clearly, we've been very happy with the results we've seen after only the first 3 wells. I think for the plans for the rest of the year, lateral length may do get a little bit longer for the second half of this year, and then we'll really start to see longer laterals lengths probably be getting more in '17. We're continuing to test different completion designs, so we're not quite in that full development mode yet that you would expect to see. I'll start to see significant savings on the DMC side, and that will probably come more in '17 as we get into full development mode as well. For the rest of this year, we're going to be testing different designs. So this latest well with 3,000 pounds per foot will actually go back and test some lower and concentration on these next couple of wells just as we zero in on what the best value case is. I think for us, we're always trying to look at what's the most of value-creating completion that we can design. It's not about IP-30, although clearly, we're very happy with this being our best IP 30 well to date and one of the best we've seen anywhere in the basin. It's certainly not about IP 24, it's not about EUR over the long term, it's about how much value we can create. So we'll test some smaller sand concentration designs as well as we zero in on that value, and we'll have another half dozen or so well by the time we get to the end of the year to help inform what our plans are for next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Evan, the other thing that's important to note there too as we've set up the year, we're now moving into the part of the year where we're having -- we're setting up ourselves for more consistent operation in both the Delaware and the Eagle Ford,
componenttext: I think, Evan, the other thing that's important to note there too as we've set up the year, we're now moving into the part of the year where we're having -- we're setting up ourselves for more consistent operation in both the Delaware and the Eagle Ford, we're going to have a rig running in both areas now. I think that will help accelerate even some of these learning curve as we go forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a -- do you have a cost that you can share on Calamity Jane? I know that the results are fantastic. I was just curious what the incremental CWCs are there? And then just -- I don't know if it's too early, but your acreage look very contiguous, an
componenttext: Is there a -- do you have a cost that you can share on Calamity Jane? I know that the results are fantastic. I was just curious what the incremental CWCs are there? And then just -- I don't know if it's too early, but your acreage look very contiguous, and that's kind of one of the questions, how much may be amendable to longer lateral when that becomes part of the development program in the future?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we move more pad drilling, you'll definitely see a longer lateral, just like you've seen us do in the Wells Ranch and East Pony. I think on the cost side, that's only the third well, I think, it's probably third, keep using an assumption that we'v
componenttext: Yes, as we move more pad drilling, you'll definitely see a longer lateral, just like you've seen us do in the Wells Ranch and East Pony. I think on the cost side, that's only the third well, I think, it's probably third, keep using an assumption that we've rolled out in the past for these wells, and as we move into more of a development plan, we'll see potentially some cost savings from there. But again, a large part of it depends on what completion design we end up with. I mean, if we end up with 3,000 pounds per foot across the board, then that's going to add several hundred thousand dollars to the completion of each well. So we'll continue to assess and figure out what the most value adding completion design is and as we move into development mode next year, we'll really start to see those cost efficiencies.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: With Leviathan potentially in sanctioned and the interest that you described an expanding activity in the Permian, DJ and Eagle Ford, the potential for higher gas price is to increase interest by your Marcellus partner and increasing drilling activity. Ca
componenttext: With Leviathan potentially in sanctioned and the interest that you described an expanding activity in the Permian, DJ and Eagle Ford, the potential for higher gas price is to increase interest by your Marcellus partner and increasing drilling activity. Can you just talk to your interest level and extent without spending cash flow in 2017? And how you would time the level of activity based on per month and strip oil prices?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as all of us are doing now, we're starting to look at our plans for '17, and there's still probably a lot of volatility as to what kind of commodity price expectations you're looking at. I think when you look at our capital program for '17, o
componenttext: Yes, I think as all of us are doing now, we're starting to look at our plans for '17, and there's still probably a lot of volatility as to what kind of commodity price expectations you're looking at. I think when you look at our capital program for '17, obviously, the capital in the Eastern Med will be driven by the timing of a Leviathan sanction, and as we've talked about, we are well set up and especially now also with some of the sell down of the Tamar interest to be able to fund that from kind of that ring fenced strategy over there. As we look at the U.S., the Eagle Ford's been great returns. The Delaware performance highlights what the returns in that area can be, and the DJ has been strong returns. So then you're looking at in the Marcellus, I think we're still in the mode of continuing to manage the cash flow and working with our partner in that element. What we've said there is as gas price continues to increase, I think that provides more cash to continue to be able to spent in that arena. So I think when you put it all together, Brian, we're really going to have to continue to watch and stay flexible on how we allocate capital based on what our outlook on both oil and gas commodity is. The good part is we have a lot of flexibility because we've got very little what you call nondiscretionary capital next year, I'd say it's all pretty much discretionary.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. And then a follow-up is on the operating cost. You've shown pretty low up cost year on the LOE side for the last few quarters, and I wondered if you could speak to -- if we do go into a higher commodity environment, the sustainability of th
componenttext: Great, thanks. And then a follow-up is on the operating cost. You've shown pretty low up cost year on the LOE side for the last few quarters, and I wondered if you could speak to -- if we do go into a higher commodity environment, the sustainability of these cost declines on the operating side and then if you see room for any further efficiencies?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think a lot of it is sustainable. I think when you think about operating cost, a lot of it's driven by people cost and electricity costs. So those are going to be the 2 moving factors on that. I think what you're seeing, as we continue to get more
componenttext: Well, I think a lot of it is sustainable. I think when you think about operating cost, a lot of it's driven by people cost and electricity costs. So those are going to be the 2 moving factors on that. I think what you're seeing, as we continue to get more and more efficient, the cost will continue to be beneficial going forward. I think you've seen that. Look at what we're doing now, we're handling about 33% of more volume right now at the same LOE and G&A cost that we did prior to that. So I mean, that's pretty much a testament to the ability to continue to manage that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: I'd like to dig a bit deeper on your U.S. oil volumes in Q2. There was a decline of about 6,000 barrels a day from 1Q. I know you've gone into some detail on some of the things in the DJ Basin that contributed to that. But I'm wondering if you could add any other context to what contributed to that sequential drop? And if that's the kind of thing where 2Q is what we should be thinking about the levels in the back half of the year whether there is going to be some rebound on U.S. oil volumes as -- if those issues are more transient.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when oil volumes in reality, they were right in line with what we had expected on that. We had expected in some of the DJ piece to come down a little bit from first to the second quarter just based on the activity levels, quarterly activity l
componenttext: Yes, I think when oil volumes in reality, they were right in line with what we had expected on that. We had expected in some of the DJ piece to come down a little bit from first to the second quarter just based on the activity levels, quarterly activity levels. I think in the Gulf of Mexico, they were down a little bit in the second quarter also from first quarter with some of the downtime that Gary mentioned on some of the onshore facilities. I think when you look at it going forward, it's going to move around some quarter-by-quarter, just from the listings in West Africa. As you know, Charles, we've seen that before, but as far as the outlook on oil volumes, U.S. or total, I mean, it's on track with what we've been expecting. I think when you look at the third quarter too and a little bit in the fourth quarter, you got to not forget that we have to build in a little bit of assumption on some downtime in the Gulf of Mexico for both storms and potentially some of this onshore facility impact. So you have a little bit of that. But you have quarterly, you have a volumes move around a good bit. For example, third quarter West Africa volumes, oil volumes will be under listed. When we look at the projection going forward, we thinking pretty hard look at even at the horizontal volumes in the DJ for example, it's pretty consistent on oil percentage going forward. So that's why I'd say it's attracting pretty well with what we expected.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful detail. And then if I could ask question perhaps to dovetail on those again, really remarkably good results, you had in the Delaware Basin. The thing that stands out of there is the 3,000 pounds of sand a foot, and I know it's a different b
componenttext: That's helpful detail. And then if I could ask question perhaps to dovetail on those again, really remarkably good results, you had in the Delaware Basin. The thing that stands out of there is the 3,000 pounds of sand a foot, and I know it's a different basin from the DJ, but it's just a contrast that there would be recent additions have in the DJ being a thousand pounds a sand a foot, is there more room in the DJ to increase those sand concentrations? Or do you think you can zeroed in on it and it's -- and you're at the right spot that's dictated by just the reservoir conditions and the rock properties?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're picking up on a good theme, Charles. I think whichever the -- whether it's Eagle Ford, whether it's Delaware, whether it's DJ, we're seeing continued performance improvements as we continue to work on optimizing these completions. Then my f
componenttext: I think you're picking up on a good theme, Charles. I think whichever the -- whether it's Eagle Ford, whether it's Delaware, whether it's DJ, we're seeing continued performance improvements as we continue to work on optimizing these completions. Then my feeling, we're not that the end of that game yet. I think Gary will expand on that a little bit. We've actually seen some increase concentration in the DJ and he can talk a little more to how he's thinking about those from each of the different areas.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Charles, I mean, when we talked about enhanced completion in the DJ, we've said 1,000 pounds or more. And the historical designs in the DJ were in the 700, 800-pound per foot range, so 1,000 pounds or more is 50% more to twice as much as historical u
componenttext: Yes, Charles, I mean, when we talked about enhanced completion in the DJ, we've said 1,000 pounds or more. And the historical designs in the DJ were in the 700, 800-pound per foot range, so 1,000 pounds or more is 50% more to twice as much as historical used. I'd tell you that we've tested some that are quite a bit more than 1,000 pounds, more in line with some of the types of designs that we've been using down in Texas. So today's plan, it's a transition that we're making to test some higher proppant loading designs there as well, and certainly, if we see similar uplift there that we've seen in some of the areas in Texas, it can be very encouraging for those volumes going forward.
