headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've seen the benefit of that, when you look at just what we're delivering now versus what we're spending. When we went into the year, we talked about spending $1.5 billion per what, 390,000 barrels equivalent per day for the year. Now we'r
componenttext: Well, I think we've seen the benefit of that, when you look at just what we're delivering now versus what we're spending. When we went into the year, we talked about spending $1.5 billion per what, 390,000 barrels equivalent per day for the year. Now we're spending what looks like, if you just project out what we've laid out for guidance for third and fourth quarter, under $1.5 billion and delivering 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day for the year. So we're seeing that benefit. You're seeing that's allowing us to do a little more, even here in the second half of the year, which shows in some of the activity, both in some of the capital activity, what we talked about, the allocation of 80% of our capital here, this second half here, going into the onshore business or close to that. I don't -- Gary any other thoughts on that efficiency and how it's playing out?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, but I think just similar to my earlier comments, it's very early days in Texas. We are picking up rigs in both places and moving in a development mode more in 2017 in the Delaware especially. So I would expect to see similar cost efficiencies and impr
componenttext: No, but I think just similar to my earlier comments, it's very early days in Texas. We are picking up rigs in both places and moving in a development mode more in 2017 in the Delaware especially. So I would expect to see similar cost efficiencies and improvements in the Delaware over time, similar to what we've seen in the DJ. And it's a bit surprising to me how we continue to still see improvements in the DJ to the magnitude we are. Another 4% just in 1 quarter is a pretty significant number, given how far we've already come. So I think we'll continue to see small gains in the DJ going forward and probably some pretty significant gains in the Delaware as we move to a development mode of operating.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: But those efficiency gains, they're playing out on the cost side but we're seeing it play out us some color serve reference. Just on the resource potential and the performance per well, and that's just adding inventory to us.
componenttext: But those efficiency gains, they're playing out on the cost side but we're seeing it play out us some color serve reference. Just on the resource potential and the performance per well, and that's just adding inventory to us.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you all have highlighted that development in the southern Delaware in 2017. What do you envision that looks like? Is it pad drilling, how many wells did you set on a pad? What Bones [ph] do you figure you're going to target in? Would that be more than
componenttext: And you all have highlighted that development in the southern Delaware in 2017. What do you envision that looks like? Is it pad drilling, how many wells did you set on a pad? What Bones [ph] do you figure you're going to target in? Would that be more than 1 rig would that say be maybe 2 or possibly 3 rigs?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it can definitely be more than 1 rig. We're still working through plans for 2017 budget right now. But I think when you think, whether it's '17 or '18, kind of near to medium term for the Delaware Basin, you need to think about very similar to what w
componenttext: Yes, it can definitely be more than 1 rig. We're still working through plans for 2017 budget right now. But I think when you think, whether it's '17 or '18, kind of near to medium term for the Delaware Basin, you need to think about very similar to what we've done in the DJ and Wells Ranch and East Pony, where we start building centralized infrastructure where we can take advantage of those scale and efficiencies. We start building or drilling more multi-well pads, longer laterals, and we see a lot of those same efficiency show up in the Delaware that we've seen in the DJ Basin. So we'll continue to work the budget here for the next few month and talk about that when it's the right time. But I think, we'll certainly see more activity in the Delaware next year than we've seen this year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll hear from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And now we'll hear from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David Hernandez filling in for Ryan Todd. Just first a question on the asset sales front, just if you could remind us what the update is on the Tamar divestiture and kind of like the time line associated with that. And any thoughts around the pote
componenttext: This is David Hernandez filling in for Ryan Todd. Just first a question on the asset sales front, just if you could remind us what the update is on the Tamar divestiture and kind of like the time line associated with that. And any thoughts around the potential IPO of the Midstream assets? And as a follow-on, I guess, not as a follow-on, but as a follow-up question, any insider color around the performance that the Mustang IBP enhance completion would be? Appreciated.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me start on Tamar. We put the announcement out on Tamar, where we reached agreement to sell 3%. And I think that's a -- it sets a great marker, it's a good marker for the asset. I think as far as the timing, I would expect timing of that to clos
componenttext: Okay, let me start on Tamar. We put the announcement out on Tamar, where we reached agreement to sell 3%. And I think that's a -- it sets a great marker, it's a good marker for the asset. I think as far as the timing, I would expect timing of that to close by the fourth quarter. So definitely before year-end, and we'll just -- we'll obviously announce that as it happens. I think on the midstream IPO, that will be -- we've kept the S1 alive, so we've kept that available to enter the market when the market conditions kind of dictate that. So that's all about I'm saying at this point, but that's something we're keeping alive. I think at Mustang, that's an area probably our next IDP area. Gary can mention a little bit on that. But I think just initial results are very encouraging there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave. I think very happy with the first results. It's, like we said, a 10-well pad, 7 of which tested enhanced completions. It's one part of the IDP. Obviously, with it only being 1 pad. So we're very, very encouraged of what we've seen so far. It's
componenttext: Yes, Dave. I think very happy with the first results. It's, like we said, a 10-well pad, 7 of which tested enhanced completions. It's one part of the IDP. Obviously, with it only being 1 pad. So we're very, very encouraged of what we've seen so far. It's only coming on right at the end of 2Q, so a bit early to start putting numbers up there. But I think when you look at how much the enhance completions have improved, the performance of the wells and Wells Ranch, East Pony, and again that's on one of the slides in the pack, and you can see how much uplift we're getting from that, you can see why we're excited from similar well improvement in Mustang, which is the first pad there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll take a question from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And now we'll take a question from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perhaps, Gary, I was wondering if you could maybe help us understand a little bit about some of the trends, production trends, you're seeing in the DJ Basin? I guess, I was wondering, you had the turnaround in Q2 plus some unplanned downtime, but you did
componenttext: Perhaps, Gary, I was wondering if you could maybe help us understand a little bit about some of the trends, production trends, you're seeing in the DJ Basin? I guess, I was wondering, you had the turnaround in Q2 plus some unplanned downtime, but you did indicate that you have less workover activity for verticals. So I was wondering if you could help us think about how the DJ may progress on a sequential basis for the balance of the year?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we've said for quite some time that in the DJ Basin, it takes 3 to 4 rigs to keep production flat. We've been running 2, obviously, for a while now. Balancing part of that is clearly the fact that we've seen better results from these enhanced
componenttext: Yes, I think we've said for quite some time that in the DJ Basin, it takes 3 to 4 rigs to keep production flat. We've been running 2, obviously, for a while now. Balancing part of that is clearly the fact that we've seen better results from these enhanced completions. I think in 2Q, you have the issues that you mentioned, the turnaround at the Wells Ranch central processing facility as well as some third-party gas plant downtime that impacted volumes. As we mentioned and you reiterated there, we've also held back on some workovers and repairs, especially on the vertical wells that just don't make sense in this price environment, so those have impacted vertical volumes. I think when you look at our level of activity going forward, with the type of performance we're seeing on these enhanced completions, even with 2 rigs, we're probably flat on horizontal production through the end of the year. Vertical will decline a bit. So overall, you'll be declining through the end of the year, as we've kind of suggested in the past. But horizontal program is holding in there quite nicely with just 2 rigs.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think to that point, Arun, and it's worth emphasizing and Gary mentioned it is we're actually on the horizontal program doing as well or better with the amount of capital that we're spending than we would have laid out before. What's masking it a little
componenttext: I think to that point, Arun, and it's worth emphasizing and Gary mentioned it is we're actually on the horizontal program doing as well or better with the amount of capital that we're spending than we would have laid out before. What's masking it a little bit is some of these decisions which are the right economic decisions, and the fact that everybody is looking at everything as a business decision on some of these vertical wells. And some of that production can be brought back at a later time in the right price environment, but now is not the right price environment to be trying to maximize the vertical production up there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a ton of sense. Thanks for clarifying that. And just, Gary, one of your peers have highlighted in pretty close proximity to you guys, some optimism about the Third Bone Spring interval in the southern Delaware. Any plans to test that over the n
componenttext: That makes a ton of sense. Thanks for clarifying that. And just, Gary, one of your peers have highlighted in pretty close proximity to you guys, some optimism about the Third Bone Spring interval in the southern Delaware. Any plans to test that over the next, call it, 6 to 12 months?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got plans to test it. We've got 1 Third Bone Spring well that we'll spud around the end of this year. We won't have any completions on this year, but we will spud 1 before the end of the year. With everything we've seen from offset operators, our ow
componenttext: We've got plans to test it. We've got 1 Third Bone Spring well that we'll spud around the end of this year. We won't have any completions on this year, but we will spud 1 before the end of the year. With everything we've seen from offset operators, our own mapping, we believe that majority of our acreage we will consider probably Tier 1 perspective for the Third Bone Spring.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll hear from Irene Haas with Wunderlich.
componenttext: And now we'll hear from Irene Haas with Wunderlich.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So congratulations with all the good work you've done in Texas, and specific, I'm curious as to, on Wolfcamp A, how many of zones have you decided to tackle? Would you consider Wolfcamp B? And importantly, at which point, how much time would we need to re
componenttext: So congratulations with all the good work you've done in Texas, and specific, I'm curious as to, on Wolfcamp A, how many of zones have you decided to tackle? Would you consider Wolfcamp B? And importantly, at which point, how much time would we need to really get some clarity on intervals spacing and sort of completion design to -- for you to sort of update your drilling inventory in the Delaware Basin?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, everything we've done so far is Wolfcamp A and really the upper part of the Wolfcamp A. As we get into the latter part of this year, as I mentioned, we'll test the Bone Spring, we'll test the lower Wolfcamp -- or we'll spud the lower Wolfcam
componenttext: Yes, I think, everything we've done so far is Wolfcamp A and really the upper part of the Wolfcamp A. As we get into the latter part of this year, as I mentioned, we'll test the Bone Spring, we'll test the lower Wolfcamp -- or we'll spud the lower Wolfcamp A, probably it won't be on this year. So we'll continue to delineate through that vertical section. I think it's probably a bit early to zero in too much on how many wells or what spacing we think we'll ultimately end up in that pad given that we've only brought our Third Noble operated well on so far. I think it's a pretty wide range we're looking at right now when you consider all the way from the Third Bone Spring through the Upper A to Lower A and maybe even into the B. Could be as many as 15 to 25 wells, I know it's a wide range, but give us a bit more time to 3 completions and we'll narrow that going forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 1 follow-up question. How much money did you say from using slickwater versus high grade in Delaware Basin?
componenttext: I have 1 follow-up question. How much money did you say from using slickwater versus high grade in Delaware Basin?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Delaware Basin, I don't know its exact number, Irene. I mean what we've seen in the DJ Basin with those fracs is it's $300,000 to $400,000 savings from slickwater. It's probably on the same order of magnitude in the Delaware.
componenttext: The Delaware Basin, I don't know its exact number, Irene. I mean what we've seen in the DJ Basin with those fracs is it's $300,000 to $400,000 savings from slickwater. It's probably on the same order of magnitude in the Delaware.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: I think Gary touched on it. We just need to get more wells on production. We need to get more time in the history on the wells we have on production. Som eare extended production period, not only ours but even the offset operators, even some of the more recent wells out there that have been highly encouraging. We're not going to rush to revise the type curve and then have to rush to revise it again. We'll get a little longer extended production period both for ours and offset operators and watch them both and then get some more wells online.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: I guess, [indiscernible] my question -- Okay, go ahead, Gary [indiscernible].

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what's encouraging for me, Doug, is even though it's only 3 wells, it's 3 wells that are spaced across the acreage and all are above the type curve, which is obviously intended to be an average of the acreage. So I think, we'll continue to see imp
componenttext: I think what's encouraging for me, Doug, is even though it's only 3 wells, it's 3 wells that are spaced across the acreage and all are above the type curve, which is obviously intended to be an average of the acreage. So I think, we'll continue to see improvement in the completion designs there, and since we have a few more than 300 under our belt, we can talk about what that 700 goes to.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I realize it's very early days. I guess what was at the back of my mind was when you think about incremental rig adds, obviously, the type of economics that you currently have as your current well, if you like, has a very different implications as to wher
componenttext: I realize it's very early days. I guess what was at the back of my mind was when you think about incremental rig adds, obviously, the type of economics that you currently have as your current well, if you like, has a very different implications as to where you had in the Delaware versus the Eagle Ford. That's actually what I was kind of getting at.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, and to the same extent, we're looking at that same opportunity in both where they're both well outperforming the type curves. So we have to take that into account as we look at setting our plans for next year.
componenttext: Right, and to the same extent, we're looking at that same opportunity in both where they're both well outperforming the type curves. So we have to take that into account as we look at setting our plans for next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in the Delaware, when you look at that well in the Delaware, that's 75% above the type curve in the early days, obviously, huge impact on the economics of that. But as Dave point out, we're seeing very nice improvement in the economics in the Eagle F
componenttext: Yes, in the Delaware, when you look at that well in the Delaware, that's 75% above the type curve in the early days, obviously, huge impact on the economics of that. But as Dave point out, we're seeing very nice improvement in the economics in the Eagle Ford too which were already very robust. And when you look at the 500-foot space 12 that are in line or above with 3 million barrel type curve that was based on the spacing twice as wide as that, when you look at Northern Gates Ranch where we're above a 3 million barrel type curve, which is 3x what we have assumed when we did the acquisition, and when you look at Briscoe Ranch where we're significantly above the type curve that we assumed [indiscernible] the acquisition and we haven't even brought those enhanced style completions to all the areas yet, I think there's tremendous upside potential in both of these areas that will be very economic even in this price environment.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, my follow-up is maybe a little bit of a standard question nowadays, but with the signature deadline comping up in the 8th of August, I'm just wondering if you could share your latest thoughts on the Colorado setback drill, and I'll leave it there.
componenttext: Dave, my follow-up is maybe a little bit of a standard question nowadays, but with the signature deadline comping up in the 8th of August, I'm just wondering if you could share your latest thoughts on the Colorado setback drill, and I'll leave it there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I think I'm extremely glad that we put the work in that we have over the last couple of years. I think we're doing the things we need to do and I'm comfortable we're doing the right things to stay out in front of this. We've stayed focused on,
componenttext: Well, yes, I think I'm extremely glad that we put the work in that we have over the last couple of years. I think we're doing the things we need to do and I'm comfortable we're doing the right things to stay out in front of this. We've stayed focused on, engaged on, being out in front them defeating any potential ballots if they get enough signatures, and we'll wait and see how that plays out. But either way, we're staying out in front of this. The nice part is we build a strong coalition and a business community out there. You've got land owners, farmers, homebuilders that all are affected by this and greatly affected at some point that went through. So they're out in front of this also and working hard on this. I think the government's been supportive of what we're doing, and very engaged in this effort. So the other part of it is the public education has worked. I mean, you've seen that from the polling, you've seen that from the results, the increase support awareness and understanding, so again I'll go back to where I started with we're doing the right things and we're in the right position to stay in front of this.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: In the Delaware, can you comment more on what forthcoming drilling completions activity will be focused on this year? You mentioned the Wolfcamp zones and the Third Bone, is that the primary focus or could we expect some sort of delineation as well?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, as I said, it will be -- we'll kind of drill a Third Bone spring and probably a lower Wolfcamp A later this year. Half dozen or so, additional completions that will bring on production this year, I think are all Wolfcamp A upper, and as far as
componenttext: No, I mean, as I said, it will be -- we'll kind of drill a Third Bone spring and probably a lower Wolfcamp A later this year. Half dozen or so, additional completions that will bring on production this year, I think are all Wolfcamp A upper, and as far as aerial all testing, they're all probably in that east central part of the acreage block for the rest of the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: Great, thanks. And then one on guidance, just going back to the ongoing outperformance across the U.S. early onshore. Anything baked in on that front at this point? Or is it all still based on existing curves, the 700 in Delaware and so forth? And similarly, regarding Israel, is there being factored in for the potential for continued coal to gas switching, and again, just for this fact of kind of full year updated Q3 guidance numbers here.

componenttext: Yes, I'd say, for both of those, we've baked in some of what we're seeing, But given the early days on both of those, we've probably been a bit conservative in the guidance.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is a little bit macro related and trying to better understand how you circle in on your budget for next year, and maybe specifically if you look at the strip, what do you plan on spending that cash flow or above or below? How should we think a
componenttext: My question is a little bit macro related and trying to better understand how you circle in on your budget for next year, and maybe specifically if you look at the strip, what do you plan on spending that cash flow or above or below? How should we think about your process there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as I mentioned earlier, we're working through that process now, and obviously, you've seen a lot of volatility on the pricing still see even 2017 outlook for prices continue to change. But we'll -- the benefit we have is we've generated exce
componenttext: Well, I think as I mentioned earlier, we're working through that process now, and obviously, you've seen a lot of volatility on the pricing still see even 2017 outlook for prices continue to change. But we'll -- the benefit we have is we've generated excess cash this year. And as we look at that and as we look to next year, we'll look at our cash flow projection and what other opportunities we have to support cash flow next year on various things. So we'll look at the whole picture things and setting the budget and focus our capital activity on what we need to do to support the Leviathan development based on wherever it is, and most of the rest of it will start with our onshore activity and how we allocate between the different plays based on the things we've talked about this morning.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

componenttext: And next, we'll move to Gail Nicholson with KLR Group.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the presentation, you talked about how the larger [indiscernible] the DJ leads to longer cycle time [indiscernible] I was wondering if you could qualify that versus old standard completion versus the new enhanced completion?
componenttext: In the presentation, you talked about how the larger [indiscernible] the DJ leads to longer cycle time [indiscernible] I was wondering if you could qualify that versus old standard completion versus the new enhanced completion?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It all depends, Gail, on how long the laterals are, how many wells there are in the pad, so it's hard to give you kind of an average number. What I will say, it did push some completions from 2Q into 3Q. We're addressing some of that by bringing a third f
componenttext: It all depends, Gail, on how long the laterals are, how many wells there are in the pad, so it's hard to give you kind of an average number. What I will say, it did push some completions from 2Q into 3Q. We're addressing some of that by bringing a third frac crew out to help bring some more wells on before we get to year end. But it's going to vary quite a bit based on how long the laterals are and how many wells there are in the pad. It goes to really more how many stages are what the cluster spacing is, to save spacing is on those probably even more than the sand concentration.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then you also mentioned, as you progress the year, potential debt reduction as you get towards year end. When we look at that debt reduction, is there an internal target of absolute or is it more kind of a level net debt-to-EBITDA that yo
componenttext: Okay, great. And then you also mentioned, as you progress the year, potential debt reduction as you get towards year end. When we look at that debt reduction, is there an internal target of absolute or is it more kind of a level net debt-to-EBITDA that you would like to be at? And then is there any talks about taking the cash flow generated and returning it back to shareholders potential increase in the dividend?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you look at the debt, we look at a number different of factors, and we haven't set a specific number. The nice part about that is with how we've continued to build liquidity somewhat this year, it doesn't become an either/or discussion
componenttext: Well, I think when you look at the debt, we look at a number different of factors, and we haven't set a specific number. The nice part about that is with how we've continued to build liquidity somewhat this year, it doesn't become an either/or discussion from debt investment in the business. I think we'll have the abilities to pay down some debt by the end of the year, and at the same time, reduce our capacity and maintain our capacity to be opportunistic, whether for accelerating opportunities in the portfolio as the environment dictates or other new opportunities. So the nice part about it is we've maintained the capacity to look at all those spectrums.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've time for one more question, that will come from Jon Wolff with Jefferies.
componenttext: We've time for one more question, that will come from Jon Wolff with Jefferies.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question around Delaware. The area you're in is obviously sizzling hot. I guess, you're moving kind of as fast as you can practically. But you spend a lot of time thinking about the potential for missed opportunities around acreage grab given the level
componenttext: A question around Delaware. The area you're in is obviously sizzling hot. I guess, you're moving kind of as fast as you can practically. But you spend a lot of time thinking about the potential for missed opportunities around acreage grab given the level of activity there, and if understanding that the DJ is better now, is there a way to go faster in the Delaware, is that even a choice, or is it constrained by something?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've been following the plan we laid out for the year as we continued to learn, we continue to adjust, especially as we're looking into next year. But as Gary said, the performance has been better than we would have even expected, and the n
componenttext: Well, I think we've been following the plan we laid out for the year as we continued to learn, we continue to adjust, especially as we're looking into next year. But as Gary said, the performance has been better than we would have even expected, and the nice part about it, it's been across the spectrum of the acreage. I think when you look at other opportunities, yes, we're looking at the other opportunities. If the right opportunities for the right price comes around, we'll move on it. But in the meantime, we've got 1,200 locations on our position that we're focused on now. And to your point, to the extent and how we manage that and how we set up that program is important. As Gary mentioned, we've got to model this a little bit after some of the DJ portion where we knew IDP concept we put the facility then, and we make sure we're optimizing the value, not just the value for this year, but the value for the whole play.

componenttext: No, I think on the 3 projects, to your point, we brought on 3 major projects over in the last year, on time, performance has been as expected or better, and on cost. So again, that's a testament to our major project execution that's showing up here very visibly in the Gulf of Mexico over the last year. I think as we look forward here, I would expect some decline now that we've had Dantzler and Big Bend on for about a year, it's in line with what we've said originally. Gunflint, we'll see to what extent it ramps up after we get it ramped up. And as I mentioned before, we've built in some downtime expectations from some of that onshore facility coming back online or some of it's downtime and some storm downtime here near term. So everything's performing as expected out there, at least as well as expected.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jake. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today.This morning, I hope you've had a chance to review our second quarter 2016 operational and financial news release as well as the supplemental slides for this event, which highlight
componenttext:
Thanks, Jake. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today.
This morning, I hope you've had a chance to review our second quarter 2016 operational and financial news release as well as the supplemental slides for this event, which highlight a very strong quarter for Noble Energy and an enhanced outlook for the remainder of the year. Both items are posted to our website, and you will find them helpful as we talk through our prepared comments. In addition, we anticipate filing our 10-Q with the SEC later this morning. 
Following prepared comments from Dave Stover, Chairman, President and CEO; and Gary Willingham, EVP of Operations, we'll open the event for a Q&A session. [Operator Instructions] Additional management members available for Q&A are Ken Fisher, EVP and CFO; Susan Cunningham, EVP, Exploration and New Ventures; and Keith Elliott, SVP of our Eastern Med assets.
I want to remind everyone that this event may contain projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
With that, I'll turn the call to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Before diving into the specifics on the quarter, I thought it'd be helpful to take a high-level view of our performance to date in 2016. Entering the year with an uncertain outlook on commodities, our stated focus
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. Before diving into the specifics on the quarter, I thought it'd be helpful to take a high-level view of our performance to date in 2016. Entering the year with an uncertain outlook on commodities, our stated focus was clear: first, operate the business within cash flows; second, continue to improve capital efficiency to enhance returns; and third, increase our flexibility and financial strength by leveraging our portfolio. We're running well ahead of plan for the year and meeting or exceeding all of these identified goals. 
We've delivered another quarter where cash flow exceeded capital expenditures. We raised our full year 2016 volume expectation for a second time this year, providing an additional 10 million barrels of oil equivalent compared to our original expectation. We have accomplished this with less capital than originally planned, an efficiency story that not many in our industry can match. We've also reset our underlying cost structure and continued to strengthen our financial position through a series of portfolio optimization transactions. Each of these accomplishments has improved our long-term outlook and generated significant value. 
In terms of what we control in our business, I can easily say that we are executing as well as I have seen in my 14-year history with Noble. 
Moving into the second quarter results. It was a period of operational records and milestones. To name a few, Noble reported record total company sales volumes, led by our U.S. onshore assets and Israel. Over the last year, we've realized a daily volume increase of nearly 130,000 barrels of oil equivalent, while absolute lease operating expense and G&A combined were actually down period-over-period. As part of the volume increase, 31,000 barrels per day were oil and 32,000 barrels per day were NGLs. 
Focusing onshore. In Texas, we brought online our best Delaware Basin well yet, along with several great Eagle Ford wells, extending our successes in these assets since we acquired them a year ago. In the DJ Basin, we enhanced our asset position through a strategic acreage exchange, adding additional depth of high-quality inventory in our core Wells Ranch IDP area. And in the Marcellus, wells continue to outperform expectation, enhancing resource recovery in this leading gas position. 
This operational momentum has continued offshore. Recent highlights include: in the Gulf of Mexico, we commenced production at Gunflint on time and under budget; in Equatorial Guinea, the Alba compression project has also started up; and in Israel, at the beginning of July, we entered into an agreement for an initial 3% divestiture of our world-class Tamar asset, establishing a gross valuation benchmark of $12.3 billion. Second quarter volumes totaled 427,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, an increase of 43% versus the second quarter of last year or 18% on a pro forma basis. 
Performance for each business unit in commodity was ahead of expectations. This illustrates the benefits of our portfolio and industry-leading execution, continuing to drive differential value among our peer group. 
With respect to costs, results were within or below our expectation on essentially every metric. Capital was below the low end of guidance, driven by efficiency gains and the shifting of some onshore wells into the second half of the year. Unit lease operating expense stood out, down 30% from the second quarter of last year. LOE per barrel equivalent benefited from record total production and deferred workover activity. 
I cannot overemphasize the strong performance of our Texas assets, where completion optimization and a busy quarter of activity drove substantial growth. Our third Noble-designed Delaware Basin completion is showing robust productivity and a higher oil mix. Gary will share more on this well and our plans for the Delaware in a minute. 
Everyone seems curious how we and others are thinking about capital allocation for the remainder of the year and into 2017. Our capital allocation discussion never stops. It's a continual process focused on delivering the best value and returns. The forward curve on oil has declined versus where it was the time of our last earnings call, and 2017 remains notably below the $50 level. The recent trend reflects resilient global supply and high inventories. The outlook on gas appears to have improved slightly for 2017, yet it softens quickly in the following years. Significant volatility in both commodities remains. We've not yet seen market fundamentals reach a point where we would consider changing our capital plans for the year. At the same time, our execution and operating performance has increased our inventory and resource potential for when the environment is appropriate to accelerate. But while total capital for the year remains under $1.5 billion, it has shifted slightly more toward the U.S. onshore unconventional liquid plays, where we have been able to exceed our production goals with fewer completions. Adding to our flexibility is the expectation that we will now exit this year with about 140 operated drilled and completed wells. This represents a decrease of just 10% from the beginning of the year, a higher inventory -- higher inventory than previously expected. 
As we look forward, our capital will be prioritized on accelerating our Delaware Basin position, developing our DJ and Eagle Ford positions and, post sanction, implementing our first phase of Leviathan. Our other offshore assets will provide necessary cash to support these activities. The Marcellus program will be driven by the gas price outlook. 
With an improved liquidity profile following our asset sale proceeds, we're positioned to begin paying down debt by the end of the year, which will continue to lower Noble's underlying cost structure and further strengthen our balance sheet. Sufficient liquidity will be maintained to allow us to increase activity when it makes sense. 
We have executed as well as anyone during the volatility over the last 2 years. I am confident that our focused and disciplined strategy is the right approach in this environment. 
Let me now hand the call over to Gary to walk through our excellent operating performance.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. As Dave mentioned, high levels of operating momentum continued in the second quarter, particularly in the U.S. onshore business. Operating and capital costs have been further reduced, and production from new wells is ou
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning, everyone. As Dave mentioned, high levels of operating momentum continued in the second quarter, particularly in the U.S. onshore business. Operating and capital costs have been further reduced, and production from new wells is outperforming historical type curves in every one of our business units. 
I want to start off this quarter in Texas, where improvements we've made in both areas in a relatively short period of time highlight the quality of our acreage and the value that Noble Energy can deliver. I'll start on the Delaware with the Calamity Jane 2101H well. To say this is an exciting well is an understatement, especially when you consider it's only our third completion in the basin. You can see on Slide 5 the location of the well versus the first 2 Noble completions. The 2101H well is nearly 5,000 feet in lateral length and was completed with 3,000 pounds of proppant per lateral foot and slickwater fluid. In absolute terms, we have a 2,500 barrel of oil equivalent per day well, with 1,450 barrels of oil, 560 barrels of natural gas liquids and over 3 million cubic feet of gas per day. The chart shows the production compared to our prior 2 wells in the type curve. The first 2 wells continue to widen versus the 700,000 barrel equivalent type curve, and this latest well is even better. Versus type curve, this most recent well is more than 75% higher. 
From recent industry M&A activity, it's clear that the value of the Delaware Basin acreage continues to increase. Two recent transactions, specifically in and around our acreage, reaffirmed to me that we have a very enviable 45,000-acre position in the basin. Being early into the play obviously generated a tremendous amount of value. 
We'll have a rig operating in the Delaware almost continuously through the remainder of the year, with several new drills and wells coming on production. Long-term development planning is underway, and our focus will be on delivering substantial well cost efficiencies by utilizing multi-well pad design and longer laterals, and we will also delineate multiple Wolfcamp zones in the Third Bone Spring across our acreage. In addition, we are working to design centralized infrastructure, which will support our long-term plans. 
We also announced extremely strong results in the Eagle Ford this morning, specifically in the Gates Ranch area. Slightly more than half of the announced wells had 500-foot lateral spacing, with the remainder completed at 1,000-foot lateral spacing or more. And I want to emphasize a couple of takeaways from these results, which are shown on Slide 6. First, results continue to demonstrate the benefits of higher-intensity fracs, specifically more proppant with tighter cluster and stage spacing. A great example of this is the 2 wells which commenced production in the North Gates Ranch area during the quarter. These wells are performing above the 3 million barrel equivalent type curve that we used for Southern Gates Ranch or 3x our prior assumption for North Gates Ranch. This follows similar significantly improved results in Briscoe Ranch, which we talked about last quarter. Second, we are gathering additional production history on lateral spacing, which will increase our drilling inventory going forward. With a 500-foot space well performing in line with the 3 million barrel equivalent type curve, we believe the South Gates Ranch area will support at least 750-foot spacing as we move into drilling and completing the fourth row of South Gates Ranch during 2017. 
In addition to our Delaware rig activity, we have a rig coming into the Eagle Ford for the remainder of the year and have ongoing completion activity as well. Our Eagle Ford volumes will be lower in the third quarter, reflecting shut-in impacts for offsetting frac activity. Several new wells are expected to come online toward the end of the third quarter, giving us strong momentum exiting the year and into 2017.  This will include wells in the Briscoe Ranch area, one of which will be an Upper Eagle Ford test. 
Moving to the DJ Basin. The dominant theme continues to be transformative capital efficiencies from drill time reductions and cost savings as well as performance improvements from enhanced completions. As we indicated on the first quarter call, our central processing facility underwent its first planned turnaround since starting up 3 years ago. As a result, the only wells which were brought online during the quarter were in May or June and, thus, did not have a full quarter impact. The basin also experienced unplanned third-party facility downtime during the quarter. 
Once again, we've reduced normalized extended-reach lateral well costs. We are now down to $2.6 million in Wells Ranch, which represents a sequential quarterly decrease of another 4%. This includes the cost efficiency of the monobore drilling, which accounted for nearly all of our drilling activity during the second quarter, as well as the increased cost of higher sand concentrations and higher stages. 
On the completion design front, the change to slickwater fluid as well as increasing proppant loading continues. And I'll turn your attention to Slide 8, which provides more details. Cumulative production charts on the right show the actual averages for these new completion designs, with 1,000 pounds of proppant or more compared to the historical type curve. As you can see, performance in Wells Ranch is at least 15% higher than historical type curve, and East Pony has improved by more than 35%. With continued strong performance improvement, I am excited about the potential impact of a higher percentage of these well designs coming online the remainder of the year. 
The new 10-well Moser pad and the Mustang IDP includes our first 7 wells testing enhanced completions outside of Wells Ranch and East Pony. These wells came online at the end of the quarter and are significantly outperforming expectations, which speaks very positively for the future potential of our Mustang IDP development. 
During the quarter, we continued to optimize our large DJ Basin acreage position. We completed the first closing of the previously announced sale of approximately 33,000 net acres from our Greeley Crescent area. This acreage was not in our development plans for many years. We received $486 million in proceeds, with the remaining $19 million expected around the end of the year. In addition, we completed a strategic acreage trade with PDC Energy, which expands our Wells Ranch position by approximately 20% and provides substantial operating synergies and cost efficiencies for both companies. Both transactions are consistent with our strategy to focus on areas with higher oil content, where we have more contiguous acreage that can drive efficiency gains through long lateral development and existing infrastructure. 
As part of our focus on improving total value in the DJ Basin, we have been deferring workovers and repairs, especially for legacy vertical wells, when those expenditures just don't make sense in this price environment. As a result of these economic choices, vertical production is expected to be impacted by up to 5,000 barrels equivalent per day during the second half of 2016. 
Moving on to the Marcellus. Production remains above expectations despite the limited capital spend. In addition, the JV continues to benefit from shared infrastructure to optimize recycling of produced water, significantly reducing our operating expenses. Recent pads in both the wet and dry gas areas continue to highlight the prolific nature of our position in the play, as depicted on Slide 9. We remain aligned with our partner to operate the JV within cash flow in 2016, and we'll continue to be flexible with activities for the remainder of the year. 
At current commodity prices, we expect 6 additional wells to be completed between now and year-end. The continued outstanding performance of the Marcellus wells has driven the growth seen by CONE, the midstream gathering company partially owned by Noble. 
Offshore in the Gulf of Mexico. We continued to see strong production for the Big Bend and Dantzler fields during the quarter. This is despite a temporary shut-in of the Thunder Hawk facility in late June due to issues with their downstream third-party gas processing plant. In July, we brought online our Gunflint development on time and under budget. This is the third Middle Miocene tieback to commence production in the last 12 months, contributing to the almost doubling of our Gulf of Mexico volumes this year.  The net amount from Gunflint to Noble Energy is expected to be at least 5,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, with potential for additional volumes dependent upon available capacity at the third-party host facility. The 2 wells are currently ramping up as expected. 
Sales volumes in West Africa were up from the first quarter, which had downtime from the installation of the new Alba B3 compression platform. Startup of this Marathon-operated project, which will enhance full field recovery, occurred in July. While Noble's quarterly sales volumes will fluctuate a bit quarter to quarter based on the lifting schedule, we would expect total West Africa production to remain relatively level for the remainder of the year. 
Our Gulf of Mexico and West Africa assets don't often get the attention from the equity markets they deserve. The company's major project execution capabilities were highlighted again recently with the success of the Gunflint and Alba, and these capabilities continue to deliver substantial value for Noble Energy. Looking forward, near-term capital needs in both are relatively low, and the assets remain significant cash flow generators. 
In Israel, natural gas volumes from Tamar were up nearly 30% from the same period last year and even higher than the first quarter of this year. The Israeli government has mandated the reduction of coal-fired power generation by 15% year-over-year, as shown on Slide 11. This reflects the government's recognition of the economic and environmental benefits of natural gas and their confidence in the timing of the Leviathan development. This new underlying  baseload demand is showing up in big numbers, particularly in the shoulder periods, when additional quantities of gas have historically been available. As a result, coal power dispatch during the second quarter was down over 20% versus the second quarter of last year. We are now into the high-demand third quarter period, when Israel will need even more gas. 
We've also announced plans to commence drilling another well at Tamar later this year, which will reinforce reliability and help meet peak demand going forward. At Leviathan, we are continuing to target a final investment decision around year-end. We've now contracted up to 100 million cubic feet per day of natural gas to Israeli customers and continue to advance negotiations with additional domestic and regional customers. The regulatory progress we have seen over the last quarter is also significant, including the government approval of the fixed platform Plan of Development. FEED work is underway, and early indications are that this continues to be a great opportunity to lock in very competitive cost for this long-life resource project. Over the coming months, we expect to finalize remaining key milestones for sanction. This includes additional sales contracts, both in Israel and for the export market, and financing plans as well as completion of the engineering work and project cost estimates. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. We've provided a full update of our 2016 guidance on Slide 14. As I mentioned earlier, we've now raised full year sales volumes to 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up more than 7% from our original guidance on a divestment-adjusted
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. We've provided a full update of our 2016 guidance on Slide 14. As I mentioned earlier, we've now raised full year sales volumes to 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up more than 7% from our original guidance on a divestment-adjusted basis, while reducing our original full year capital expenditure guidance. Not many companies will grow production at that rate while enhancing their financial position and without diluting shareholders. This is a testament to our high-quality portfolio and the underlying execution in our business delivered by our talented and dedicated workforce. 
For the third quarter, capital is expected to range between $400 million and $450 million, with 80% going to the U.S. onshore business. Sales volumes are anticipated to range between 405,000 and 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. The primary difference from the second quarter is our Eagle Ford volumes due to well shut-ins for offset completions. 
In our other onshore areas, Marcellus will likely be up in the third quarter, and DJ is expected to be down, reflecting lower vertical production, as Gary mentioned. Offshore volumes should be relatively flat to the second quarter, with Israel up and West Africa lower due to timing of liftings. The third quarter outlook also includes the impact of about 2,000 barrel equivalent per day from the Bowdoin sale in Montana and the initial closing of the Greeley Crescent divestiture. The production impact from asset sales grossed around 8,000 barrels of oil equivalent in the fourth quarter, with the second Greeley Crescent closing and the Tamar sell-down already announced. These asset divestitures accelerate and highlight the value in our portfolio. 
There's a lot to look forward to in the second half of 2016. We have continuous operations ongoing in both the Eagle Ford and the Delaware Basins, including a doubling of new wells in the Delaware compared to the first half of the year. We will also continue to advance the enhanced completion designs in the DJ Basin and leverage our midstream competitive advantage. And in Israel, we expect to see higher utilization of our Tamar asset while, at the same time, progressing Leviathan to a final investment decision. 
When you put it all together, this is a great company with a great future. The high quality and deep inventory of our U.S. onshore portfolio can deliver high return growth for many years. This is complemented by the visible and prolific long-term growth and value potential of the Eastern Med assets. In addition, the Gulf of Mexico and West Africa assets provide meaningful and long-term cash generation. Portfolio, execution and financial capacity, these are our competitive advantages and our strong foundation to build upon. 
At this time, Jake, we'll go ahead and open the call for questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Gary jump into more details, but I'll reiterate your observation first that the performance has been outstanding, whether you're looking at the Delaware Basin or the Eagle Ford. But let me have Gary go ahead and expand on that.
componenttext: I'll let Gary jump into more details, but I'll reiterate your observation first that the performance has been outstanding, whether you're looking at the Delaware Basin or the Eagle Ford. But let me have Gary go ahead and expand on that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, clearly, we've been very happy with the results we've seen after only the first 3 wells. I think for the plans for the rest of the year, lateral length may get a little bit longer for the second half of this year, and then we'll really start
componenttext: Yes. I mean, clearly, we've been very happy with the results we've seen after only the first 3 wells. I think for the plans for the rest of the year, lateral length may get a little bit longer for the second half of this year, and then we'll really start to see longer lateral lengths probably beginning more in '17. We're continuing to test different completion designs, so we're not quite in that full development mode yet that you would expect to see and start to see significant savings on the D&C side. That will probably come more in '17 as we get into full development mode as well. For the rest of this year, we're going to be testing different designs, though. This latest well with 3,000 pounds per foot, we'll actually go back and test some lower sand concentrations on these next couple of wells just as we zero in on what the best value case is. I think for us, we're always trying to look at what's the most value-creating completion that we can design. It's not about IP-30, although clearly, we're very happy with this being our best IP-30 well to date and one of the best we've seen anywhere in the basin. It's certainly not about IP-24, and it's not about EUR over the long term. It's about how much value we can create. So we'll test some smaller sand concentration designs as well as we zero in on that test value, and we'll have another half dozen or so well by the time we get to the end of the year to help inform what our plans are for next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Evan, the other thing that's important to note there, too, as we had set up the year, we're now moving into that part of the year where we're having -- we're setting up ourselves for more consistent operation in both the Delaware and the Eagle Fo
componenttext: I think, Evan, the other thing that's important to note there, too, as we had set up the year, we're now moving into that part of the year where we're having -- we're setting up ourselves for more consistent operation in both the Delaware and the Eagle Ford. We're going to have a rig running in both areas now. I think that will help accelerate even some of this learning curve as we go forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a -- do you have a cost that you can share on Calamity Jane? I know that the results are fantastic. I was curious what the incremental CWCs are there. And just -- I don't know if you would -- it's too early, but your acreage looked very contiguou
componenttext: Is there a -- do you have a cost that you can share on Calamity Jane? I know that the results are fantastic. I was curious what the incremental CWCs are there. And just -- I don't know if you would -- it's too early, but your acreage looked very contiguous, and that's kind of what the question was. How much may be amendable to the longer lateral when that becomes part of the development program in the future?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we move more pad drilling, you'll definitely see longer laterals, just like you've seen us do in the Wells Ranch and East Pony. I think on the cost side, again, it's only the third well. I think it's probably fair to keep using an assumption that
componenttext: Yes, as we move more pad drilling, you'll definitely see longer laterals, just like you've seen us do in the Wells Ranch and East Pony. I think on the cost side, again, it's only the third well. I think it's probably fair to keep using an assumption that we've rolled out in the past for these wells, and as we move into more of a development plan, we'll see potentially some cost savings from there. Again, a large part of it depends on what completion design we end up with. I mean, if we end up with 3,000 pounds per foot across the board, then that's going to add several hundred thousand dollars to the completion of each well. So we'll continue to assess and figure out what the most value-adding completion design is. And as we move into the development mode next year, we'll really start to see those cost efficiencies.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
