headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question on adding the rig in Texas, and you have one in both the southern Delaware as well as the Eagle Ford. How much room have you guys found in your budget due to cost savings and efficiencies? And how much more could there be over the next,
componenttext: I have a question on adding the rig in Texas, and you have one in both the southern Delaware as well as the Eagle Ford. How much room have you guys found in your budget due to cost savings and efficiencies? And how much more could there be over the next, say, 6 to 12 months?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've seen the benefit of that when you look at just what we're delivering now versus what we're spending. When we went into the year, we talked about spending $1.5 billion per, what, 390,000 barrels equivalent per day for the year. Now we'r
componenttext: Well, I think we've seen the benefit of that when you look at just what we're delivering now versus what we're spending. When we went into the year, we talked about spending $1.5 billion per, what, 390,000 barrels equivalent per day for the year. Now we're spending what looks like, if you just project out what we've laid out for guidance for third and fourth quarter, under $1.5 billion and delivering 415,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day for the year. So we're seeing that benefit. You're seeing that's allowing us to do a little more, even here in the second half of the year, which shows in some of the activity, both in some of the capital activity, what we talked about, the allocation of 80% of our capital here -- in the second half here going into the onshore business or close to that. I don't -- Gary, any other thoughts on that efficiency and how it's playing out?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. And I think just similar to my earlier comments, it's very early days in Texas. We are picking up rigs in both places and moving in a development mode more in 2017 in the Delaware, especially. So I would expect to see similar cost efficiencies and imp
componenttext: No. And I think just similar to my earlier comments, it's very early days in Texas. We are picking up rigs in both places and moving in a development mode more in 2017 in the Delaware, especially. So I would expect to see similar cost efficiencies and improvements in the Delaware over time, similar to what we've seen in the DJ. And it's a bit surprising to me how we continue to still see improvements in the DJ to the magnitude we are. Another 4% just in one quarter is a pretty significant number given how far we've already come. So I think we'll continue to see small gains in the DJ going forward and probably some pretty significant gains in the Delaware as we move to that development mode of operating.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: But those efficiency gains, they're playing out on the cost side, but we're seeing it play out, as some of the colors have referenced, just on the resource potential and the performance per well. And that's just adding inventory to us.
componenttext: But those efficiency gains, they're playing out on the cost side, but we're seeing it play out, as some of the colors have referenced, just on the resource potential and the performance per well. And that's just adding inventory to us.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you all have highlighted the development in the southern Delaware in 2017. What do you envision that looks like? Is it pad drilling? How many wells do you set up on a pad? What zones do you figure you're going to target in? Would that be more than one
componenttext: And you all have highlighted the development in the southern Delaware in 2017. What do you envision that looks like? Is it pad drilling? How many wells do you set up on a pad? What zones do you figure you're going to target in? Would that be more than one rig? Would that, say, be maybe 2 or possibly 3 rigs?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it can definitely be more than one rig. We're still working through plans for 2017 budget right now. But I think when you think, whether it's '17 or '18, kind of near to medium term for the Delaware Basin, you need to think about it very simi
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it can definitely be more than one rig. We're still working through plans for 2017 budget right now. But I think when you think, whether it's '17 or '18, kind of near to medium term for the Delaware Basin, you need to think about it very similar to what we've done in the DJ and Wells Ranch and East Pony, where we start building centralized infrastructure, where we can take advantage of those scale and efficiencies. We start building -- or drilling more multi-well pads, longer laterals, and we see a lot of those same efficiencies show up in the Delaware that we've seen in the DJ Basin. So we'll continue to work the budget here for the next few months and talk about that when it's the right time. But I think we'll certainly see more activity in the Delaware next year than we've seen this year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll hear from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And now we'll hear from Ryan Todd with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David Fernandez filling in for Ryan Todd. Just, first, a question on the asset sales front, just if you can remind us what the update is on the Tamar divestiture and kind of like the timeline associated with that. And any thoughts around the poten
componenttext: This is David Fernandez filling in for Ryan Todd. Just, first, a question on the asset sales front, just if you can remind us what the update is on the Tamar divestiture and kind of like the timeline associated with that. And any thoughts around the potential IPO of the midstream assets? And as a follow-on -- I guess not as a follow-on but as a follow-up question, any insight or color around the performance at the Mustang IDP enhanced completions would be appreciated.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, let me start on Tamar. We put the announcement out on Tamar, where we reached agreement to sell 3%. And I think that's a -- it sets a great marker, sets a good marker for the asset. I think as far as the timing, I would expect the timing of that to
componenttext: Okay, let me start on Tamar. We put the announcement out on Tamar, where we reached agreement to sell 3%. And I think that's a -- it sets a great marker, sets a good marker for the asset. I think as far as the timing, I would expect the timing of that to close by the fourth quarter, so definitely before year-end. And we'll just -- we'll obviously announce that as it happens. I think on the midstream IPO, that will be -- we've kept the S-1 alive, so we've kept that available to enter the market when the market conditions kind of dictate that. So that's about all I'll say on that at this point, but that's something we're keeping alive. I think Mustang, that's an area -- probably our next IDP area. Gary can mention a little bit on that. But I think the initial results are very encouraging there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. I think we're very happy with the first results. It's, like we said, a 10-well pad, 7 of which tested enhanced completions. It's one part of the IDP, obviously, with it only being 1 pad. So we're very, very encouraged of what we've seen so far
componenttext: Yes, David. I think we're very happy with the first results. It's, like we said, a 10-well pad, 7 of which tested enhanced completions. It's one part of the IDP, obviously, with it only being 1 pad. So we're very, very encouraged of what we've seen so far. It's only coming on right at the end of 2Q, so a bit early to start putting numbers up there. But I think when you look at how much the enhanced completions have improved, the performance of the wells in Wells Ranch, in East Pony, and again, that's on one of the slides in the pack, and you can see how much uplift we're getting from that, you can see why we're excited from a similar level of improvement in Mustang, which is the first pad there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll take a question from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And now we'll take a question from Arun Jayaram with JPMorgan.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perhaps, Gary, I was wondering if you could maybe help us understand a little bit about some of the trends, production trends you're seeing in the DJ Basin. I guess I was wondering, you had the turnaround in Q2 plus some unplanned downtime, but you did in
componenttext: Perhaps, Gary, I was wondering if you could maybe help us understand a little bit about some of the trends, production trends you're seeing in the DJ Basin. I guess I was wondering, you had the turnaround in Q2 plus some unplanned downtime, but you did indicate that you have less workover activity for verticals. I was wondering if you could help us think about how the DJ may progress on a sequential basis for the balance of the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think we've said for quite some time that in the DJ Basin, it takes 3 to 4 rigs to keep production flat. We've been running 2, obviously, for a while now. The balancing part of that is clearly the fact that we've seen better results from th
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think we've said for quite some time that in the DJ Basin, it takes 3 to 4 rigs to keep production flat. We've been running 2, obviously, for a while now. The balancing part of that is clearly the fact that we've seen better results from these enhanced completions. I think in 2Q, you have the issues that you mentioned, the turnaround at the Wells Ranch central processing facility as well as some third-party gas plant downtime that impacted volumes. As we mentioned and you reiterated there, we've also held back on some workovers and repairs, especially on vertical wells that just don't make sense in this price environment, so those have impacted vertical volumes. I think when you look at our level of activity going forward, with the type of performance we're seeing on these enhanced completions, even with 2 rigs, we're probably flat on horizontal production through the end of the year. Vertical will decline a bit. So overall, you'll be declining through the end of the year, as we've kind of suggested in the past. But the horizontal program is holding in there quite nicely with just 2 rigs.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think to that point, Arun, and it's worth emphasizing and Gary mentioned it, is we're actually, on the horizontal program, doing as well or better with the amount of capital that we're spending than we would have laid out before. What's masking it a lit
componenttext: I think to that point, Arun, and it's worth emphasizing and Gary mentioned it, is we're actually, on the horizontal program, doing as well or better with the amount of capital that we're spending than we would have laid out before. What's masking it a little bit is some of these decisions which are the right economic decisions and the fact that everybody is looking at everything as a business decision on some of these vertical wells. And some of that production can be brought back at a later time in the right price environment, but now is not the right price environment to be trying to maximize the vertical production up there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes a ton of sense. And just, Gary, one of your peers have highlighted, in pretty close proximity to you guys, some optimism about the Third Bone Spring interval in the southern Delaware. Any plans to test that over the next, call it, 6 to 12 month
componenttext: That makes a ton of sense. And just, Gary, one of your peers have highlighted, in pretty close proximity to you guys, some optimism about the Third Bone Spring interval in the southern Delaware. Any plans to test that over the next, call it, 6 to 12 months?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got plans to test it. We've got one Third Bone Spring well that we'll spud around the end of this year. We won't have any completions on this year, but we will spud one before the end of the year. I think with everything we've seen from offset opera
componenttext: We've got plans to test it. We've got one Third Bone Spring well that we'll spud around the end of this year. We won't have any completions on this year, but we will spud one before the end of the year. I think with everything we've seen from offset operators and our own mapping, we believe that the majority of our acreage, we would consider probably Tier 1 perspective for the Third Bone Spring.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll hear from Irene Haas with Wunderlich.
componenttext: And now we'll hear from Irene Haas with Wunderlich.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So congratulations on all the good work you've done in Texas in specific, and I'm curious as to -- on Wolfcamp A, how many zones have you decided to tackle? Would you consider Wolfcamp B? And importantly, at which point -- how much time would we need to r
componenttext: So congratulations on all the good work you've done in Texas in specific, and I'm curious as to -- on Wolfcamp A, how many zones have you decided to tackle? Would you consider Wolfcamp B? And importantly, at which point -- how much time would we need to really get some clarity on interval spacing and sort of completion design to -- for you to sort of update your drilling inventory in the Delaware Basin?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think everything we've done so far is Wolfcamp A and, really, the upper part of the Wolfcamp A. As we get into the latter part of this year, as I mentioned, we'll test the Bone Spring. We'll test a lower Wolfcamp -- or we'll spud a lower Wolfcamp A
componenttext: Yes. I think everything we've done so far is Wolfcamp A and, really, the upper part of the Wolfcamp A. As we get into the latter part of this year, as I mentioned, we'll test the Bone Spring. We'll test a lower Wolfcamp -- or we'll spud a lower Wolfcamp A, probably won't be on this year. So we'll continue to delineate through that vertical section. I think it's probably a bit early to zero in too much on how many wells or what spacing we think we'll ultimately end up at, given that we've only brought our third Noble-operated well on so far. I think it's a pretty wide range we're looking at right now when you consider all the way from the Third Bone Spring through the Upper A to Lower A and maybe even into the B. It could be as many as 15 to 25 wells. I know it's a wide range, but give us a bit more time than 3 completions, and we'll narrow that going forward.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have one follow-up question. How much money did you save from using slickwater versus hybrid in Delaware Basin?
componenttext: I have one follow-up question. How much money did you save from using slickwater versus hybrid in Delaware Basin?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Delaware Basin, I don't know the exact number, Irene. I mean, what we've seen in the DJ Basin with those fracs is it's $300,000 to $400,000 savings from slickwater. It's probably on the same order of magnitude in the Delaware.
componenttext: The Delaware Basin, I don't know the exact number, Irene. I mean, what we've seen in the DJ Basin with those fracs is it's $300,000 to $400,000 savings from slickwater. It's probably on the same order of magnitude in the Delaware.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And now we'll take a question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And now we'll take a question from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I wonder if I could ask you about the type curve trajectory you see in the Delaware Basin. I mean, clearly, it's early days, but when you look at the offset operators, and obviously the myriad of industry data out there, what are you guys looking t
componenttext: David, I wonder if I could ask you about the type curve trajectory you see in the Delaware Basin. I mean, clearly, it's early days, but when you look at the offset operators, and obviously the myriad of industry data out there, what are you guys looking to see before you revisit what is clearly looking increasingly [indiscernible] assumption at this point?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Gary touched on it. We just need to get more wells on production. We need to get more time and history on the wells we have on production. Some were on extended production period, not only ours but even the offset operators and even some of the mo
componenttext: I think Gary touched on it. We just need to get more wells on production. We need to get more time and history on the wells we have on production. Some were on extended production period, not only ours but even the offset operators and even some of the more recent wells there that have been highly encouraging. We're not going to rush to revise the type curve and then have to rush to revise it again. We'll get a little longer extended production period, both for ours and offset operators, watch them both and then get some more wells online.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what's behind my question -- okay, go ahead, Gary. Sorry.
componenttext: I guess what's behind my question -- okay, go ahead, Gary. Sorry.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to say I think what's encouraging for me, Doug, is, again, even though it's only 3 wells, it's 3 wells that are spaced across the acreage. And all are above the type curve, which is obviously intended to be an average of the acreage. So I thin
componenttext: I was going to say I think what's encouraging for me, Doug, is, again, even though it's only 3 wells, it's 3 wells that are spaced across the acreage. And all are above the type curve, which is obviously intended to be an average of the acreage. So I think we'll continue to see improvement in the completion designs there. And since we got a few more than 3 under our belt, we can talk about what that 700,000 goes to.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I realize it's very early days. I guess what was at the back of my mind was when you think about incremental rig adds, obviously, the type curve economics that you currently have as your current well, if you like, has very different implications as to whe
componenttext: I realize it's very early days. I guess what was at the back of my mind was when you think about incremental rig adds, obviously, the type curve economics that you currently have as your current well, if you like, has very different implications as to whether you would add in the Delaware versus the Eagle Ford. That's what I was kind of getting at.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And to the same extent, we're looking at that same opportunity in both, where they're both well outperforming the type curve. So we have to take that into account as we look at setting our plans for next year.
componenttext: Right. And to the same extent, we're looking at that same opportunity in both, where they're both well outperforming the type curve. So we have to take that into account as we look at setting our plans for next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In the Delaware, when you look at a well in the Delaware, that's 75% above the type curve in the early days, obviously huge impact on the economics of that. But as Dave pointed out, we're seeing very nice improvement in the economics in the Eagle For
componenttext: Yes. In the Delaware, when you look at a well in the Delaware, that's 75% above the type curve in the early days, obviously huge impact on the economics of that. But as Dave pointed out, we're seeing very nice improvement in the economics in the Eagle Ford, too, which were already very robust. And when you look at the 500-foot space wells that are in line or above with 3 million barrel type curve that was based on spacing twice as wide as that, when you look at Northern Gates Ranch, where we're above a 3 million barrel type curve, which is 3x what we assumed when we did the acquisition, and when you look at Briscoe Ranch where we're significantly above the type curve that we assumed at the time of the acquisition, and we haven't even brought those enhanced-style completions to all the areas yet, I think there's tremendous upside potential in both of these areas that will be very economic even in this price environment.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice problem to have, fellows. Dave, my follow-up is maybe a little bit of a standard question nowadays. But with the signature deadline coming up on the 8th of August, I'm just wondering if you could share your latest thoughts on the Colorado [indiscerni
componenttext: Nice problem to have, fellows. Dave, my follow-up is maybe a little bit of a standard question nowadays. But with the signature deadline coming up on the 8th of August, I'm just wondering if you could share your latest thoughts on the Colorado [indiscernible]. And I'll leave it there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, I think I'm extremely glad we put the work in that we have over the last couple of years. I think we're doing the things we need to do, and I'm comfortable we're doing the right things to stay out in front of this. We've stayed focused on -- en
componenttext: Well, yes, I think I'm extremely glad we put the work in that we have over the last couple of years. I think we're doing the things we need to do, and I'm comfortable we're doing the right things to stay out in front of this. We've stayed focused on -- engaged on being out in front them, defeating any potential ballots if they get enough signatures, and we'll wait and see how that plays out. But either way, we're staying out in front of this. The nice part is we've built a strong coalition in the business community up there. You've got landowners, farmers, homebuilders that all were affected by this and greatly affected at some point that went through, so they're out in front of this also and working hard on this. I think the government's been supportive of what we're doing and very engaged in this effort. So the other part of it is the public education has worked. I mean, you can see that from the polling. You can see that from the results, their increased support, awareness and understanding. So again, I'll go back to where I started with. We're doing the right things, and we're in the right position to stay in front of this.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Jeoffrey Lambujon with Tudor, Pickering, Holt & Co.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Jeoffrey Lambujon with Tudor, Pickering, Holt & Co.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the Delaware, can you comment more on what forthcoming drilling completions activity will be focused on this year? You mentioned the Wolfcamp zones and the Third Bone. Is that the primary focus? Or can we expect some sort of aerial delineation as well?
componenttext: In the Delaware, can you comment more on what forthcoming drilling completions activity will be focused on this year? You mentioned the Wolfcamp zones and the Third Bone. Is that the primary focus? Or can we expect some sort of aerial delineation as well?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, it'll -- as I said, it will be -- we'll test a -- drill a Third Bone Spring and probably a lower Wolfcamp A later this year. Half a dozen or so additional completions that we'll bring on production this year, I think, are all Wolfcamp A upper.
componenttext: No. I mean, it'll -- as I said, it will be -- we'll test a -- drill a Third Bone Spring and probably a lower Wolfcamp A later this year. Half a dozen or so additional completions that we'll bring on production this year, I think, are all Wolfcamp A upper. And as far as aerial testing, they're all probably in that east to central part of the acreage block for the rest of the year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then one on guidance, just kind of going back to the ongoing outperformance across the U.S. or the onshore. Anything baked in on that front at this point? Or is it all still based on existing curves, the 700,000 in Delaware and so forth? And si
componenttext: Great. And then one on guidance, just kind of going back to the ongoing outperformance across the U.S. or the onshore. Anything baked in on that front at this point? Or is it all still based on existing curves, the 700,000 in Delaware and so forth? And similarly, regarding Israel, is there anything being factored in for the potential for continued coal-to-gas switching? And again, just with respect to the kind of full year and updated Q3 guidance numbers here.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I'd say for both of those, we've baked in some of what we're seeing. But given the early days on both of those, we've probably been a bit conservative in the guidance.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I'd say for both of those, we've baked in some of what we're seeing. But given the early days on both of those, we've probably been a bit conservative in the guidance.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: David Beard with Coker & Palmer has the next question.
componenttext: David Beard with Coker & Palmer has the next question.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is a little bit macro-related and trying to better understand how you circle in on your budget for next year. And maybe specifically, if you look at strip, would you plan on spending at cash flow or above or below? How should we think about yo
componenttext: My question is a little bit macro-related and trying to better understand how you circle in on your budget for next year. And maybe specifically, if you look at strip, would you plan on spending at cash flow or above or below? How should we think about your process there?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as I mentioned earlier, we're working through that process now. And obviously, you're seeing a lot of volatility on the pricing still, and we see even 2017 outlook for prices continue to change. But we'll -- the benefit we have is we've gene
componenttext: Well, I think as I mentioned earlier, we're working through that process now. And obviously, you're seeing a lot of volatility on the pricing still, and we see even 2017 outlook for prices continue to change. But we'll -- the benefit we have is we've generated excess cash this year. And as we look at that and as we look to next year, we'll look at our cash flow projection and what other opportunities we have to support cash flow next year on various things. So we'll look at the whole picture of things in setting the budget and focus our capital activity on what we need to do to support the Leviathan development based on wherever it is, and most of the rest of it will start with our onshore activity and how we allocate between the different plays based on the things we've talked about this morning.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll move to Gail Nicholson with KLR Group.
componenttext: And next, we'll move to Gail Nicholson with KLR Group.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the presentation, you talked about how the larger -- bigger jobs in DJ leads to longer cycle times and clean-up [indiscernible]. I was wondering if you can quantify that versus -- the old standard completion versus the new enhanced completion.
componenttext: In the presentation, you talked about how the larger -- bigger jobs in DJ leads to longer cycle times and clean-up [indiscernible]. I was wondering if you can quantify that versus -- the old standard completion versus the new enhanced completion.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It all depends, Gail, on how long the laterals are and how many wells there are on the pad, so it's hard to give you kind of an average number. What I will say is it did push some completions from 2Q into 3Q. We're addressing some of that by bringing a th
componenttext: It all depends, Gail, on how long the laterals are and how many wells there are on the pad, so it's hard to give you kind of an average number. What I will say is it did push some completions from 2Q into 3Q. We're addressing some of that by bringing a third frac crew out to help bring some more wells on before we get to year-end. But it's going to vary quite a bit based on how long the laterals are and how many wells there are on the pad. It goes to, really, more how many stages or what the cluster spacing is, the stage spacing is on the wells probably even more than the sand concentration.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then you also mentioned, as you progress the year potential debt reduction as you get towards year-end. When you look at that debt reduction, is there an internal target of absolute? Or is it more kind of a level net debt-to-EBITDA that y
componenttext: Okay, great. And then you also mentioned, as you progress the year potential debt reduction as you get towards year-end. When you look at that debt reduction, is there an internal target of absolute? Or is it more kind of a level net debt-to-EBITDA that you would like to be at? And then is there any thoughts about taking the cash flow generated and returning it back to shareholders and a potential increase in the dividend?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you look at the debt piece, we look at a number different of factors, and we haven't set a specific number. The nice part about that is with how we've continued to build liquidity somewhat this year, it doesn't become an either/or discu
componenttext: Well, I think when you look at the debt piece, we look at a number different of factors, and we haven't set a specific number. The nice part about that is with how we've continued to build liquidity somewhat this year, it doesn't become an either/or discussion from debt versus investment in the business. I think we'll have the abilities to pay down some debt by the end of the year and, at the same time, not reduce our capacity and maintain our capacity to be opportunistic, whether for accelerating opportunities in the portfolio as the environment dictates or other new opportunities. So the nice part about it is we've maintained the capacity to look at all those spectrums.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have time for one more question. That will come from Jon Wolff with Jefferies.
componenttext: We have time for one more question. That will come from Jon Wolff with Jefferies.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question around Delaware. The area you're in is obviously sizzling hot. I guess you're moving kind of as fast as you can practically. But you spend a lot of time thinking about the potential for missed opportunities around acreage grab given the level o
componenttext: A question around Delaware. The area you're in is obviously sizzling hot. I guess you're moving kind of as fast as you can practically. But you spend a lot of time thinking about the potential for missed opportunities around acreage grab given the level of activity there. And understanding that the DJ is better now, is there a way to go faster in the Delaware? Is that even a choice? Or is it constrained by something?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we've been following the plan we laid out for the year. As we continue to learn, we'll continue to adjust, especially as we're looking into next year. But as Gary said, the performance has been better than we would have even expected. And th
componenttext: Well, I think we've been following the plan we laid out for the year. As we continue to learn, we'll continue to adjust, especially as we're looking into next year. But as Gary said, the performance has been better than we would have even expected. And the nice part about it is that's been across the spectrum of the acreage. I think when you look at other opportunities -- yes, we're looking at the other opportunities. If the right opportunity for the right price comes around, we'll move on it. But in the meantime, we've got 1,200 locations on our position that we're focused on now. And to your point, to the extent -- and how we manage that and how we set up that program is important. As Gary mentioned, we've got to model this a little bit after some of the DJ portion where we use an IDP concept we put the facilities in, and we make sure we're optimizing the value, not just the value for this year but the value for the whole play.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I guess to add on to that, do you feel like you're at any disadvantage in terms of knowledge? Are you capable of bidding on adjacent acreage? Do you have the knowledge base as yet?
componenttext: Great. I guess to add on to that, do you feel like you're at any disadvantage in terms of knowledge? Are you capable of bidding on adjacent acreage? Do you have the knowledge base as yet?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say we're definitely not at any disadvantage. I think from what I've seen and our ability to execute and our ability to take advantage of the learnings and take advantage of the learnings quick, we're in a great position.
componenttext: I'd say we're definitely not at any disadvantage. I think from what I've seen and our ability to execute and our ability to take advantage of the learnings and take advantage of the learnings quick, we're in a great position.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. The last one, Gulf of Mexico, Dantzler, Big Bend update on how they're performing. And then Gunflint seems to have come on about exactly where you thought -- the timing you thought it would. And then obviously, fields did decline, so any e
componenttext: That's helpful. The last one, Gulf of Mexico, Dantzler, Big Bend update on how they're performing. And then Gunflint seems to have come on about exactly where you thought -- the timing you thought it would. And then obviously, fields did decline, so any exploration plans?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think on the 3 projects, to your point, we brought on 3 major projects over the last year on time, performance has been as expected or better, and on cost. So again, that's a testament to our major project execution that's shown up here very visibly in
componenttext: I think on the 3 projects, to your point, we brought on 3 major projects over the last year on time, performance has been as expected or better, and on cost. So again, that's a testament to our major project execution that's shown up here very visibly in the Gulf of Mexico over the last year. I think no, as we look forward here, I would expect some decline now that we've had Dantzler and Big Bend on for about a year. It's in line with what we've said originally. Gunflint, we'll see to what extent it ramps up after we get it ramped up. And as I mentioned before, we've built in some downtime expectations from some of that onshore facility coming back online or some of its downtime and some storm downtime here near term. So everything's performing as expected out there, at least as well as expected.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Webcast and Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahe
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Webcast and Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I hope you've had a chance to review our third quarter 2016 operational and financial news release, which highlights once again robust outperformance for Noble Energy. We've also po
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I hope you've had a chance to review our third quarter 2016 operational and financial news release, which highlights once again robust outperformance for Noble Energy. We've also posted a few supplemental slides on our website. And later today, we anticipate filing our 10-Q with the SEC. 
Following our prepared comments, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Dave Stover, Chairman and CEO; and Gary Willingham, EVP of Operations, will provide some commentary. While Ken Fisher, EVP and CFO; and Keith Elliott, SVP of our Eastern Med assets, will join for Q&A. 
I want to remind everyone that this event may contain projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full discover -- disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
Before highlighting our performance for the third quarter, I want to ensure you all saw the announcement that Noble Energy will be hosting an additional webcast in just 2 weeks, on November 16 at 9:00 a.m. Central Time. Our team is looking forward to providing a long-term outlook, focusing on the company's U.S. onshore operations so you'll understand today if we saved our plans for 2017 and beyond. 
Now let's get to the numbers. Total volumes for the quarter were 425,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 12% in absolute and 8% pro forma over the third quarter of last year. Versus our internal expectations, total volumes were 15,000 barrels equivalent per day, above the midpoint of our range. 
By business unit, this was the result of higher-than-expected volumes in the DJ Basin, Gulf of Mexico and West Africa. By hydrocarbon, oil was a significant outperformer, comprising nearly 60% of the higher number. NGLs were also higher, and natural gas volumes reflected a record quarter from Tamar and Israel. 
We want to highlight that across the board, nearly every unit cost item came in under expectations as well. This was the result of higher-than-forecasted production and continued capital efficiency and cost control. The higher volumes and lower cost contributed to a meaningful earnings and cash flow beats for the quarter. Financial liquidity at the end of the third quarter grew to nearly $6 billion, including $1.8 billion in cash. 
During the quarter, we received approximately $300 million following the very successful Noble Midstream IPO. As Noble Energy is the General partner, Noble Midstream's results are fully consolidated into Noble's financials. You probably noticed some specific adjustments in our earnings release tables to reflect the new public entity, both on the income statement and the balance sheet, where we have identified the portion attributable to the noncontrolling interest. Dave will talk more about the success of NBLX and how it positions us with competitive advantages for the future. 
With that, I'll turn the call to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. After being unable to engage with you for the last couple of months due to the timing of our midstream IPO, I've been looking forward to this opportunity to share what Noble has accomplished, and we've accomplishe
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. After being unable to engage with you for the last couple of months due to the timing of our midstream IPO, I've been looking forward to this opportunity to share what Noble has accomplished, and we've accomplished a lot. 
As you look at our operating and financial numbers, they are up where we want them to be up and down where we want them to be down. Last quarter, I commented that Noble Energy was executing at the highest levels I have seen in my time with the company. Results from the most recent quarters solidify that view even further. 
Taking a look at Slide 3. We have delivered tremendous results everywhere: Volumes, product mix, cost control and cash generation. We're delivering everything we set out to accomplish in 2016 and more. Much more. 
Yet the numbers are only a part of the story. We've also recently accomplished some big things that are strategically significant to our future. These include the highly successful launch of the Noble Midstream IPO, the separation of the Marcellus JV to provide both companies independent control of their future development, the signing of Leviathan's first sizable sales export contract, the significant debt reduction helps support our long-term growth plans and an acceleration of our onshore development program. All of this was accomplished while delivering top-quartile debt adjusted production cash flow growth in 2016. 
Looking beyond 2016, we will provide a view in our future at the November 16 investor event. The combination of our exceptional portfolio, leading operational execution and financial strength and flexibility provides significant competitive advantages differentiates our future, our growth potential and our value. 
This morning, I'd like to spend a few moments on a number of the recent major accomplishments mentioned. Steps along the path in delivering our future, steps that are enhancing our ability to accelerate our growth and steps that are generating industry-leading returns. 
Starting with operational execution. The momentum we have generated in every area of the business continues to deliver outstanding results. We highlighted in last night's release a number of new wells in the DJ Basin, Eagle Ford and Delaware Basin. Our teams continue to push the leading edge of enhanced completions across our onshore business, and we remain encouraged by the productivity and capital efficiency improvements. 
We have recently added 2 rigs to our U.S. drilling programs, bringing our total onshore rig count to 6: 2 in the DJ, 2 in the Eagle Ford and 2 in the Delaware. Based upon our current view of pricing, we're positioned for additional activity increases in 2017. 
In the Eastern Mediterranean, third quarter volumes were outstanding. They reflect the high seasonal period in Israel and also the government's continued focus on increased dependence on gas usage for power generation. We've also made excellent progress on Leviathan and have line of sight on projects sanctioned around the end of the year or early next year. 
And in our other offshore areas, we benefited from strong reservoir and facility performance at Gunflint in the Gulf of Mexico and the Alba compression project in Equatorial Guinea. Both are producing higher rates than expected. 
Beyond operational -- beyond operations excellence, we have continued to strengthen our financial position. The successful IPO of our Noble Midstream business highlights tremendous work by Terry and the midstream team. With the IPO proceeds, this public vehicle has already returned the capital investments made in those assets back to Noble. The long-term value potential for both Noble and the NBLX orders is substantial. 
Slide 4 highlights the NBLX assets. And on Slide 5, we have shown a combined valuation to Noble for both Noble Midstream as well as CONE. In total, we estimate a midstream value for Noble at over $2.5 billion. This value is expected to grow quickly as we move into 2017 and beyond. 
Including the initial distribution from NBLX, we have generated almost $1.5 billion in portfolio proceeds this year and increased total liquidity to nearly $6 billion. We are in the enviable position of being able to accelerate development activity while also reducing leverage to maintain our financial strength and flexibility. We're doing precisely what we have said we would do all year. 
Since the end of the third quarter, we have paid down $850 million of our term loan. With free cash flow being generated organically and expected portfolio proceeds, we still estimate that at the end of the year, we will have well over $5 billion in liquidity on hand. 
The third area of competitive advantage is our portfolio. Earlier this week, we, along with CONSOL, announced an intent to dissolve the upstream Marcellus joint venture. It's now been 5 years since we entered the asset with CONSOL. The accomplishments over that time period have been remarkable. Significant ramps in both production and recoverable resources have highlighted the strong coordination and technical excellence of both companies. 
Over the last several months, the parties focused on how to maximize value and flexibility. We agreed to split the upstream acreage and production in such a way that each party controls 100% of its assets and future activity. Noble will retain 100% working interest and 363,000 acres in current production of approximately 450 million cubic feet equivalent per day. We will keep our core wet gas Marcellus operations in Majorsville and Moundsville, including the Utica potential in Moundsville and substantial gas inventory for future development. 
You can see a before-and-after look of the transaction on Slide 7. Closing is anticipated before year-end. 
I'd like to personally express my appreciation to both the CONSOL and Noble teams that have worked so well together for the past 5 years. There are no changes to the CONE midstream ownership, acreage dedications or services. We will continue to work with CONSOL as sponsors to enhance the value of that business. 
Other recent portfolio optimization efforts have included the DJ Basin acreage trade and initial sell-down of our Tamar interest. We anticipate the Tamar transaction will close during the fourth quarter. 
On the topic of portfolio, I want to address the recent market speculation around Noble's interest in a potential Permian bolt-on acquisition. Let me be clear. We feel no urgency nor have any desire to bid up prices in the basin. And as always, we will be patient and selective in evaluating any additions to our position in the heart of the Delaware play. We remain focused on increasing drilling activity in our existing position, and we'll highlight during our call in 2 weeks how dramatically and quickly we can grow our volumes and increase our value there. 
Each step we have made over the last couple of years, including those mentioned today, has been centered on enhancing our future and the value potential for shareholders. Our company is well positioned and focused. Our capital is prioritized to accelerate our Delaware Basin asset, develop our DJ and Eagle Ford positions and post sanction implement the first phase of Leviathan. These themes will be clear in the investor call in 2 weeks. 
Now let me hand the call over to Gary to walk through our excellent operating performance.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. We have a lot to share with you on November 16, so I'll keep my comments relatively short today. Let's start with the DJ Basin. Third quarter production totaled 113,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. That's
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. We have a lot to share with you on November 16, so I'll keep my comments relatively short today. 
Let's start with the DJ Basin. Third quarter production totaled 113,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. That's several thousand barrels equivalent per day higher than expected. This resulted from continued success with enhanced completions and relatively low line pressures throughout the basin. Majority of our activity in the DJ Basin continues to focus on the Wells Ranch and East Pony areas, although we also brought online several Mustang wells during the quarter. In total, we commenced production on 43 wells, with proppant concentration averaging over 1,600 pounds per lateral foot. I'm particularly encouraged about some DJ wells that have recently come on production, testing even higher proppant concentrations, 2,000 pounds plus. And we should have some Wells Ranch higher results for you on the call in a couple of weeks. 
During the quarter, we completed the previously announced strategic acreage trade with PDC Energy, which expanded our Wells Ranch position by approximately 20%. This transaction is consistent with our strategy to focus on areas with higher oil content, where we have more contiguous acreage and can drive efficiency gains through longer lateral development and existing infrastructure. For Noble, this transaction added substantial value to our forward development plans. 
Moving to Texas. We continued our successes in the Delaware with the Johnny Ringo 9 3H well. The well is nearly 5,000 feet in lateral length and completed with 2,500 pounds of proppant per lateral foot and slickwater fluid. Another outstanding well, one of the top 2 industry wells in the third quarter in the basin. Total production from the well is almost 1,600 barrels of oil equivalent per day with approximately 70% oil. 
For the second rig added to our position there, the pace of our drilling and completions will ramp up quickly. Fourth quarter activity will be higher than the first 3 quarters of the year combined, with an even further acceleration into 2017. I'm excited about the fact that we are now doing our first pad drilling in our first long lateral wells. Also, we will soon be testing multiple zones beyond the Wolfcamp Bay that we have in the heart of the Delaware Basin. 
Over in the Eagle Ford, we announced strong results from the wells in Gates Ranch. The 5 lower Eagle Ford wells we brought on line in the quarter had 500-foot lateral spacing at an average lateral length of nearly 5,900 feet. IP-30 rates have averaged more than 3,100 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
During the third quarter, we shot in 33 Eagle Ford wells for about a month to perform offset tracks. In the fourth quarter, we're bringing on a number of new wells in Briscoe Ranch, including a couple in the upper Eagle Ford. and they will be Noble's first tests of this potentially large resource. 
Dave mentioned earlier the recent production performance at Tamar. As a result of the increasing Israeli gas demand outlook, we recently commenced drilling an additional development well at Tamar. And this well will provide reliability and additional production capacity. 
At Leviathan, we are continuing to target a final investment decision around year-end or early next year. We've now contracted up to 450 million cubic feet per day for 15 years, equating to estimated gross revenues of more than $12 billion. Our recent contracts with the National Electric Power Company of Jordan represents the first Leviathan export contract. We look forward to supplying gas to Jordan for many years into the future. The Leviathan FID work continues, and we're making substantial progress on all of the bids and awards. Over the next couple of months, we expect to finalize remaining key milestones for sanctions. This concludes additional domestic sales contracts and financing plans as well as completion of the engineering work, project cost estimates and required construction permits. 
Offshore in the Gulf of Mexico, we brought online our Gunflint development in mid-July. This is the third middle Miocene tieback to commence production in the last 12 months. And these 3 contributed to the more than doubling of our Gulf of Mexico volumes over the last year. The net amount from Gunflint to Noble Energy during the quarter was 6,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This is higher than expected due to additional open capacity at the host facility. 
We continue to see strong production from the Big Bend and Dantzler fields during the quarter and recently celebrated the 1-year anniversary in both of these fields. 
We've provided fourth quarter 2016 guidance on Slide 8. As mentioned in the press release, we are increasing our fourth quarter capital guidance to $425 million to $475 million, reflecting the rig additions and higher activity levels. Even with this activity acceleration, we will still be well under $1.5 billion in capital this year. 
We have maintained our previous fourth quarter volume guidance despite the impact of asset divestitures that were not previously modeled. Otherwise, we would've projected above the high end of our 400,000 to 410,000 barrels equivalent per day range. The largest of these transactions is the Marcellus JV separation that Dave talked to earlier. With the close anticipated in November, we expect about 7,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day impact on the fourth quarter. Making up the difference is higher volumes than previously expected in the DJ Basin and the Gulf of Mexico, which also contribute to a slightly higher oil mix for the quarter as well. 
We also reduced a few of our cost item expectations for the fourth quarter, including LOE and G&A. There are a lot of catalysts to look forward to as we approach 2017. Drilling activity is accelerating. The effectiveness of enhanced completions in all basins continues to improve, and we're leveraging our onshore infrastructure advantage with NBLX. In addition, our offshore assets continue to generate substantial cash flows to the business, and a sanction at Leviathan is near. We will have much more to show in 2 weeks. I hope you will plan to join us then as well. 
And at this time, we'll go ahead and open the call to questions.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

And I think just making that clear, since we really haven't had a chance to give a bigger-picture longer-term outlook for a few years now. As we've maneuvered through the last couple of years, I think we want to highlight how bright the future is for us.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Makes a lot of sense. And just one quick modeling question on the Eagle Ford. I know you guided to this last quarter, but your Texas volumes were impacted on a sequential basis by the shut-in of 33 wells. I know you brought on 5 in the quarter. How
componenttext: Great. Makes a lot of sense. And just one quick modeling question on the Eagle Ford. I know you guided to this last quarter, but your Texas volumes were impacted on a sequential basis by the shut-in of 33 wells. I know you brought on 5 in the quarter. How should we think about shut-ins in the Eagle Ford going forward? Is this an unusually high level of shut-ins? And how do we think about that perhaps going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arun, having 33 wells shut in, I would say, is unusually high. But shutting an offset well to frac new completions is standard in the area. We've had some of that all along. Rosetta had some of that in the past, so we'll continue to have that going f
componenttext: Yes, Arun, having 33 wells shut in, I would say, is unusually high. But shutting an offset well to frac new completions is standard in the area. We've had some of that all along. Rosetta had some of that in the past, so we'll continue to have that going forward. But 33 was an unusually high number, I would say.

componenttext: My first question is can you guys discuss the strategic drivers on the dissolution of the CNS JV? And given assets unlikely could be for capital first [ph] the balance sheet portfolio, should we expect a disposition? Or do you view the asset as a gas option or withholding? Any comments?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, think that the driver was, as we'd progressed and I think Nick addressed this on his call the other day, too. But as we progress over time, and you look just look at the different portfolios for both companies, it made a lot of sense to set it up to w
componenttext: No, think that the driver was, as we'd progressed and I think Nick addressed this on his call the other day, too. But as we progress over time, and you look just look at the different portfolios for both companies, it made a lot of sense to set it up to where we each could control our own development plans and our own future going forward. So I think that was the driver. And pure and simple, we had a great relationship for the 5 years and delivered a tremendous amount of value. But as you look forward and looked at it from just the whole portfolio aspect for each company, it made a lot of sense to set it up where each company could operate and drive at 100% their own portion of it. I think when we look at it going forward, we like the position we have there, especially the ability to control the timing and pace of development. And so we'll just see how that plays out and look at it relative to the returns of the other parts of our portfolio as we make decisions on capital allocation. But we like the position. It does give some nice option value and the best gas basin in the U.S. and it's still a significant position.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Yes, I think we're headed that direction now. We noted in the press release that we just ED-ed our first long lateral in the Delaware. It was almost 7,800-foot lateral length. As you know, we have nice contiguous position there and the ability to drill more long laterals going forward. And I think you'll see us do that just like you've seen in the transition in the DJ, where we averaged over 9,000 foot in lateral length in the third quarter. As far as the other zones go, we've mentioned in the past that we're testing or drilling our first lower Wolfcamp A well and our first Bone Spring well this quarter. They won't be on in fourth quarter. They won't come on till next year, but those will be the first test of those zones that Noble has drilled. And so look forward to those results next year.

componenttext: Well, yes, obviously, that depends on longer-term gas price, and we'll see how that plays out. I think in the Marcellus, we'll continue to watch how gas price plays out. I think we've always talked about keep kind of improving netbacks in the $3-type gas price. There's still a nice portion of it that will compete well over time. And I think as we've talked about, we'll lay that longer-term picture out here in a couple of weeks.

componenttext: Yes, Scott. You'll see a lot more on that here on the 16th. I'd say the range we put out there's, it's a realistic range. As we think about modeling this out, what should we think of as the constraint for you to push the envelope?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think will give you much better clearer picture of that so we can guide you to what that activity level will be. But I think when you think about the considerations, all of those are considerations. I think you have to look at cash generation or cash us
componenttext: I think will give you much better clearer picture of that so we can guide you to what that activity level will be. But I think when you think about the considerations, all of those are considerations. I think you have to look at cash generation or cash uses and cash generation, so you're going to look at the whole mix of that piece. Some of the things we've done this year already helped with setting up the activity for next year, like NBLX being out there, some of those types of things. So that will be a good supporter of activity going forward. I think the other elements you mentioned, how you look at your balance sheet. This key element also is just how do you efficiently and effectively drive that growth activity. And that's something that you want to make sure you're doing it efficiently, so you're creating value as you go and you're creating the most value optimizing the basis as you go. So all of those things are going to be considerations. I think the execution is going to be key. All of that. And I think if you look at the history of Noble, it's always been strong on execution, and that will continue to be the key attribute going forward, supplemented with the fact that we've maintained a strong balance sheet to support that execution. So those are the 2 key elements, both the financial strength and the operational execution that will help support the plan that we lay out for you.

You've accelerated and you're getting ready to accelerate more. And I understand that we're going to get more detail on that in a couple of weeks. But I wonder if you could characterize just this last data point you got with we had this really encouraging well result with high well rate, with a big fracked on it. Is this -- are you more in the area of -- are you more on the phase of figuring out what your completions going to be and honing in on what your design is going to be? Or is it in contrast? Is this more kind of opening people's eyes and increasing the possibilities of what would maybe looking at going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Charles, this is Gary. I think it's a little bit of both. I think we're certainly still in the phase of optimizing completions in the area, figuring out what the right proppant concentration is as we complete these wells. This is really the fourth well th
componenttext: Charles, this is Gary. I think it's a little bit of both. I think we're certainly still in the phase of optimizing completions in the area, figuring out what the right proppant concentration is as we complete these wells. This is really the fourth well that we've brought on as Noble Energy. And we completed this over [ph] 2,500 pounds of proppant. Third well, we were at 3,000 pounds of proppant. We said at the time we continue to test different ranges. That's what we're continuing to do. We've got another 5-or-so wells, 6 wells coming on in the fourth quarter. Those will be different proppant levels as well, testing all the way up to 5,000 pounds per foot. So we'll see those results here in another 3 months or so. So we're very much a still optimizing what the right completion strategy is for these wells. I think to your second part of your question, it does pretty clearly, I think demonstrate the quality of the acreage and the potential that's there as we continue to develop the most efficient strategy for playing this out. As we noted in the prepared comments, according to a third-party report that's out there, this well is the second-best well in the basin in the third quarter. So still a lot to do, still a lot of improvement. I think we can get beyond this, but hard to be disappointed in what we've seen so far. That's for sure.

componenttext: Well, I think, as we've mentioned, Doug, that now we can kind of control that pace of development. I think we've got, in our portion, that we're now operating in and control 100%. componenttext: Yes, Doug, I'm not sure I heard the very last part of the question. But as far as lateral length, there's pretty big disparity between what we tell in 3Q at over 9,000 feet and what we brought online. It's been around 6,000 feet. A part of that is where the activity has been focused. A large part of the wells we brought on in 3Q more in East Pony, which tends to be a little shorter lateral length. Most of what we drilled in 3Q within Wells Ranch, which tends to be longer lateral lengths. I think when you think about it going forward, the Wells Ranch we'll continue to see those long laterals as we move into areas in Mustang, in the coming years, you'll see long laterals there as well. Certainly, our preference is to continue to drill those long laterals everywhere we can, plus or minus, 9,000 feet. So that's the way I think about it in the areas that we're active in.

componenttext: Yes, David. We brought on our first Mustang IDP wells earlier in the year. We talked about that in the past, extremely excited about the performance of those wells. Very pleased with the results that we've seen. Again, it's an area where we can drill long laterals. We're just now starting to build on the infrastructure for that area, so we'll be able to take advantage of the efficiencies and the cost reductions from that when that's constructed just like we have in Wells Ranch and East Pony. But very excited about the results. EURs have been well above the type curve projections. componenttext: Pearce, this is Gary. We're starting to see a little bit of cost creep in some areas. Steel prices have gone up. Rig costs are starting to creep up ever so slightly. Those are probably the areas we've seen the most insofar. I wouldn't say it's anything significant yet. And as we've talked about in the past, well over 50% of the cost savings and capital efficiencies that we've been able to deliver over the last couple of years, we expect to stick with us even after prices come up and some of the service costs come back up. So not anything to be too concerned about yet. We've got a supply chain group here that stays very much on top of where everything is headed. We've got great relationships with our key partners and suppliers and continue to work at every chance we get.
