componenttext: That's right. You're not going to be [indiscernible] . It's a nice part about this splitting up for both companies is you do control your development plan, it's not controlling you.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then if I could ask another question about the Delaware Basin. I think you guys made it clear in your prepared comments that you're on your front foot there. You've accelerated and you're getting ready to accelerate more. And I understand that
componenttext: Got it. And then if I could ask another question about the Delaware Basin. I think you guys made it clear in your prepared comments that you're on your front foot there. You've accelerated and you're getting ready to accelerate more. And I understand that we're going to get more detail on that in a couple of weeks. But I wonder if you could characterize just this last data point you got with, we had this really encouraging well result with high well rate, with a big frac you put on it. Is this -- are you more in the area of -- are you more in the phase of figuring out what your completions going to be and honing in on what your recipe and design is going to be? Or is it in contrast? Is this more of a kind of opening people's eyes and increasing the possibilities of what we maybe looking at going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary. I think it's a little bit of both. I think we're certainly still in the phase of optimizing completions in the area, figuring out what the right proppant concentration is as we complete these wells. This is really the fourth well that we've
componenttext: This is Gary. I think it's a little bit of both. I think we're certainly still in the phase of optimizing completions in the area, figuring out what the right proppant concentration is as we complete these wells. This is really the fourth well that we've brought on as Noble Energy. And we completed this when we were 2,500 pounds of proppant. The third well, we were at 3,000 pounds of proppant. We said at that time we'll continue to test different ranges. That's what we're continuing to do. We've got another 5-or-so wells, 6 wells coming on in the fourth quarter. Those will be different proppant levels as well, testing all the way up to 5,000 pounds per foot. So we'll see those results here in another 3 months or so. So we're very much still optimizing what the right completion strategy is for these wells. I think, to that your second part of your question, it does pretty clearly, I think, demonstrate the quality of the acreage and the potential that's there as we continue to develop the most efficient strategy for playing this out. As we noted in the prepared comments, according to a third-party report that's out there, this well is the second-best well in the basin in the third quarter. So still a lot to do, still a lot of improvement. I think we can get beyond this, but hard to be disappointed in what we've seen so far. That's for sure.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Dave, I wonder if I could follow up on a couple of those on the Marcellus. Could you characterize how your standalone outlook can contrasts, perhaps, with the joint decision process? And what I'm really getting at is that you've got a lot of ducks I assume do compete for capital on an asset that may otherwise decline. So is your object -- what's your objective there? I'm not digging in too much hopefully on the call in two weeks. To stabilize production? Or -- just characterize how you think about the outlook there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as we've mentioned, Doug, that now we can kind of control that pace of development. I think we've got, in our portion, that we're now operating in and control 100%, I think we've got 20 or little over 20 ducks in that, all high quality, tha
componenttext: Well, I think, as we've mentioned, Doug, that now we can kind of control that pace of development. I think we've got, in our portion, that we're now operating in and control 100%, I think we've got 20 or little over 20 ducks in that, all high quality, that will continue to play into our plan going forward and then the pace of development on the different pads, if you will, or the different areas will be driven by how it competes for capital. So we're not changing how we think about -- how we compete for capital on the best returns are going to play, and that's going to be where we're going to allocate our money. And I think you'll continue to see that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I'm getting at is it's obviously a sizable portion of your overall company production. So a decline rate could be a bit of a headwind. I'm just trying to understand if your objective is to start out by stabilizing production and go from ther
componenttext: I guess, what I'm getting at is it's obviously a sizable portion of your overall company production. So a decline rate could be a bit of a headwind. I'm just trying to understand if your objective is to start out by stabilizing production and go from there? Or is that not really the way you think about it?

componenttextpreview: I don't think we're thinking about it from that particular area. We're thinking about it from how we want to manage the whole company. Again, and that's the benefit of having the portfolio. I think as we'll lay out for you and especially as we focus on th
componenttext: I don't think we're thinking about it from that particular area. We're thinking about it from how we want to manage the whole company. Again, and that's the benefit of having the portfolio. I think as we'll lay out for you and especially as we focus on the whole onshore portfolio here in a couple weeks, I think it ought to be pretty clear on where we're putting our money and what the impact should be in each area.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up hopefully is an easy one. And again, I'm not sure how much deeper you want to go into today. But 43 wells in production versus 23 drilled with a very different average lateral lengths [ph] in those 2 buckets. Should we think of 23 wells
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up hopefully is an easy one. And again, I'm not sure how much deeper you want to go into today. But 43 wells in production versus 23 drilled with a very different average lateral lengths [ph] in those 2 buckets. Should we think of 23 wells, the 9,000-foot prospect [ph] average is that going to be the dominant length [ph] for those incremental as going forward? Or are we still going to see a mix, you think? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, I'm not sure I heard the very last part of the question. But as far as lateral length, yes, there's pretty big disparity between what we drilled in 3Q at over 9,000 feet and what we brought online at around 6,000 feet. A part of that is where t
componenttext: Yes, Doug, I'm not sure I heard the very last part of the question. But as far as lateral length, yes, there's pretty big disparity between what we drilled in 3Q at over 9,000 feet and what we brought online at around 6,000 feet. A part of that is where the activity has been focused. A large part of the wells we brought on in 3Q were in East Pony, which tend to be a little shorter lateral length. Most of what we drilled in 3Q within Wells Ranch, which tends to be longer lateral lengths. I think when you think about going forward, in Wells Ranch we'll continue to see those long laterals, as we move into areas in Mustang, in the coming years, you'll see long laterals there as well. Certainly, our preference is to continue to drill those long laterals everywhere we can, plus or minus 9,000 feet. So that's the way I'd think about it in the areas that we're active in.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So East Pony will still be the shorter lateral, I guess, is what you're saying?
componenttext: So East Pony will still be the shorter lateral, I guess, is what you're saying?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: East Pony still tends to be shorter lateral. There're some offsetting acres there. It's not quite as contiguous and locked up as well as Ranch and Mustang is.
componenttext: East Pony still tends to be shorter lateral. There're some offsetting acres there. It's not quite as contiguous and locked up as well as Ranch and Mustang is.

componenttext: Yes. When we brought on our first Mustang IDP wells earlier in the year. We talked about that in the past, extremely excited about the performance of those wells. This is down in the southern half of what we consider the Mustang IDP. So it's pretty good step out from where we've been most active over the last couple of years in Wells Ranch and East Pony. Very pleased with the results that we've seen. Again, it's an area where we can drill long laterals. We're just now starting to build out the infrastructure for that area, so we'll be able to take advantage of the efficiencies and the cost reductions from that when that's constructed just like we have in Wells Ranch and East Pony. But very excited about the results. EURs have been well above the type curve projections. And that's an area that as we get infrastructure built out over the next year or so, you'll see more activity in that area.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question pertains to service costs and what you're seeing on that front. Are you seeing any inflation right now in the basins you operate in? And then as you look out to 2017, how are you planning around that? And are you doing anything to try to
componenttext: My first question pertains to service costs and what you're seeing on that front. Are you seeing any inflation right now in the basins you operate in? And then as you look out to 2017, how are you planning around that? And are you doing anything to try to help mitigate any type of inflation?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary. We're starting to see some little bit of cost creep in some areas. Steel prices have gone up. Rig costs are starting to creep up ever so slightly. Those are probably the areas we've seen the most insofar. I wouldn't say it's anything signifi
componenttext: This is Gary. We're starting to see some little bit of cost creep in some areas. Steel prices have gone up. Rig costs are starting to creep up ever so slightly. Those are probably the areas we've seen the most insofar. I wouldn't say it's anything significant yet. And as we've talked about in the past, well over 50% of the cost savings and capital efficiencies that we've been able to deliver over the last couple of years, we expect to stick with us even after prices come up and some of the service costs come back up. So not anything to be too concerned about yet. We've got a supply chain group here that stays very much on top of where everything is headed. We've got great relationships with our key partners and suppliers and continue to work that every chance we get.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Right. I think it's getting a little more line of sight and some more progress on some of contracts, especially some of the domestic portion. We now have 400 million to 450 million a day with the addition of Jordan and what we've done already domestically. We've got some things we think we can pull together over the next short period of time: getting some of the additional permits in place; some of the agreements, whether it's between governments, within the government, some of the key elements of those lining up; some of the financing, making progress on that; get -- finalizing our bids coming in on some of the key technical aspects and just pulling those together. So I think everything's all on track. Great progress. I don't see anything that's giving me any concern at this point.

componenttext: I'll let Keith talk a little bit about that, but there's still seasonality. You see that as you move from third quarter to fourth quarter with Israel that you got the expected seasonality. But demand's been strong. And let me have Keith kind of accentuate that a little bit.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- I think what you see in Israel is -- we're really seeing the impact of the government's decree of this sort of 15% year-on-year coal reduction from 2015 to 2016. So that's had a meaningful impact. As Dave said, you're still seeing the seasona
componenttext: Yes, it's -- I think what you see in Israel is -- we're really seeing the impact of the government's decree of this sort of 15% year-on-year coal reduction from 2015 to 2016. So that's had a meaningful impact. As Dave said, you're still seeing the seasonality that go -- that comes in. But that seasonality, I would say, has probably been less of an issue this year as we've seen. Typically we see much more of a kind of dip in the shoulder months in spring and autumn. And we're not seeing as big a dip as we would historically expect.

componenttext: Looking at the location of the Johnny Ringo, that seems to be closer to the Calamity Jane well that had a lower oil cut. Could you talk about maybe the higher oil cut in Johnny Ringo that was driven by the completion technique or potentially where you landed in the zone?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's more the location of the well where we are in the zone. The Calamity Jane well in the far northeast side of the acreage, I think we got the toe section of that lateral into an area that can be a bit gassier, which is why you saw a little
componenttext: Yes. I think it's more the location of the well where we are in the zone. The Calamity Jane well in the far northeast side of the acreage, I think we got the toe section of that lateral into an area that can be a bit gassier, which is why you saw a little bit lower oil cut there. I think the oil cut that we've seen on the Johnny Ringo is probably more representative of what you should expect to see in the eastern half of that acreage.

componenttext: Our proppant loading has been creeping up, as we've talked about. I think we've been pretty conservative in the past about assuming the uplift that we would see on production from those higher loadings until we saw more history. I think the ability that we have in the fourth quarter now to offset the 7,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day that we're losing as part of the Marcellus trade with higher volumes in the DJ and GOM, you're seeing some of that performance start to show up. So I think the way we've got it modeled for 4Q is representative of what we're bringing on in 4Q. We'll see how those higher-concentration jobs perform over time. And we'll see where we go from there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Webcast and Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Brad Whitmarsh. Please go
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Noble Energy's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Webcast and Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I'd now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Brad Whitmarsh. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I hope you've had a chance to review our third quarter 2016 operational and financial news release, which highlights once again robust outperformance for Noble Energy. We've also po
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. I hope you've had a chance to review our third quarter 2016 operational and financial news release, which highlights once again robust outperformance for Noble Energy. We've also posted a few supplemental slides on our website. And later today, we anticipate filing our 10-Q with the SEC. 
Following our prepared comments, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] Dave Stover, Chairman and CEO; and Gary Willingham, EVP of Operations, will provide some commentary. While Ken Fisher, EVP and CFO; and Keith Elliott, SVP of our Eastern Med assets, will join for Q&A. 
I want to remind everyone that this event may contain projections and forward-looking statements as well as certain non-GAAP financial measures. You should read our full discover -- disclosures in our latest news release and SEC filings for a discussion of those items. 
Before highlighting our performance for the third quarter, I want to ensure you all saw the announcement that Noble Energy will be hosting an additional webcast in just 2 weeks, on November 16 at 9:00 a.m. Central Time. Our team is looking forward to providing a long-term outlook, focusing on the company's U.S. onshore operations so you'll understand today if we save our plans for 2017 and beyond. 
Now let's get to the numbers. Total volumes for the quarter were 425,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 12% in absolute and 8% pro forma over the third quarter of last year. Versus our internal expectations, total volumes were 15,000 barrels equivalent per day, above the midpoint of our range. 
By business unit, this was the result of higher-than-expected volumes in the DJ Basin, Gulf of Mexico and West Africa. By hydrocarbon, oil was a significant outperformer, comprising nearly 60% of the higher number. NGLs were also higher, and natural gas volumes reflected a record quarter from Tamar and Israel. 
We want to highlight that across the board, nearly every unit cost item came in under expectations as well. This was the result of higher-than-forecasted production and continued capital efficiency and cost control. The higher volumes and lower costs contributed to meaningful earnings and cash flow beats for the quarter. Financial liquidity at the end of the third quarter grew to nearly $6 billion, including $1.8 billion in cash. 
During the quarter, we received approximately $300 million following the very successful Noble Midstream IPO. As Noble Energy is the general partner, Noble Midstream's results are fully consolidated into Noble's financials. You probably noticed some specific adjustments in our earnings release tables to reflect the new public entity, both on the income statement and the balance sheet, where we have identified the portion attributable to the noncontrolling interest. Dave will talk more about the success of NBLX and how it positions us with competitive advantages for the future. 
With that, I'll turn the call to Dave.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. After being unable to engage with you for the last couple of months due to the timing of our Midstream IPO, I've been looking forward to this opportunity to share what Noble has accomplished, and we've accomplishe
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good morning, everyone. After being unable to engage with you for the last couple of months due to the timing of our Midstream IPO, I've been looking forward to this opportunity to share what Noble has accomplished, and we've accomplished a lot. 
As you look at our operating and financial numbers, they are up where we want them to be up and down where we want them to be down. Last quarter, I commented that Noble Energy was executing at the highest levels I have seen in my time with the company. Results from the most recent quarters solidify that view even further. 
Taking a look at Slide 3. We have delivered tremendous results everywhere: Volumes, product mix, cost control and cash generation. We're delivering everything we set out to accomplish in 2016 and more, much more. 
Yet the numbers are only a part of the story. We've also recently accomplished some big things that are strategically significant to our future. These include the highly successful launch of the Noble Midstream IPO, the separation of the Marcellus JV to provide both companies independent control of their future development, the signing of Leviathan's first sizable sales export contract, a significant debt reduction to help support our long-term growth plans and an acceleration of our onshore development program. All of this was accomplished while delivering top-quartile debt-adjusted production cash flow growth in 2016. 
Looking beyond 2016, we will provide a view into our future at the November 16 investor event. The combination of our exceptional portfolio, leading operational execution and financial strength and flexibility provide significant competitive advantages, differentiates our future, our growth potential and our value. 
This morning, I'd like to spend a few moments on a number of the recent major accomplishments mentioned. Steps along the path in delivering our future, steps that are enhancing our ability to accelerate our growth and steps that are generating industry-leading returns. 
Starting with operational execution. The momentum we have generated in every area of the business continues to deliver outstanding results. We highlighted in last night's release a number of new wells in the DJ Basin, Eagle Ford and Delaware Basin. Our teams continue to push the leading edge of enhanced completions across our onshore business, and we remain encouraged by the productivity and capital efficiency improvements. 
We have recently added 2 rigs to our U.S. drilling programs, bringing our total onshore rig count to 6: 2 in the DJ, 2 in the Eagle Ford and 2 in the Delaware. Based upon our current view of pricing, we're positioned for additional activity increases in 2017. 
In the Eastern Mediterranean, third quarter volumes were outstanding. They reflect the high seasonal period in Israel and also the government's continued focus on increased dependence on gas usage for power generation. We've also made excellent progress on Leviathan and have line of sight on projects sanctioned around the end of the year or early next year. 
And in our other offshore areas, we benefited from strong reservoir and facility performance at Gunflint in the Gulf of Mexico and the Alba compression project in Equatorial Guinea. Both are producing at higher rates than expected. 
Beyond operational -- beyond operations excellence, we have continued to strengthen our financial position. The successful IPO of our Noble Midstream business highlights tremendous work by Terry Gerhart and the Midstream team. With the IPO proceeds, this public vehicle has already returned the capital investments made in those assets back to Noble. The long-term value potential for both Noble and the NBLX unit holders [ph] is substantial. 
Slide 4 highlights the NBLX assets. And on Slide 5, we have shown a combined valuation to Noble for both Noble Midstream as well as CONE. In total, we estimate a midstream value for Noble at over $2.5 billion. This value is expected to grow quickly as we move into 2017 and beyond. 
Including the initial distribution from NBLX, we have generated almost $1.5 billion in portfolio proceeds this year and increased total liquidity to nearly $6 billion. We are in the enviable position of being able to accelerate development activity while also reducing leverage to maintain our financial strength and flexibility. We're doing precisely what we have said we would do all year. 
Since the end of the third quarter, we have paid down $850 million of our term loan. With free cash flow being generated organically and expected portfolio proceeds, we still estimate that at the end of the year, we will have well over $5 billion in liquidity on hand. 
The third area of competitive advantage is our portfolio. Earlier this week, we, along with CONSOL, announced an intent to dissolve the upstream Marcellus joint venture. It's now been 5 years since we entered the asset with CONSOL. The accomplishments over that time period have been remarkable. Significant ramps in both production and recoverable resources have highlighted the strong coordination and technical excellence of both companies. 
Over the last several months, the parties focused on how to maximize value and flexibility. We agreed to split the upstream acreage and production in such a way that each party controls 100% of its assets and future activity. Noble will retain 100% working interest and 363,000 acres in current production of approximately 450 million cubic feet equivalent per day. We will keep our core wet gas Marcellus operations in Majorsville and Moundsville, including the Utica potential in Moundsville and substantial gas inventory for future development. 
You can see a before-and-after look of the transaction on Slide 7. Closing is anticipated before year-end. 
I'd like to personally express my appreciation to both the CONSOL and Noble teams that have worked so well together for the past 5 years. There are no changes to the CONE midstream ownership, acreage dedications or services. We will continue to work with CONSOL as sponsors to enhance the value of that business. 
Other recent portfolio optimization efforts have included the DJ Basin acreage trade and initial sell-down of our Tamar interest. We anticipate the Tamar transaction will close during the fourth quarter. 
On the topic of portfolio, I want to address the recent market speculation around Noble's interest in a potential Permian bolt-on acquisition. Let me be clear. We feel no urgency nor have any desire to bid up prices in the basin. And as always, we will be patient and selective in evaluating any additions to our position in the heart of the Delaware play. We remain focused on increasing drilling activity in our existing position, and we'll highlight during our call in 2 weeks how dramatically and quickly we can grow our volumes and increase our value there. 
Each step we have made over the last couple of years, including those mentioned today, has been centered on enhancing our future and the value potential for shareholders. Our company is well positioned and focused. Our capital is prioritized to accelerate our Delaware Basin asset, develop our DJ and Eagle Ford positions and post sanction implement the first phase of Leviathan. These themes will be clear on the investor call in 2 weeks. 
Now let me hand the call over to Gary to walk through our excellent operating performance.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. We have a lot to share with you on November 16, so I'll keep my comments relatively short today. Let's start with the DJ Basin. Third quarter production totaled 113,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. That's
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good morning, everyone. We have a lot to share with you on November 16, so I'll keep my comments relatively short today. 
Let's start with the DJ Basin. Third quarter production totaled 113,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. That's several thousand barrels equivalent per day higher than expected. This resulted from continued success with enhanced completions and relatively low line pressures throughout the basin. Majority of our activity in the DJ Basin continues to focus on the Wells Ranch and East Pony areas, although we also brought online several Mustang wells during the quarter. In total, we commenced production on 43 wells, with proppant concentration averaging over 1,600 pounds per lateral foot. I'm particularly encouraged about some DJ wells that have recently come on production, testing even higher proppant concentrations, 2,000 pounds plus. And we should have some Wells Ranch higher intensity results for you on the call in a couple of weeks. 
During the quarter, we completed the previously announced strategic acreage trade with PDC Energy, which expanded our Wells Ranch position by approximately 20%. This transaction is consistent with our strategy to focus on areas with higher oil content, where we have more contiguous acreage and can drive efficiency gains through longer lateral development and existing infrastructure. For Noble, this transaction added substantial value to our forward development plans. 
Moving to Texas. We continued our successes in the Delaware with the Johnny Ringo 9 3H well. The well is nearly 5,000 feet in lateral length and completed with 2,500 pounds of proppant per lateral foot and slickwater fluid. Another outstanding well, one of the top 2 industry wells in the third quarter in the basin. Total production from the well is almost 1,600 barrels of oil equivalent per day with approximately 70% oil. 
With the second rig added to our position there, the pace of our drilling and completions will ramp up quickly. Fourth quarter activity will be higher than the first 3 quarters of the year combined, with an even further acceleration into 2017. I'm excited about the fact that we are now doing our first pad drilling in our first long lateral wells. Also, we will soon be testing multiple zones beyond the Wolfcamp Bay that we have in the heart of the Delaware Basin. 
Over in the Eagle Ford, we announced strong results from new wells in Gates Ranch. The 5 lower Eagle Ford wells we brought on line in the quarter had 500-foot lateral spacing and an average lateral length of nearly 5,900 feet. IP-30 rates have averaged more than 3,100 barrels of oil equivalent per day. 
During the third quarter, we shut-in 33 Eagle Ford wells for about a month to perform offset fracs.
In the fourth quarter, we're bringing on a number of new wells in Briscoe Ranch, including a couple in the upper Eagle Ford, and they will be Noble's first tests of this potentially large resource. 
Dave mentioned earlier the recent production performance at Tamar. As a result of the increasing Israeli gas demand outlook, we recently commenced drilling an additional development well at Tamar. And this well will provide reliability and additional production capacity. 
At Leviathan, we are continuing to target a final investment decision around year-end or early next year. We've now contracted up to 450 million cubic feet per day for 15 years, equating to estimated gross revenues of more than $12 billion. Our recent contracts with the National Electric Power Company of Jordan represents the first Leviathan export contract. We look forward to supplying gas to Jordan for many years into the future. The Leviathan FID work continues, and we're making substantial progress on all of the bids and awards. Over the next couple of months, we expect to finalize remaining key milestones for sanction. This includes additional domestic sales contracts and financing plans as well as completion of the engineering work, project cost estimates and required construction permits. 
Offshore in the Gulf of Mexico, we brought online our Gunflint development in mid-July. This is the third Middle Miocene tieback to commence production in the last 12 months. And these 3 contributed to the more than doubling of our Gulf of Mexico volumes over the last year. The net amount from Gunflint to Noble Energy during the quarter was 6,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. This is higher than expected due to additional open capacity at the host facility. 
We continue to see strong production from the Big Bend and Dantzler fields during the quarter and recently celebrated the 1-year anniversary in both of these fields. 
We've provided fourth quarter 2016 guidance on Slide 8. As mentioned in the press release, we are increasing our fourth quarter capital guidance to $425 million to $475 million, reflecting the rig additions and higher activity levels. Even with this activity acceleration, we will still be well under $1.5 billion in capital this year. 
We have maintained our previous fourth quarter volume guidance despite the impact of asset divestitures that were not previously modeled. Otherwise, we would've projected above the high end of our 400,000 barrel equivalent per day to 410,000 barrel equivalent per day range. The largest of these transactions is the Marcellus JV separation that Dave talked through earlier. With the close anticipated in November, we expect about 7,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day impact on the fourth quarter. Making up the difference is higher volumes than previously expected in the DJ Basin and the Gulf of Mexico, which also contribute to a slightly higher oil mix for the quarter as well. 
We also reduced a few of our cost item expectations for the fourth quarter, including LOE and G&A. There are a lot of catalysts to look forward to as we approach 2017. Drilling activity is accelerating. The effectiveness of enhanced completions in all basins continues to improve, and we're leveraging our onshore infrastructure advantage with NBLX. In addition, our offshore assets continue to generate substantial cash flows to the business, and a sanction at Leviathan is near. We will have much more to show in 2 weeks. I hope you will plan to join us then as well. 
And at this time, we'll go ahead and open the call to questions.

componenttext: Arun, I appreciate the question and also the plug for the 16th. I think, no doubt, we want to highlight just the performance and the long-term expectation performance of our onshore business. I think that gets lost a little bit at times, and I think we can do a great job of laying that out. And also, just what we're focusing on, where we expect to spend capital and what are going to be the growth drivers for us going out over multiple years. And I think just making that clear, since we really haven't had a chance to give a bigger-picture longer-term outlook for a few years now. As we've maneuvered through the last couple of years, I think we want to highlight how bright the future is for us.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Makes a lot of sense. And just one quick modeling question on the Eagle Ford. I know you guided to this last quarter, but your Texas volumes were impacted on a sequential basis by the shut-in of 33 wells. I know you brought on 5 in the quarter. How
componenttext: Great. Makes a lot of sense. And just one quick modeling question on the Eagle Ford. I know you guided to this last quarter, but your Texas volumes were impacted on a sequential basis by the shut-in of 33 wells. I know you brought on 5 in the quarter. How should we think about shut-ins in the Eagle Ford going forward? Is this an unusually high level of shut-ins? And how do we think about that perhaps going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, having 33 wells shut-in, I would say, is unusually high. But shutting an offset well to frac new completions is standard in the area. We've had some of that all along. Rosetta had some of that in the past, so we'll continue to have that going forward
componenttext: Yes, having 33 wells shut-in, I would say, is unusually high. But shutting an offset well to frac new completions is standard in the area. We've had some of that all along. Rosetta had some of that in the past, so we'll continue to have that going forward. But 33 was an unusually high number, I would say.

componenttext: My first question is can you guys discuss the strategic drivers on the dissolution of the CNX JV? And given the assets unlikely could be for capital, first the balance sheet portfolio, should we expect a disposition? Or do you view the asset as a gas option worth holding? Any comments?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that the driver was, as we'd progressed and I think Nick addressed this on his call the other day, too. But as we had progressed over time, and you look -- just looked at the different portfolios for both companies, it made a lot of sense to s
componenttext: No, I think that the driver was, as we'd progressed and I think Nick addressed this on his call the other day, too. But as we had progressed over time, and you look -- just looked at the different portfolios for both companies, it made a lot of sense to set it up to where we each could control our own development plans and our own future going forward. So I think that was the driver. And pure and simple, we had a great relationship for the 5 years and delivered a tremendous amount of value. But as you looked forward and looked at it from just the whole portfolio aspect for each company, it made a lot of sense to set it up where each company could operate and drive at 100% their own portion of it. I think when we look at it going forward, we like the position we have there, especially the ability to control the timing and pace of development. And so we'll just see how that plays out and look at it relative to the returns of the other parts of our portfolio as we make decisions on capital allocation. But we like the position. It does give some nice option value and the best gas basin in the U.S. And it's still a significant position.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So maybe that'll be clear on the 16th, when we see the forward capital spend. My second question or a few questions on the Delaware, and I realize it's early there. You'd given your contiguous position and long lateral leadership in the DJ. When do
componenttext: Great. So maybe that'll be clear on the 16th, when we see the forward capital spend. My second question or a few questions on the Delaware, and I realize it's early there. You'd given your contiguous position and long lateral leadership in the DJ. When do you expect to test longer laterals? And on the zones, you drilled 4 successful wells in the upper Wolfcamp with strong results. When are you planning to test the Bone Spring and lower Wolfcamp Bay?  I'll leave it there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll let Gary comment in a minute. But definitely, that's one of the areas we'll highlight our plans on the 16th. Gary can talk a little bit more specific about some of those aspects.
componenttext: Yes, I'll let Gary comment in a minute. But definitely, that's one of the areas we'll highlight our plans on the 16th. Gary can talk a little bit more specific about some of those aspects.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're headed that direction now. We noted in the press release that we just ED-ed our first long lateral in the Delaware. It was almost 7,800-foot lateral length. As you know, we have got a nice contiguous position there and the ability to dr
componenttext: Yes, I think we're headed that direction now. We noted in the press release that we just ED-ed our first long lateral in the Delaware. It was almost 7,800-foot lateral length. As you know, we have got a nice contiguous position there and the ability to drill more long laterals going forward. And I think you'll see us do that just like you've seen that transition in the DJ, where we averaged over 9,000 foot in lateral length in the third quarter. As far as the other zones go, we've mentioned in the past that we're testing or drilling our first lower Wolfcamp A well and our first Bone Spring well this quarter. They won't be on in fourth quarter. They won't come on till next year, but those will be the first tests of those zones that Noble has drilled. And so we look forward to those results next year.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Scott Hanold with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Scott Hanold with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could ask the Marcellus question in a different way. When you look at where returns are based on strip prices at the Marcellus, how does that rank with some of your plays and maybe you'll be giving some more specifics in a couple of weeks, but just g
componenttext: If I could ask the Marcellus question in a different way. When you look at where returns are based on strip prices at the Marcellus, how does that rank with some of your plays and maybe you'll be giving some more specifics in a couple of weeks, but just generalized, can you compete with the DJ and Eagle Ford and Permian right now?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, obviously, that depends on longer-term gas price, and we'll see how that plays out. I think right now, I think it's been pretty clear, our capital allocation has been in DJ, Delaware and Eagle Ford right now, and I don't see that changing near
componenttext: Well, yes, obviously, that depends on longer-term gas price, and we'll see how that plays out. I think right now, I think it's been pretty clear, our capital allocation has been in DJ, Delaware and Eagle Ford right now, and I don't see that changing near term. I think in the Marcellus, we'll continue to watch how gas price plays out. I think we've always talked about if you can keep kind of improving netbacks in the $3-type gas price, there's still a nice portion of it that will compete well over time. And I think as we've talked about, we'll lay that longer-term picture out here in a couple of weeks.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up question, in the Permian, you all have added a rig. You're up at 2 right now. Logistically, what is on the footprint you've right now, what do you think the max capacity of being able to run rigs on that position is? And maybe it'
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up question, in the Permian, you all have added a rig. You're up at 2 right now. Logistically, what is on the footprint you've right now, what do you think the max capacity of being able to run rigs on that position is? And maybe it's wells, not rigs. But just generalize, can you run 4, 5, 6 rigs on that position? What is your view over the long term on that asset?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You'll see a lot more on that here on the 16th. I'd say the range you put out there's, it's a realistic range. Probably, the lower end of that range on a rig count over time given the efficiencies we expect to continue to generate there and drilling
componenttext: Yes. You'll see a lot more on that here on the 16th. I'd say the range you put out there's, it's a realistic range. Probably, the lower end of that range on a rig count over time given the efficiencies we expect to continue to generate there and drilling more wells with fewer rigs, just like we've seen in the DJ over time. But for now, we've added a second rig. We'll ramp up activity from there. We'll make sure that we can do it in an efficient and safe manner. And we'll talk more on the 16th about how quickly we increase it further from there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shifting a bit to international. You mentioned the FID for Leviathan is potentially by year-end or early next year. I know you haven't actually done that yet, but can you talk to the financing strategy there? How quickly you would expect and how significa
componenttext: Shifting a bit to international. You mentioned the FID for Leviathan is potentially by year-end or early next year. I know you haven't actually done that yet, but can you talk to the financing strategy there? How quickly you would expect and how significantly we should expect the capital budget to go up as you prepare for that growth? And then the interest level in outspending cash flow?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think when you think about Leviathan, we've always talked about that as probably majority investment will occur over 3 years with probably the larger portion of it in the second and third year, though the first portion's probably less than 1/3 of t
componenttext: Yes. I think when you think about Leviathan, we've always talked about that as probably majority investment will occur over 3 years with probably the larger portion of it in the second and third year, though the first portion's probably less than 1/3 of the total capital. The other nice part about that is we've essentially prefunded that first year with the sell-down of the interest we've sold down this year in the Eastern Med. So we're in good shape there from the standpoint of being able to fund Leviathan and not take away from any of our other development. What was the other part of your question, Brian?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The extent to which you'd outspend cash flow or we would see that versus project financing or financing Leviathan through additional asset sales, including Leviathan itself?
componenttext: The extent to which you'd outspend cash flow or we would see that versus project financing or financing Leviathan through additional asset sales, including Leviathan itself?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think a good point because what we've also said is I would think high likelihood, almost an expectation that before Leviathan comes on production, we'll have sold down the other 7% or 8% of Tamar. Chance we could sell down some interest in Le
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think a good point because what we've also said is I would think high likelihood, almost an expectation that before Leviathan comes on production, we'll have sold down the other 7% or 8% of Tamar. Chance we could sell down some interest in Leviathan also. We've always said that we'd be open to that for the right price, especially post sanction. So I think you've got a number of ways to make sure that you've got that funded, along with the fact that we're still looking at some project financing. And I expect that will still be an element of things.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then going back to on the onshore, obviously, a lot of specifics you're planning from a couple of weeks from now. But just more strategically, how do you think about what the constraint is to how aggressively you push the envelope onshore U.S.
componenttext: Got it. And then going back to on the onshore, obviously, a lot of specifics you're planning from a couple of weeks from now. But just more strategically, how do you think about what the constraint is to how aggressively you push the envelope onshore U.S.? Is it a cash flow constraint? Is it a leverage target for the company overall? Is it you want to increase activity to the point at which operational efficiency would be sacrificed through something else? As we think about modeling this out, what should we think of as the constraint to where you push the envelope?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we'll give you much better clearer picture of that so we can guide you to what that activity level will be. But I think when you think about the considerations, all of those are considerations. I think you have to look at cash generation or cash u
componenttext: I think we'll give you much better clearer picture of that so we can guide you to what that activity level will be. But I think when you think about the considerations, all of those are considerations. I think you have to look at cash generation or cash uses and cash generation, so you're going to look at the whole mix of that piece. Some of the things we've done this year already helped with setting up the activity for next year, like NBLX being out there, some of those types of things. So that will be a good supporter of activity going forward. I think the other elements you mentioned, how you look at your balance sheet. The key element also is just how do you efficiently and effectively drive the growth activity. And that's something that you want to make sure you're doing it efficiently, so you're creating value as you go and you're creating the most value you can and optimizing the asset base as you go. So all of those things are going to be considerations. I think the execution is going to be key to all of that and I think if you look at the history of Noble, it's always been strong on execution, and that will continue to be the key attribute going forward, supplemented with the fact that we've maintained a strong balance sheet to support that execution. So those are the 2 key elements, both the financial strength and the operational execution that will help support the plan that we lay out for you.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: If I could ask one more question about the Marcellus. As I look at your map and you have what 363,000 net acres now. What -- can you give us an idea what percentage of that is HBP? And if the natural gas strip bears out the way it looks right now, we're looking at $3 for the next few years, what do you imagine that acreage position will be 2 years to 3 years down the line?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the nice part about it is that it's almost all HBP. So you have the flexibility, which I think the heart of your question is. You have the flexibility to develop it and maintain the position that gives you that optionality going forward, Cha
componenttext: Well, I think the nice part about it is that it's almost all HBP. So you have the flexibility, which I think the heart of your question is. You have the flexibility to develop it and maintain the position that gives you that optionality going forward, Charles. So I don't think you lose anything or are forced to have to drill something that you're not ready to drill.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Right. That's what I thought. You got long-dated options.

componenttext: That's right. You're not going to be [indiscernible] . It's a nice part about this splitting up for both companies is you do control your development plan, it's not controlling you.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then if I could ask another question about the Delaware Basin. I think you guys made it clear in your prepared comments that you're on your front foot there. You've accelerated and you're getting ready to accelerate more. And I understand that
componenttext: Got it. And then if I could ask another question about the Delaware Basin. I think you guys made it clear in your prepared comments that you're on your front foot there. You've accelerated and you're getting ready to accelerate more. And I understand that we're going to get more detail on that in a couple of weeks. But I wonder if you could characterize just this last data point you got with, we had this really encouraging well result with high well rate, with a big frac you put on it. Is this -- are you more in the area of -- are you more in the phase of figuring out what your completions going to be and honing in on what your recipe and design is going to be? Or is it in contrast? Is this more of a kind of opening people's eyes and increasing the possibilities of what we maybe looking at going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary. I think it's a little bit of both. I think we're certainly still in the phase of optimizing completions in the area, figuring out what the right proppant concentration is as we complete these wells. This is really the fourth well that we've
componenttext: This is Gary. I think it's a little bit of both. I think we're certainly still in the phase of optimizing completions in the area, figuring out what the right proppant concentration is as we complete these wells. This is really the fourth well that we've brought on as Noble Energy. And we completed this when we were 2,500 pounds of proppant. The third well, we were at 3,000 pounds of proppant. We said at that time we'll continue to test different ranges. That's what we're continuing to do. We've got another 5-or-so wells, 6 wells coming on in the fourth quarter. Those will be different proppant levels as well, testing all the way up to 5,000 pounds per foot. So we'll see those results here in another 3 months or so. So we're very much still optimizing what the right completion strategy is for these wells. I think, to that your second part of your question, it does pretty clearly, I think, demonstrate the quality of the acreage and the potential that's there as we continue to develop the most efficient strategy for playing this out. As we noted in the prepared comments, according to a third-party report that's out there, this well is the second-best well in the basin in the third quarter. So still a lot to do, still a lot of improvement. I think we can get beyond this, but hard to be disappointed in what we've seen so far. That's for sure.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Doug Leggate with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dave, I wonder if I could follow up on a couple of those on the Marcellus. Could you characterize how your standalone outlook can contrasts, perhaps, with the joint decision process? And what I'm really getting at is that you've got a lot of ducks I assum
componenttext: Dave, I wonder if I could follow up on a couple of those on the Marcellus. Could you characterize how your standalone outlook can contrasts, perhaps, with the joint decision process? And what I'm really getting at is that you've got a lot of ducks I assume do compete for capital on an asset that may otherwise decline. So is your object -- what's your objective there? I'm not digging in too much hopefully on the call in two weeks. To stabilize production? Or -- just characterize how you think about the outlook there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, as we've mentioned, Doug, that now we can kind of control that pace of development. I think we've got, in our portion, that we're now operating in and control 100%, I think we've got 20 or little over 20 ducks in that, all high quality, tha
componenttext: Well, I think, as we've mentioned, Doug, that now we can kind of control that pace of development. I think we've got, in our portion, that we're now operating in and control 100%, I think we've got 20 or little over 20 ducks in that, all high quality, that will continue to play into our plan going forward and then the pace of development on the different pads, if you will, or the different areas will be driven by how it competes for capital. So we're not changing how we think about -- how we compete for capital on the best returns are going to play, and that's going to be where we're going to allocate our money. And I think you'll continue to see that.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I'm getting at is it's obviously a sizable portion of your overall company production. So a decline rate could be a bit of a headwind. I'm just trying to understand if your objective is to start out by stabilizing production and go from ther
componenttext: I guess, what I'm getting at is it's obviously a sizable portion of your overall company production. So a decline rate could be a bit of a headwind. I'm just trying to understand if your objective is to start out by stabilizing production and go from there? Or is that not really the way you think about it?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're thinking about it from that particular area. We're thinking about it from how we want to manage the whole company. Again, and that's the benefit of having the portfolio. I think as we'll lay out for you and especially as we focus on th
componenttext: I don't think we're thinking about it from that particular area. We're thinking about it from how we want to manage the whole company. Again, and that's the benefit of having the portfolio. I think as we'll lay out for you and especially as we focus on the whole onshore portfolio here in a couple weeks, I think it ought to be pretty clear on where we're putting our money and what the impact should be in each area.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My follow-up hopefully is an easy one. And again, I'm not sure how much deeper you want to go into today. But 43 wells in production versus 23 drilled with a very different average lateral lengths [ph] in those 2 buckets. Should we think of 23 wells
componenttext: Okay. My follow-up hopefully is an easy one. And again, I'm not sure how much deeper you want to go into today. But 43 wells in production versus 23 drilled with a very different average lateral lengths [ph] in those 2 buckets. Should we think of 23 wells, the 9,000-foot prospect [ph] average is that going to be the dominant length [ph] for those incremental as going forward? Or are we still going to see a mix, you think? And I'll leave it there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Doug, I'm not sure I heard the very last part of the question. But as far as lateral length, yes, there's pretty big disparity between what we drilled in 3Q at over 9,000 feet and what we brought online at around 6,000 feet. A part of that is where t
componenttext: Yes, Doug, I'm not sure I heard the very last part of the question. But as far as lateral length, yes, there's pretty big disparity between what we drilled in 3Q at over 9,000 feet and what we brought online at around 6,000 feet. A part of that is where the activity has been focused. A large part of the wells we brought on in 3Q were in East Pony, which tend to be a little shorter lateral length. Most of what we drilled in 3Q within Wells Ranch, which tends to be longer lateral lengths. I think when you think about going forward, in Wells Ranch we'll continue to see those long laterals, as we move into areas in Mustang, in the coming years, you'll see long laterals there as well. Certainly, our preference is to continue to drill those long laterals everywhere we can, plus or minus 9,000 feet. So that's the way I'd think about it in the areas that we're active in.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So East Pony will still be the shorter lateral, I guess, is what you're saying?
componenttext: So East Pony will still be the shorter lateral, I guess, is what you're saying?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: East Pony still tends to be shorter lateral. There're some offsetting acres there. It's not quite as contiguous and locked up as well as Ranch and Mustang is.
componenttext: East Pony still tends to be shorter lateral. There're some offsetting acres there. It's not quite as contiguous and locked up as well as Ranch and Mustang is.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When we brought on our first Mustang IDP wells earlier in the year. We talked about that in the past, extremely excited about the performance of those wells. This is down in the southern half of what we consider the Mustang IDP. So it's pretty good s
componenttext: Yes. When we brought on our first Mustang IDP wells earlier in the year. We talked about that in the past, extremely excited about the performance of those wells. This is down in the southern half of what we consider the Mustang IDP. So it's pretty good step out from where we've been most active over the last couple of years in Wells Ranch and East Pony. Very pleased with the results that we've seen. Again, it's an area where we can drill long laterals. We're just now starting to build out the infrastructure for that area, so we'll be able to take advantage of the efficiencies and the cost reductions from that when that's constructed just like we have in Wells Ranch and East Pony. But very excited about the results. EURs have been well above the type curve projections. And that's an area that as we get infrastructure built out over the next year or so, you'll see more activity in that area.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question pertains to service costs and what you're seeing on that front. Are you seeing any inflation right now in the basins you operate in? And then as you look out to 2017, how are you planning around that? And are you doing anything to try to
componenttext: My first question pertains to service costs and what you're seeing on that front. Are you seeing any inflation right now in the basins you operate in? And then as you look out to 2017, how are you planning around that? And are you doing anything to try to help mitigate any type of inflation?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary. We're starting to see some little bit of cost creep in some areas. Steel prices have gone up. Rig costs are starting to creep up ever so slightly. Those are probably the areas we've seen the most insofar. I wouldn't say it's anything signifi
componenttext: This is Gary. We're starting to see some little bit of cost creep in some areas. Steel prices have gone up. Rig costs are starting to creep up ever so slightly. Those are probably the areas we've seen the most insofar. I wouldn't say it's anything significant yet. And as we've talked about in the past, well over 50% of the cost savings and capital efficiencies that we've been able to deliver over the last couple of years, we expect to stick with us even after prices come up and some of the service costs come back up. So not anything to be too concerned about yet. We've got a supply chain group here that stays very much on top of where everything is headed. We've got great relationships with our key partners and suppliers and continue to work that every chance we get.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my follow-up is just high level. What are the next steps on Leviathan to reach FID by the time you want it, by later this year?
componenttext: And then my follow-up is just high level. What are the next steps on Leviathan to reach FID by the time you want it, by later this year?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. I think it's getting a little more line of sight and some more progress on some of contracts, especially some of the domestic portion. We now have 400 million to 450 million a day with the addition of Jordan and what we've done already domestically
componenttext: Right. I think it's getting a little more line of sight and some more progress on some of contracts, especially some of the domestic portion. We now have 400 million to 450 million a day with the addition of Jordan and what we've done already domestically. We've got some things we think we can pull together over the next short period of time: getting some of the additional permits in place; some of the agreements, whether it's between governments, within the government, some of the key elements of those lining up; some of the financing, making progress on that; get -- finalizing our bids coming in on some of the key technical aspects and just pulling those together. So I think everything's all on track. Great progress. I don't see anything that's giving me any concern at this point.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- I think what you see in Israel is -- we're really seeing the impact of the government's decree of this sort of 15% year-on-year coal reduction from 2015 to 2016. So that's had a meaningful impact. As Dave said, you're still seeing the seasona
componenttext: Yes, it's -- I think what you see in Israel is -- we're really seeing the impact of the government's decree of this sort of 15% year-on-year coal reduction from 2015 to 2016. So that's had a meaningful impact. As Dave said, you're still seeing the seasonality that go -- that comes in. But that seasonality, I would say, has probably been less of an issue this year as we've seen. Typically we see much more of a kind of dip in the shoulder months in spring and autumn. And we're not seeing as big a dip as we would historically expect.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then maybe on the Gulf of Mexico. Can you provide, maybe this will come in a couple of weeks, but any insight on how do you expect volumes to track, in particular from the 3 most recent developments there at Gunflint, Big Bend and Dantzler over the next, I guess, as we look through 2017 over the next 15 months or so, any comment -- and then any commentary on kind of decline rates overall for that part of your business?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you're right, we'll show you more. But just in general, I think things are going as expected. You've seen Big Bend and Dantzler now on for a year, so we would expect those to start to decline. And Gunflint, we'll have the advantage of a full year next
componenttext: And you're right, we'll show you more. But just in general, I think things are going as expected. You've seen Big Bend and Dantzler now on for a year, so we would expect those to start to decline. And Gunflint, we'll have the advantage of a full year next year for Gunflint. It's been doing as expected, at least, as well as expected.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: But should we expect moderate decline out of the Gulf of Mexico next year, year-on-year?

componenttext: We'll go next to Gail Nicholson with KLR group.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at the location of the Johnny Ringo, that seems to be closer to the Calamity Jane well that had a lower oil cut. Could you talk about maybe the higher oil cut in Johnny Ringo that was driven by the completion technique or potentially where you lan
componenttext: Looking at the location of the Johnny Ringo, that seems to be closer to the Calamity Jane well that had a lower oil cut. Could you talk about maybe the higher oil cut in Johnny Ringo that was driven by the completion technique or potentially where you landed in the zone?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's more the location of the well where we are in the zone. The Calamity Jane well in the far northeast side of the acreage, I think we got the toe section of that lateral into an area that can be a bit gassier, which is why you saw a little
componenttext: Yes. I think it's more the location of the well where we are in the zone. The Calamity Jane well in the far northeast side of the acreage, I think we got the toe section of that lateral into an area that can be a bit gassier, which is why you saw a little bit lower oil cut there. I think the oil cut that we've seen on the Johnny Ringo is probably more representative of what you should expect to see in the eastern half of that acreage.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then looking at the updated 4Q volume guidance that you provided, the outperformance in the DJ, is that assuming a 1,600-pound per proppant foot loading? Or you talked about those 2,000 pounds that you did or is that higher expectation of
componenttext: Okay, great. And then looking at the updated 4Q volume guidance that you provided, the outperformance in the DJ, is that assuming a 1,600-pound per proppant foot loading? Or you talked about those 2,000 pounds that you did or is that higher expectation of proppant loading in the fourth quarter versus the third quarter proppant loading?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our proppant loading has been creeping up, as we've talked about. I think we've been pretty conservative in the past about assuming the uplift that we would see on production from those higher loadings until we saw more history. I think the ability that w
componenttext: Our proppant loading has been creeping up, as we've talked about. I think we've been pretty conservative in the past about assuming the uplift that we would see on production from those higher loadings until we saw more history. I think the ability that we have in the fourth quarter now to offset the 7,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day that we're losing as part of the Marcellus trade with higher volumes in the DJ and GOM, you're seeing some of that performance start to show up. So I think the way we've got it modeled for 4Q is representative of what we're bringing on in 4Q. We'll see how those higher-concentration jobs perform over time. And we'll see where we go from there.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Tim Rezvan with Mizuho Securities.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question. In prepared comments, I wanted to make sure I got the numbers right. There was discussion of $850 million of the term loan was paid down, and you expect liquidity of over $5 billion at year-end. Are there any other moving parts in that kin
componenttext: First question. In prepared comments, I wanted to make sure I got the numbers right. There was discussion of $850 million of the term loan was paid down, and you expect liquidity of over $5 billion at year-end. Are there any other moving parts in that kind of equation? Or is that just assuming you'll be free cash flow positive in the fourth quarter?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll be free cash flow positive in the quarter and we also expect to receive from proceeds from sell-down of the 3% interest in Tamar. So you'll have a very robust quarter. And we'll end the year in very strong position in terms of liquidity.
componenttext: We'll be free cash flow positive in the quarter and we also expect to receive from proceeds from sell-down of the 3% interest in Tamar. So you'll have a very robust quarter. And we'll end the year in very strong position in terms of liquidity.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then there's the $200 million as we close the CONSOL and Marcellus agreement that we'll be paying out there too, so those will probably be the moving pieces to think about.
componenttext: And then there's the $200 million as we close the CONSOL and Marcellus agreement that we'll be paying out there too, so those will probably be the moving pieces to think about.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then the timing of the possible 1% incremental sell-down, is there clarity on when that would be?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Their decision is by closing, so that's probably something we'll know more of over the next month. We will still expect closing probably over the next month or so of the initial 3%. And so they have to decide by closing.
componenttext: Their decision is by closing, so that's probably something we'll know more of over the next month. We will still expect closing probably over the next month or so of the initial 3%. And so they have to decide by closing.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And my follow-up question is more of a modeling one. The 4Q '16 NGL guidance you provided, if we take the midpoint, you're down about 9% quarter-over-quarter. Is that entirely from the Marcellus JV or there are kind of other factors driving th
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And my follow-up question is more of a modeling one. The 4Q '16 NGL guidance you provided, if we take the midpoint, you're down about 9% quarter-over-quarter. Is that entirely from the Marcellus JV or there are kind of other factors driving that?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- Yes, I think, obviously, there's some impact from the Marcellus portion there. Could be just a mix of what we're bringing on in the Eagle Ford from that balance, too. I think as we've seen in the DJ is actually a little higher oil cut, some of the
componenttext: The -- Yes, I think, obviously, there's some impact from the Marcellus portion there. Could be just a mix of what we're bringing on in the Eagle Ford from that balance, too. I think as we've seen in the DJ is actually a little higher oil cut, some of the other areas. Follow up with Brad, he can probably give you more insight into the specifics.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Mike Scialla with Stifel.
componenttext: We'll go next to Mike Scialla with Stifel.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Last quarter, the BOEM issued a notice to the Gulf of Mexico operators about posting supplemental surety bonds and other collateral, I guess, to ensure you have 100% of the featured decommissioning costs covered. Want to see if there's any impact to Noble
componenttext: Last quarter, the BOEM issued a notice to the Gulf of Mexico operators about posting supplemental surety bonds and other collateral, I guess, to ensure you have 100% of the featured decommissioning costs covered. Want to see if there's any impact to Noble based on that. And does that change the landscape for the Gulf of Mexico for the industry in general at all?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've been granted a decent amount of selfish insurance under the program, so that's the primary way we'll cover that. Secondly then, we would have access to surety bonds for any additional piece of that. So I don't see it having any real impact o
componenttext: I think we've been granted a decent amount of selfish insurance under the program, so that's the primary way we'll cover that. Secondly then, we would have access to surety bonds for any additional piece of that. So I don't see it having any real impact on us. I think the other thing that's beneficial is, is that your partners will also be posting collateral if they're less creditworthy. So I think that's actually in a way a good thing. So I don't see it having an impact on the way we think about that business.

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I want to see plans for the rig you have drilling at Tamar right now. Is that rig under long-term contract? What are you going to do with that rig going forward?
componenttext: Okay. And I want to see plans for the rig you have drilling at Tamar right now. Is that rig under long-term contract? What are you going to do with that rig going forward?

headline: Noble Energy, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The contract on that rolls off, I think, towards the summer of next year. We haven't defined exactly what we're doing after Tamar. We're in discussions on a number of different things there after this Tamar-8 well that we're drilling. That'll be -- I mean
componenttext: The contract on that rolls off, I think, towards the summer of next year. We haven't defined exactly what we're doing after Tamar. We're in discussions on a number of different things there after this Tamar-8 well that we're drilling. That'll be -- I mean, that well will go through probably drilling completion into probably late first quarter or so.
